ENFORCEMENT_RESULT: In October 2006, SSI Korea pleaded guilty to violating the anti-bribery and accounting provisions of the FCPA and agreed to a $7.5 million criminal fine with the DOJ.  In October 2006, Schnizter Steel entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ and consented to a SEC cease-and-desist order and disgorgement and pre-judgment interest of $7.7 million.  The company agreed to retain a compliance monitor for three years.  According to the company, the deferred prosecution agreement expired by its terms on October 15, 2009.In June 2007, Si Chan Wooh pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate the FCPA and entered into a cooperation agreement with the DOJ.  In August 2007, without admitting or denying the allegations, Wooh settled a civil suit with the SEC, agreeing to approximately $40,000 in disgorgement, pre-judgment interest, and civil penalties.  Wooh also agreed to an order enjoining him from future violations.  Wooh's sentencing following his guilty plea was repeatedly delayed.  Finally, on October 14, 2011, the prosecutors filed a motion to drop its criminal information against Wooh, citing prosecutorial discretion.  It appears that the DOJ decided to dismiss following a protracted legal battle over how the case was handled and information from a FBI agent that Wooh was in fact a whistleblower in the case.  In December 2007, Robert W. Philip, without admitting or denying the allegations, settled a civil suit with the SEC, agreeing to pay $169,864 in disgorgement of bonuses, $16,537 in prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty of $75,000.  Philip also agreed to an order enjoining him from future violations.

On 18 July 2001, without admitting or denying the allegations, ABNH consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order enjoining the company from violating various federal securities laws, including the FCPA.  Additionally, the company consented to a USD 75,000 civil penalty. On 17 July 2001, Cantor pleaded guilty to a four-count information charging that he conspired to commit securities fraud, falsified corporate books and records, provided false statements to auditors, and violated the FCPA.  He has not yet been sentenced.On 10 April 2003, without admitting or denying the allegations, Cantor consented to an order permanently enjoining him from violating and/or aiding and abetting violations of various federal securities laws, including the FCPA.  Cantor also consented to a ten year officer and director bar.  This was a refiling of earlier charges against Cantor in 2001, which had been voluntarily dismissed without prejudice.

On 28 July 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Avery consented to the entry of a final judgment requiring the company to pay a civil penalty of USD 200,000.  Avery also agreed to the entry of a cease-and-desist order and to disgorgement of USD 273,213, together with USD 45,257 in prejudgment interest.

On 26 April 2007, BHSI pleaded guilty to violations of the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA, conspiracy to violate the FCPA, and aiding and abetting the falsification of the books and records of its parent company Baker Hughes.  BHSI agreed to pay an USD 11 million criminal fine, serve a three-year term of organizational probation, and adopt a comprehensive anti-bribery compliance program.  Simultaneously, Baker Hughes entered into a two-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ regarding the same underlying conduct, accepting responsibility for the conduct of its employees.  Baker Hughes agreed to hire an independent monitor for three years and to cooperate with the DOJ in its ongoing investigations.  Also on 26 April 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Baker Hughes agreed to the entry of a judgment ordering it to comply with the SEC cease-and-desist order issued on 12 September 2001 and permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA's book and records and internal controls provisions.  Baker Hughes agreed to pay USD 19,944,778 in disgorgement, USD 3,133,237.41 in prejudgment interest, and USD 10,000,000 in civil penalties.  It appears that Roy Fearnley has yet to reach a settlement with the SEC regarding the charges filed against him in the complaint.At the time, the USD 44 million in combined fines and penalties was the largest monetary sanction ever imposed in an FCPA case.On 28 April 2009, upon motion by the DOJ, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas dismissed with prejudice the charges against Baker Hughes, finding that the company had fully complied with all of its obligations under the deferred prosecution agreement.

On 15 January 2002, without admitting or denying the allegations, BellSouth settled a civil action with the SEC under which BellSouth was ordered to pay a USD 150,000 civil penalty.  BellSouth also consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order in a related proceeding.  The SEC complaint and cease-and-desist order found that BellSouth violated the books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.

On 10 March 2004, without admitted or denying the allegations, BJ Services consented to the entry of the cease-and-desist order by the SEC.  In light of BJ Services's prompt remedial actions and cooperation with the SEC, the company received no monetary penalty.  BJ Services also undertook certain remedial actions immediately following its internal investigation, including:  (i) arranging for the proper classification of the equipment associated with the January 2001 payment; (ii) revising the accounting treatment of the subject payments and including the appropriate supporting documentation in the accounting records; (iii) replacing the management of its Latin American region; (iv) expanding its existing corporate internal audit department and adding an additional audit manager in its Latin American region reporting directly to the BJ Services' Director of Internal Audit; (v) retaining an additional independent auditor to conduct a forensic audit of its books and records in Argentina; and (vi) adopting an improved and expanded FCPA education and prevention program for all of its regions worldwide.
On 26 September 2007, without admitting or denying the findings, Bristow consented to the entry of an administrative cease-and-desist order from the SEC.  No financial penalties were imposed.

On 3 October 2001, without admitting or denying the allegations, Chiquita consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order.  Under a settled complaint filed by the SEC on the same day, Chiquita agreed to pay a USD 100,000 civil penalty.

In 1998, CSS and Crites each pleaded guilty to a three-count information containing charges of conspiracy to violate the FCPA, substantive violations of the FCPA, and bribery of a U.S. public official.  Crites was sentenced to three years of probation and 150 hours of community service.  CSS was sentenced to a fine of USD 1,500 and one year of probation.
On 27 August 2008, without admitted or denying the SEC's allegations, Con-way agreed to the entry of a cease-and-desist order and to a USD 300,000 civil penalty.

On 25 July 2007, Delta & Pine and Turk Deltapine settled with the SEC, jointly agreeing to pay a USD 300,000 civil penalty.   On 26 July 2007, the SEC filed a cease-and-desist order against the two companies, under which Delta & Pine agreed to retain an independent consultant for a one-year period to review and make recommendations to enhance the company's compliance program.

On 13 February 2007, without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's complaint, Dow consented to pay a USD 325,000 civil penalty.  In a related proceeding on the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's findings, Dow consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order related to the same conduct.  The SEC recognized Dow's remedial efforts and cooperation with the Commission staff.  India's Central Bureau of Investigation ("CBI") is currently investigating DE-Nocil, as well as the company's product formulators in India, Agro Pack and Crop Health.  On 20 September 2010, India's Ministry of Agriculture blacklisted Dow AgroSciences (DE-Nocil's successor) for five years.  A special court of India's Central Bureau of Investigation ("CBI") had earlier that year found Dow AgroSciences guilty bribing a senior central government employee and his aides.  CBI recommended that the firm be blacklisted.

On 11 September 2009, following a two-and-a-half week trial in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, a federal jury found Gerald and Patricia Green guilty of conspiracy and substantive violations of the FCPA and money laundering laws.  Patricia Green was also found guilty of falsely subscribing U.S. income tax returns in connection with the same set of conduct.  The conspiracy and substantive FCPA charges each carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison, while each of the money laundering charges carry a maximum penalty of up to twenty years in prison.  The false subscription of a U.S. income tax return charge carries a three-year maximum penalty and a fine not greater than USD 100,000.  In its 14 December 2009 response to the pre-sentence report for Gerald Green, the government argued that his sentencing range should be life in prison.  On 12 August 2010, the Greens were each sentenced to six months in prison followed by six months of home confinement and were each ordered to pay USD 250,000 in restitution.  After serving their six month terms, they were released from federal custody in May 2011.  The government initially appealed the short sentences but then withdrew the appeal on 23 August 2011.  The government did win a forfeiture count, leaving the Greens indigent.  The Greens appealed the restitution order of USD 250,000 to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit,  and the Ninth Circuit affirmed the District Court ruling on 11 July 2013. On 19 January 2010, an indictment against former TAT governor Juthamas Siriwan and her daughter, Jittisopa Siriwan, was unsealed in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles.  The indictment charges the Siriwans with conspiracy to commit money laundering, transporting funds to promote unlawful activity (bribery of a foreign official), and aiding and abetting.  If convicted, they each face up to twenty years in prison.  Juthamas Siriwan also faces prosecution in Thailand. On 11 January 2013, prosecutors in the U.S. filed a supplemental brief asking that the charges against Siriwan and her daughter, Jittsopa Siriwan, remain open pending the unfreezing of extradition proceedings in Thailand.  The extradition process was put on hold while Thai authorities prepare their own case against the Siriwans.  In their court filing, U.S. prosecutors noted that they had received a diplomatic note on 14 December explaining that the Anti-Corruption Commission of Thailand was planning to file criminal charges against Juthamas Siriwan.

On 11 February 2009, KBR LLC pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA and to four counts of violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions.  Under the plea agreement, KBR LLC agreed to pay a USD 402 million criminal fine and to retain an independent compliance monitor for a three-year period.  The Company also agreed to cooperate with the DOJ in its ongoing investigations.  It appears that Halliburton, KBR LLC's former parent company, will in fact pay all or most of the USD 402 million fine on behalf of KBR LLC, due to an indemnification agreement signed at the time of KBR LLC's separation from Halliburton in January 2009.  Also on 11 February 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, KBR, Inc. and Halliburton consented to the entry of an order that (i) permanently enjoins KBR, Inc. from violating the anti-bribery and books and records provisions of the FCPA, and from aiding and abetting violations of the books and records and internal controls provisions; and (ii) permanently enjoins Halliburton from violating the books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  The two companies were also ordered to disgorge USD 177 million in ill-gotten profits.  An independent monitor was imposed on KBR, Inc. for a three-year period and Halliburton was required to retain an independent consultant to review its FCPA policies and procedures.  Halliburton and the KBR entities agreed to pay total penalties of USD 579 million to settle the DOJ and SEC enforcement actions.  Previously, on 3 September 2008, the DOJ filed criminal charges against KBR, Inc.'s former CEO, Albert "Jack" Stanley, for conspiring to violate the FCPA and conspiring to commit mail and wire fraud.  Stanley pleaded guilty to one count of each charge.  He faces a possible sentence of seven years in prison and payment of USD 10.8 million in restitution.  Stanley's sentencing was deferred until his cooperation with the DOJ in its ongoing investigation was complete.  He is currently awaiting sentencing.Also on 3 September 2008, the SEC charged Stanley with violations of the anti-bribery and books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA in connection with his role in the bribery scheme.  Without admitted or denying the SEC's allegations, Stanley consented to the entry of a civil injunction and agreed to cooperate in the SEC's ongoing investigation.   On 17 February 2009, two UK nationals, Jeffrey Tesler and Wojciech Chodan, were indicted by a federal grand jury in Houston, Texas in connection with their participation in the bribery scheme.  Tesler, a London lawyer, was allegedly one of the agents hired by the four-company joint venture to funnel bribes to high-ranking Nigerian government officials.  Chodan was a former executive and consultant of a KBR, Inc.'s UK subsidiary.  The indictment was unsealed on 5 March 2009 in connection with the U.S. government's extradition request and charged Tesler and Chodan with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and ten substantive counts.  On 25 March 2010, District Judge Caroline Tubbs decided at Westminster Magistrates' Court that Tesler be extradited to the United States to stand trial. He had argued that the extradition request should be denied because he would no longer be able to receive a fair trial in the United States.  Tesler appealed the decision, but on 20 January 2011, the UK High Court ruled that it could go forward.   Tesler was formally extradited on 10 March 2011.  On 11 March 2011, Tesler pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court in Houston to one count of conspiracy and one count of violating the FCPA. As part of his plea agreement, Tesler agreed to forfeit USD 148,964,568.  At his sentencing, he faces faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison on the conspiracy charge, and five years in prison on the FCPA violation charge. On 20 April 2010, Judge Tubbs ruled that Chodan be extradited to the U.S.  On 6 December 2010, following his extradition to the United States, Wojciech Chodan pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  At his sentencing, Chodan faces a maximum penalty of 60 months in prison.  As part of his plea agreement, he agreed to forfeit USD 726,885.On 23 October 2009, Halliburton disclosed in an SEC filing that the UK's Serious Fraud Office ("SFO") may bring civil claims or criminal charges against it under various UK laws.  According to Halliburton, the SFO is focused on the role of M.W. Kellogg Limited ("MWKL"), a UK subsidiary of KBR, in the TSKJ joint venture.  Halliburton also said it understood that the Bonny Island project is under investigation in France, Nigeria, and Switzerland as well, and could also result in third-party claims.The press reported that Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission ("EFCC") had arrested ten Halliburton employees in Nigeria during a raid of the offices of Halliburton Energy Services Nigeria Limited in Lagos on 25 November 2010.   The EFCC also arrested one employee each from Saipem Contracting Nigeria and Technip Offshore Nigeria.  On 7 December 2010, the EFCC reportedly filed corruption charges against Halliburton, former U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney (who was the CEO of Halliburton during the period at issue), Albert Stanley (former CEO of KBR), David Lesar (current CEO of Halliburton) and William Utt (current CEO of KBR).  Technip, Snamprogetti and JGC Corp. were reportedly also charged on the same day.  The case number is Federal Republic of Nigeria v. Halliburton and others, CV/435/10, High Court of Justice, Abuja Judicial Division (Abuja).On 21 December 2010, Halliburton reported that it reached a settlement with the Nigerian government, agreeing to pay a USD 32.5 million penalty and USD 2.5 million in legal expenses (the amount is significantly less than the supposed USD 120 million fine reported in the press previously).  Halliburton also agreed to assist the Nigerian government in recovering frozen assets in Switzerland.  In exchange, Nigeria agreed to withdraw all lawsuits and charges against KBR and Halliburton corporate entities and associated persons.  According to press reports, former U.S. President George H. W. Bush and former Secretary of State James Baker assisted with the settlement negotiations.  Former Vice President Dick Cheney had been charged by the Nigerian authorities as a former Halliburton executive.   On 20 December 2010, Saipem announced that Snamprogetti had entered into a settlement agreement and non-prosecution agreement with the Federal Government of Nigeria to resolve the investigation.  Snamprogetti agreed to the payment of a criminal penalty of USD 30 million, along with USD 2.5 million in reimbursement for legal costs and expenses incurred by the Nigerian authorities.  Nigeria agreed to dismiss all charges against Snamprogetti and to renounce to any civil claims and criminal charges in any jurisdiction.On 16 February 2011, following a High Court Order issued under Part 5 of the UK's Proceeds of Crime Act of 2002, the SFO announced a civil settlement in which MWKL will pay approximately GBP 7 million in recognition of funds MWKL was due to receive.  The SFO recognized that MWKL took no part in the criminal activity which generated the funds, but rather was used by its parent company, which participated in the joint venture and bribery scheme to bid for contracts on Bonny Island.  The agreement follows MWKL's self-reporting to the SFO in October 2009 and will lead to payment within fourteen (14) days in full and final settlement of the case.  The agreement also insures MWKL will pay the costs of the investigation, and MWKL will overhaul its internal audit and control measures to ensure its compliance systems are in accordance with UK law.  On 22 February 2012, Wojciech Chodan was sentenced to one year of unsupervised probation by the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas. Chodan was also fined USD 20,000.  He had pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges under the FCPA in December 2010, and could have received up to five years in prison.  Chodan's probation allows him to return to his residence in the UK.  The following day, on 23 February 2012, the judge in the case sentenced Jeffrey Tesler, a lawyer and consultant based in the UK who also pleaded guilty last year to violating the FCPA, to twenty-one months in prison, and two additional years of supervised probation.  Mr. Tesler had already agreed to forfeit approximately USD 150 million held in Swiss and Israeli bank accounts, at the time of the original plea agreement in March 2011 (this was the largest individual forfeiture to-date under the FCPA). In November 2012, a French court investigating Mr. Tesler's activity agreed to postpone a hearing in the case for one year, until 11 December 2013, after Tesler's scheduled release from jail in October 2013.Albert "Jack" Stanley, who pleaded guilty in 2008, was sentenced by Judge Keith B. Ellison to thirty months in prison, followed by three years of supervised probation, on 23 February 2012.  When he pleaded guilty in 2008, Stanley was ordered to pay USD 10.8 million in restitution for the kickbacks he admitted to having taken.  The judge in the case, Keith B. Ellison, agreed to allow Stanley to pay the USD 1.55 million remaining in USD 1,000 monthly installments following his release from prison.  Stanley is 69 years old in 2012. In its SEC Form 8-K filed on 19 July 2012, Halliburton announced that earlier in the month, on 9 July, the 165th Judicial District Court of Harris County, Texas had issued an order preliminarily approving the proposed settlement of a derivative suit filed against Halliburton by some of its shareholders.  The derivative action had been filed in 2009 against current and former Halliburton directors and officers for violations of the FCPA while KBR, Inc. was working as a government contractor in Iraq, illegal kickbacks, fraud in government contracts, and prohibited activity in Iran. The proposed settlement was signed by the parties in June.  In it, the Company expressly denies wrongdoing by it or the individual officers and directors named, and requires that the settlement not be construed as an admission by any of the defendants.  The settlement provides for mandatory FCPA and UK Bribery Act training, revisions to the Company's code of business conduct, clawbacks against the officers and directors, limitations on discretionary payments to officers and the payment of legal expenses, and ongoing review and modifications of the compliance program and code of business conduct.In its 10-K Form submitted to the SEC on 20 February 2013, KBR, Inc. reported that its independent compliance monitor has "certified that KBR's current anti-corruption compliance program is appropriately designed and implemented to ensure compliance with the FCPA and other applicable anti-corruption laws."On 20 May 2014, lawyer Jeffrey Tesler was disbarred by the UK Solicitors Regulation Authority.

On 30 July 2009 H&P; settled with the DOJ, entering into a two-year non-prosecution agreement and agreeing to pay a USD 1 million penalty.  On the same day, H&P; also agreed to the entry of a SEC cease-and-desist order, agreeing to pay USD 375,000 in disgorgement of profits, including pre-judgment interest.

On 10 December 2008, Hioki pleaded guilty to two felony counts: conspiracy to violate the Sherman Act and conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Hioki was sentenced to two years in jail and fined USD 80,000. Hioki was the ninth individual to plead guilty in the marine house bid-rigging investigation and the first individual to plead guilty in the FCPA conspiracy.  He agreed to cooperate in the DOJ's ongoing antitrust and FCPA investigations.

On 21 December 2000, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, IBM consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order and a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records provisions.  IBM was ordered to pay a USD 300,000 civil penalty.In July 1997, an Argentine appeals court overturned the bribery charges against BNA and IBM-Argentina employees, leaving only a lesser fraud charge in place.

On 11 February 2009, without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC complaint, ITT consented to the entry of final injunction permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions and ordering the company to pay disgorgement of USD 1,041,112, along with prejudgment interest of USD 387,538.11.  ITT also agreed to pay a USD 250,000 civil penalty.

On 31 July 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, NSP, Faggioli and Huff consented to the entry of final judgments enjoining each defendant from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions and certain other provisions of the federal securities laws.  NSP agreed to pay a civil penalty of USD 600,000.  Faggioli and Huff each agreed to pay a civil penalty of USD 25,000.

On September 3, 2009, Smith pleaded guilty to a two-count superseding information charging him with conspiracy to violate the FCPA and with corruptly obstructing and impeding the due administration of the internal revenue laws.  Smith's sentencing hearing was then postponed repeatedly.  On December 6, 2010, Judge Andrew Guilford of the Central District of California ordered Smith to pay a $7500 fine and a $200 special assessment, and sentenced him to six months in prison, followed by six months of home confinement and then three years of supervised released.  The DOJ had requested a 37-month prison sentence. Previously, on May 8, 2008, Self pleaded guilty to a two-count information charging him with violating the FCPA in connection with the same set of conduct.  On November 17, 2008, Self was sentenced to two years of probation.In April 2007, the UK-MOD official, Michael Hale, pleaded guilty in the UK to accepting over $300,000 in bribes and was sentenced to a two-year prison term.

On 2 June 2008, AGA entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement, admitting to violations of the FCPA and agreeing to pay a USD 2 million criminal penalty.  AGA also agreed to retain an independent compliance monitor for three years.

On 31 July 2009, CCI pleaded guilty to violations of the FCPA and the Travel Act. Under the plea agreement, CCI agreed to (i) pay a USD 18.2 million criminal fine; (ii) create, implement and maintain a comprehensive anti-bribery compliance program; (iii) retain an independent compliance monitor for a three-year period to review the design and implementation of the Company's anti-bribery compliance program and to make periodic reports to CCI and the DOJ; (iv) serve a three-year term of organizational probation; and (v) continue to cooperate with the DOJ in its ongoing investigation.On 2 February 2009, CCI's former Finance Director, Richard Morlok, pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA. He admitted that he had caused CCI employees to pay approximately USD 628,000 to employees of state-owned customers. He also admitted to providing false information to both internal and external auditors during a 2004 audit. On 9 January 2009, Mario Covino, CCI's former Director of Worldwide Factory Sales, pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA and providing false and misleading information to both internal and external auditors during a 2004 audit. Covino, an Italian citizen, admitted to causing CCI employees to pay over USD 1 million in bribes to employees of state-owned customers.  On 8 April 2009, six former CCI executives were indicted for violating the FCPA and the Travel Act. The individuals include: (i) Stuart Carson, former CCI CEO, charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act and two counts of violating the FCPA; (ii) Hong Carson (also known as Rose Carson), former director of sales for China and Taiwan, charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act, five counts of violating the FCPA and one count of destruction on records related to an investigation of the U.S. Department of Justice; (iii) Paul Cosgrove, former director of worldwide sales, charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act, six counts of violating the FCPA and one count of violating the Travel Act; (iv) David Edmonds, former vice president of worldwide customer service, charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act, two counts of violating the FCPA and two counts of violating the Travel Act; (v) Flavio Ricotti, former vice president and head of sales for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act, one count of violating the FCPA and three counts of violating the Travel Act; and (vi) Han Yong Kim, former president of CCI's Korean operations, charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act and two counts of violating the FCPA.  On 8 December 2009, the Court denied two motions filed by the six former CCI executives: (1) The first Order denied Defendant's Motion for Discovery of documents pertaining to the plea agreement between CCI and the DOJ, in an attempt to circumvent seeking to obtain discovery through CCI.  The Defendants argued that the DOJ had "constructive possession" of CCI's internal investigation materials and it should therefore be considered discoverable, citing to U.S. v. Stein.  In the Stein case â€“ in which KPMG, the defendant, entered into a plea agreement with the DOJ while the DOJ was still prosecuting the individuals involved â€“ the Court had allowed for the discovery of materials disclosed by KPMG under its plea agreement.  In the CCI matter, the Court denied this motion, distinguishing it from Stein on the grounds that, unlike KPMG's plea agreement, CCI's agreement contained "comprehensive privilege strictures."  The Court also found that, unlike the request in Stein, the CCI defendants' request was too broad, including requests for electronic databases and attorney work-product material. (2) The second Order denied the Defendants' Motion for Dismissal of Counts 9-11 of the indictment, claiming certain DOJ requests for foreign records were outside of the Statute of Limitations for the specific counts and that the tolling provision did not apply to the indictment as a whole.  The Court denied the second motion, finding that the tolling provision did apply, as the tolling statute provides that the starting point for tolling the limitations period is the official request for evidence, not the date the motion is made or granted. Additionally, the Court stated that the tolling applies to the entire grand jury investigation as a whole, and is not count-specific.  The Court also struck down later motions by the defendants to dismiss the Travel Act charges on the basis that the law, along with the California Penal Code, could not be used to prosecute commercial bribery committed abroad. Flavio Ricotti was arrested on 14 February 2010, in Frankfurt, Germany, and was extradited to the United States, arriving on 2 July 2010.  He pleaded guilty on 29 April 2011 to a one-count superseding information charging him with conspiring to make corrupt payments to foreign government officials, and officers and employees of private companies in several countries, including Saudi Arabia and Qatar, in violation of the FCPA and the Travel Act.On 5 March 2012, Cosgrove and Edmonds  and Hong Carson filed both a motion to suppress and a motion to dismiss the charges against them.  The motion to dismiss turned on three claims:  that the defendants were denied access to key defense documents due to the "partnership" between the government (through the DOJ) and CCI (through its attorneys), in that they coordinated between themselves, conveyed information about the defendants' willingness to cooperate and even waived the attorney-client privilege, and disclosed otherwise privileged documents; the defendants' inability to access foreign third-party records and witnesses, and; that the FCPA and Travel Acts lack clarity and can therefore not form the basis of a criminal conviction of the defendants.  Regarding this third claim, the defendants hint that the payments may not have been made to foreign officials within the meaning of the FCPA, because the government has not defined the term "instrumentality" and has not explicitly stated that a state-owned enterprise is in fact an instrumentality of a foreign government.  In conclusion, the defendants claimed that the cumulative effect of these deficiencies is to prejudice the process irreparably.The defendants' 5 March 2012 motion to suppress was based on the claim "that CCI and its counsel  were de facto public actors when they implicitly threatened to terminate Defendants' employment if they did not cooperate and participate in interviews with CCI's investigators."  In their brief on the motion, the defendants explain that they were compelled to take part in interviews by CCI's counsel at a time when CCI was collaborating closely with the DOJ.  Because CCI's representatives were acting with the government's knowledge and "with the government's general encouragement . . . CCI was an agent of the government during the interviews," and that "[b]ecause CCI was a state actor when it compelled the Defendants' statements, it violated their Fifth Amendment rights and the statements must be suppressed." On 14 May 2012, Judge David Selna of the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, Southern Division, issued a tentative order denying the motion to dismiss, stating that the cumulative effect of the shortcomings indicated by the defendants was insufficient to dismiss the claims against them.  On 17 May 2012, the judge also issued a tentative order denying  the motion to suppress, noting that "[c]ooperation with the Government does not convert the party into a state actor," and concluding that the defendants' Fifth Amendment rights had not been violated by the conduct of the investigation. On 17 April 2012, Stuart Carson and his wife Hong Rose Carson pleaded guilty to separate one-count superseding informations describing FCPA violations.  In a court filing on 12 October 2012, prosecutors acknowledged the truth in Hong "Rose" Carson's pleading, in which her attorneys claimed that she deserved a lighter sentence (than the three years' probation to which she could be sentenced), given her background (she was born and raised in China until age 26), noting, "The government cannot disagree that [the defendant]. . . lacked the American education and early business training of her co-defendants."  Prosecutors  recommended a sentence of three years' probation, possibly including six months of home confinement, plus a fine of USD 20,000 for Rose Carson.  On 9 November 2012, Rose Carson was sentenced to 6 months home confinement, and ordered to pay a fine of USD 20,000, and to perform 200 hours of community service.  Her husband, Stuart Carson, who could have been sentenced to ten months in prison, received a sentence of 4 months imprisonment and a fine of USD 200,000.On 24 May 2012, Paul Cosgrove requested a hearing in order to change his previous plea of not guilty to guilty, and on 29 May Cosgrove pleaded guilty to a one-count superseding information charging him with making a corrupt payment to a foreign government official in China in violation of the FCPA.  Cosgrove was sentenced in September 2012 to 13 months home confinement and fined USD 20,000 for bribing Chinese officials. On 15 June 2012, David Edmonds pleaded guilty to a one-count superseding information charging him with making a corrupt payment to a foreign government official in Greece in violation of the FCPA.  On 17 December 2012, Edmonds was sentenced to 4 months in prison followed by 4 months of home confinement.  The maximum sentence he might have received was 15 months in prison. On 1 February 2013, prosecutors recommended that Ricotti, Covino and Morlok be sentenced to probation and/or time served in recognition of their cooperation with the DOJ investigation into CCI.  Main Justice reported that, on 11 March 2013, Morlok and Covino were sentenced to three years of probation in addition to three months of home confinement, while Ricotti was sentenced on 18 March 2013 to time served. Charges are still pending against Han Yong Kim.

On 14 December 1999, without admitting or denying the allegations, Metcalf & Eddy entered into a consent agreement permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA.  Under the terms of the agreement, Metcalf & Eddy was required to pay USD 450,000 in fines and penalties and implement and maintain a compliance program designed to detect and prevent future FCPA violations.  In its first iteration of the necessary components of an effective compliance program, the DOJ required Metcalf & Eddy to include at a minimum: (i) a clearly articulated policy against FCPA violations and the creation of standards and procedures that are reasonably capable of reducing future violations; (ii) the assignment of one or more corporate officials responsible for oversight of the compliance program, including granting them the ability to monitor and audit systems and monitor the program as necessary; (iii) the establishment of a committee to review the hiring of third parties used to develop business outside of the United States, including determining the suitability of joint venture partners; (iv) corporate procedures to ensure that the company does not grant substantial discretionary authority to individuals whom the company knows are likely to engage in criminal activity; (v) corporate procedures to assure that the company has taken all necessary and prudent precautions to form business relationships with reputable agents, consultants and other representatives for business development purposes outside of the United States; (vi) communication of corporate FCPA policies, procedures and standards to all officers, employees, agents consultants and other representatives; (vii) appropriate disciplinary mechanisms, including discipline of individuals responsible for the failure to detect a violation of the compliance program; and (viii) a detailed representation in all third party contracts that the third party will not violate the FCPA or retain a sub-agent without the company's prior written consent, and a clause allowing for termination of the contract for violations of these representations. Metcalf & Eddy also agreed to implement financial and accounting procedures to ensure that the company maintains accurate books and records; to promptly investigate any alleged violations of the FCPA; to request certifications and representations from joint venture partners regarding compliance with the FCPA; to provide annual certifications regarding FCPA compliance for five years following the agreement to USAID or other government agencies with which it had overseas programs or contracts; to conduct periodic reviews of its corporate FCPA policies; and to provide each officer and manager a copy of the complaint, undertaking and order of permanent injunction.

On 28 February 2005, Micrus and its Swiss subsidiary, Micrus S.A., entered into a two-year deferred prosecution agreement with DOJ under which it agreed to pay USD 450,000 in penalties. In addition, Micrus agreed to the following: (i) to continue its cooperation with the DOJ's investigation; (ii) to affirmatively disclose to the DOJ any activities that it believes may violate the FCPA; (iii) not to contradict the statement of facts included in the agreement; (iv) to adopt an FCPA compliance program and internal controls in order to prevent future violations; and (v) to retain an independent compliance monitor for a three-year period.  The DOJ noted that a deferred prosecution agreement was appropriate in this case because Micrus voluntarily disclosed the conduct, took prompt disciplinary action against the officers and employees involved in the conduct, cooperated with the DOJ's investigation, and had no prior criminal history.

On 6 January 2005, Monsanto entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ for the payment to the official from the Ministry of the Environment.  Under the agreement, Monsanto agreed to pay USD 1 million in penalties, appoint an independent compliance monitor for a three-year period, and implement new anti-bribery policies and procedures.  On the same date, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Monsanto consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA.  The company agreed to pay a USD 500,000 civil penalty and retain an independent compliance monitor for a three-year period to settle claims with the SEC.  In entering into the settlement, the SEC noted Monsanto's voluntary disclosure and cooperation with the government, and the remedial actions the company was taking in response to the activity, including: (i) revision of the accounting treatment of the payments to Indonesian officials; (ii) the termination of all Monsanto employees involved in improper financial activities or who failed to oversee financial activities; (iii) termination of Monsanto's relationship with the consulting firm; (iv) restructuring of its Indonesian affiliates; (v) the appointment of a new Director of Business Conduct; and (vi) implementation of a stronger FCPA compliance program. On 6 March 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Charles Martin consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the FCPA.  Martin paid a USD 30,000 civil penalty.On 5 March 2008, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia dismissed with prejudice the charges against Monsanto, the company having fully complied with the terms of its deferred prosecution agreement.

On December 18, 2009, the District Court of Mustasaari found the former Senior Manager of Wartsila Finland not guilty of aggravated bribery. The court also dismissed the related demand for a corporate fine against Wartsila Finland.On September 22, 2010, the Vaasa Court of Appeals decided to refer the criminal case against the former Senior Manager back to the Ostrobothnia District Court.

CroatiaIn February 2010 the Croatian State Attorney's Office requested information about Patria from the Finnish authorities.  Also in 2010, the Croatian Chief State Prosecutor's Office and Finnish and Austrian prosecutors set up a joint team of investigators.FinlandIn November 2008, the Helsinki District Court ruled that Jorma Wiitakorpi, former CEO of the Patria Group, should be remanded in custody following his arrest by the National Bureau of Investigation ("NBI") on suspicion of corporate espionage and aggravated bribery.  The authorities also requested a remand for Veijo Varis , a member of the management team of Patria.  Wiitakorpi  denied any wrongdoing, and Patria's internal investigation found no indication of illegal action.  Wiitakorpi, however, had to leave Patria in August 2008, although he remained in the employ of Patria in an advisory capacity.  According to press reports, on 23 June 2010 the Finnish Prosecutor-General's office announced that it was charging four Patria executives, as well as one Egyptian citizen, with aggravated bribery and accounting fraud in connection with alleged bribes paid to Egyptian officials.  Charges were also brought against Patria.According to press reports, in June 2011, the Pirkanmaa District Court found the four current or former Patria employees guilty of a number of counts of accounting fraud and complicity in those offenses, sentencing them to suspended prison terms.  Both the prosecutor and defendants are appealing to the Court of Appeal.  The prosecutor reportedly argues that the men should have been convicted of aggravated bribery and sentenced to tougher terms.  Patria itself reportedly was not found guilty of any wrongdoing; however, the company is appealing against legal costs incurred.In a press release on 18 December 2012, the Finnish Office of the Prosecutor General announced that the Finnish Prosecution Service had brought charges of aggravated bribery and business espionage against the former CEOs of Patria Oyj and Patria Vehicles Oy, and four employees of the Patria Group in connection with the sale of Patria AMV armored vehicles to Slovenia in 2006.According to a Reuters report from 28 June 2013, Finnish prosecutors announced that they would charge three unnamed former Patria executives with bribery of Croatian officials. SloveniaSlovenia issued an indictment in the Patria case against the then and incumbent prime minister Janez Jansa and four other persons in 2011. Reuters reported on 5 June 2013 that Jansa has been sentenced to two years in prison and that two co-defendants pleaded guilty and received sentences of 22 months. The story says that Jansa is planning on appealing the decision against him.AustriaAccording to a Reuters story from 5 June 2013, an Austrian citizen has been convicted for corruption involving the Patria allegations.

U.S. EnforcementU.S. enforcement authorities began an investigation into the transactions and expanded the investigation in 2007.  In a letter to the Audit Committees counsel, dated 27 February 2009, the DOJ requested that the Audit Committee pursue all reasonable avenues of investigation prior to completing the internal investigation and issuing a final report, recognizing that this may lead to a delay in the completion of the report.  The DOJ also requested that the Audit Committee not release the final report without the approval of the DOJ, given the possible interference with the DOJ's own investigation.  In the 27 February 2009 letter, the DOJ also stated that the company's assistance to the DOJ would be taken into account when the DOJ establishes its position on this matter.  On 29 December 2011, Magyar Telekom and Deutsche Telekom AG agreed to pay a combined USD 95 million to settle civil and criminal charges to resolve Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) investigations into activities by Magyar Telekom and subsidiaries in Macedonia and Montenegro. The combined criminal penalty to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) was USD 63.9 million, while Magyar Telekom agreed to settle the Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) charges by paying more than USD 31.2 million in disgorgement and pre-judgment interest settlement.  The DOJ filed a criminal information against Magyar Telekom and a two-year deferred prosecution agreement in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. The SEC also sued three former Magyar executives. Also on 29 December 2011, the SEC filed a civil complaint against Elek Straub, Andras Balogh and Tamas Morvai, alleging that they had engaged in bribery schemes that resulted in the payment of  EUR 4.875 million, and EUR 7.35 million, part of which was paid as bribes to Macedonian and Montenegrin officials, respectively.In five claims including FCPA bribery offenses, books and records offenses, false accounting, internal controls and false statements, the SEC complaint requests injunctive relief, disgorgement and civil penalties.On 29 October 2012, the defendants jointly filed a motion to dismiss the complaint.  The grounds for the requested dismissal were (1) lack of personal jurisdiction; (2) barred by the statute of limitations; (3) failure to adequately state a bribery offense or other claim upon which relief may be granted.  In a 5 December 2012  memorandum in opposition to the defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint, the SEC claims that the defendants are subject to personal jurisdiction because their conduct caused foreseeable consequences in the United States; that the statute of limitations only begins to run when the defendants enter the United States, which they have yet to do, and; the complaint identifies specific acts which fall within the purview of the claimed violations.  Responding to this memorandum, the defendants claim that the SEC ignored key documents that undermined its arguments, including the fact that the annual filing for 2005 was not filed by the company, but instead postponed, and a disclosure informed investors that the company would release the results when the internal investigation was complete.  On 8 February 2013, Judge Richard J. Sullivan of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York denied the defendants' motion to dismiss in its entirety. Regarding the lack of personal jurisdiction claim, Judge Sullivan found that the SEC had established that Magyar Telekom's alleged bribes and concealment, even if occurring outside of the United States, were allegedly directed at the United States and thus were sufficient to meet the "minimum contacts" standard for personal jurisdiction in a U.S. district court. Judge Sullivan also found that the SEC sufficiently established the second part of the personal jurisdiction standard, which is that the court's exercise of jurisdiction over the defendants would not be unreasonable. Regarding the claim that the SEC's action was time barred, Judge Sullivan found in the plain language of the relevant statute that the five-year statute of limitations only begins when a defendant is "found within the United States." Over five years passed between the alleged conduct and the filing of the action, but the defendants were never "found within the United States" during this period. Therefore, the statute of limitations had not run. Finally, Judge Sullivan also rejected the defendants' three-tiered argument that the SEC's action failed to state a claim by not providing sufficient facts to support the allegations. Judge Sullivan found that the SEC provided sufficient facts to support 1) its claim that the defendants had made "use of the mails or any other means or instrumentality of interstate commerce corruptly in furtherance of" the alleged bribes; 2) its claim that the intended recipients of the alleged bribes were "foreign officials" under the FCPA; and 3) its claim regarding the alleged fraudulent behavior of each defendant in reference to the Exchange Act's rule on materially false or misleading statements in SEC filings and audits. The judge therefore denied the motion to dismiss in its entirety and ordered a status conference for April 2013.On 26 February 2013, the Wall Street Journal reported that these defendants have requested permission from Judge Sullivan to file an interlocutory appeal of his decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. On 10 March 2014, the SEC announced that it was dropping allegations that former executives of the Hungarian unit of Deutsche Telekom (Mr. Straub,  Mr. Balogh and Mr. Morval) bribed officials in Montenegro.  The remaining allegations that the executives bribed government officials in Macedonia to block competition against Magyar are still pending. (According to Magyar Telekom's Second Half 2010 Results, the company faced ongoing investigations by the Macedonian, Montenegrin, Hungarian and U.S. governments.  The company cooperated with each government investigation.  At that time, the company stated that it had  incurred HUF 2.3 billion in expenses related to the investigation in 2010.) Montenegro EnforcementThe Supreme State Prosecutor of the Republic of Montenegro is investigating Cmogorski Telekom, the company's Montenegrin subsidiary, in connection with the contracts at issue in the internal investigation.  Hungary EnforcementThe Hungarian Central Investigating Chief Prosecutor's Office has commenced a criminal investigation into "alleged corruption with the intention of violating obligations in international relations and other alleged criminal offenses." The Hungarian National Bureau of Investigation ("NBI") is investigating "alleged misappropriation of funds relating to payments made in connection with the Company's ongoing internal investigation and the possible misuse of personal data of employees in the context of the internal investigation."Macedonia EnforcementThe Ministry of Interior of the Republic of Macedonia issued requests to Magyar Telekom's Macedonian subsidiaries for information and documents related to certain procurement and dividend payment activities.  Based on a 10 December 2008 press release on the Macedonian Ministry of Interior website, it appears that the Ministry's Organized Crime Department submitted files to the Basic Public Prosecution Office of Organized Crime and Corruption in Macedonia, proposing that criminal charges be brought against four individuals, including three former Magyar Telekom Group employees.  These individuals are alleged to have committed an act of abuse of office and authorizations while employed at Makedonski Telekom (a Magyar Telekom subsidiary in Macedonia) in connection with five consulting contracts with a company called Chaptex Holdings Ltd. during 2005-2006.  Germany EnforcementAccording to press reports on 3 September 2010, Deutsche Telekom's offices were raided by German authorities in connection with an investigation by the Bonn Public Prosecutor's Office into the alleged misconduct in Macedonia and Montenegro.  German authorities began an investigation into whether Deutsche Telekom and its CEO, Rene Obermann, had any involvement in the matter.  According to press reports on 3 January 2011, prosecutors dropped their bribery investigation of Mr. Obermann and two others suspects, but were still investigating five others.

On 20 December 2007, Akzo Nobel entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ. Under the agreement, N.V. Organon was expected, within 180 days, to reach a resolution with the Dutch National Public Prosecutors Office for Financial, Economic and Environmental Offences regarding the conduct, wherein it would pay a criminal fine of approximately EUR 381,000 in the Netherlands.  Should N.V. Organon have failed to reach a timely resolution with the Dutch Public Prosecutor, the agreement required Akzo Nobel to pay a fine of USD 800,000 to the U.S. Treasury.  In fact, N.V. Organon reached a settlement with the Dutch Public Prosecutor in July 2008, under which the company was ordered to pay a EUR 381,602 "transaction fee."Under the non-prosecution agreement, Akzo Nobel also agreed to cooperate with the DOJ's ongoing Oil for Food investigations.   The DOJ agreed not to file criminal charges against Akzo Nobel or its subsidiaries in recognition of N.V. Organon's anticipated resolution with the Dutch Public Prosecutor and Akzo Nobel's disclosure of the improper payments to the DOJ following the publication of the final report of the Independent Inquiry Committee into the U.N. Oil-for-Food Program.Also on 20 December 2007, Akzo Nobel settled books and records and internal controls charges with the SEC.  Under the agreement, Akzo Nobel agreed to pay USD 750,000 in civil penalties, USD 1,647,363 in disgorgement of profits and USD 584,150 in pre-judgment interest.

On 30 August 1978, Katy, Carroll and Jacobs, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, each agreed to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions, as well as various federal securities laws.   Katy's Board of Directors was also required to establish a Special Committee of three outside directors to oversee an investigation into the allegations in the complaint and the company's Indonesian activities and to make remedial recommendations.  The findings of the Special Committee's investigation were to be presented to the Board and the SEC within 90 days.  Within 30 days of the filing of the report, the Board was to consider and act on the Special Committee's recommendations.

On 1 September 1999, IMS pleaded guilty to conspiracy and violating the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  IMS was sentenced to a one-year probationary term and ordered to pay a USD 1,000 fine and a USD 400 assessment fee.  On 1 September 1999, Qualey pleaded guilty to conspiracy and violating the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  He was sentenced to 3 years of probation, 150 hours of community service and 4 months of home confinement.  He was ordered to pay a USD 5,000 fine and USD 100 assessment fee.  The judgment was satisfied on 2 March 2002.

On 6 December 2004, InVision entered into a two-year non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ under which InVision accepted responsibility for the misconduct, agreed to pay a USD 800,000 criminal fine and continue to cooperate with the DOJ and SEC's investigations.  At the same time, GE entered into a one-year agreement with the DOJ governing GE's obligations with respect to its InVision business.  GE agreed to integrate InVision into GE's FCPA compliance program, to retain an independent consultant to evaluate GE's efficacy in that effort, to accept the terms of InVision's non-prosecution agreement and cause InVision performance of the agreement, and to cooperate with the DOJ and SEC's ongoing investigations.  On 14 February 2006, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, InVision agreed to the entry of a cease-and-desist order finding that the company violated the anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  InVision agreed to pay disgorgement of USD 589,000 plus prejudgment interest of USD 28,703.57 and to retain in independent consultant to evaluate the efficacy of GE's integration of InVision into its compliance program.  On the same day, the SEC also filed a settled civil action under which InVision agreed to pay a USD 500,000 civil penalty.  On 15 August 2006, the SEC filed a settled civil action against David Pillor alleging that he aided and abetted InVision's internal controls violations and that he indirectly caused the falsification of InVision's books and records.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Pillor consented to pay a USD 65,000 civil penalty and to the entry of a permanent civil injunction against future violations.

On 25 September 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Chandramowli Srinivasan consented to the entry of final judgment enjoining him from violating the anti-bribery and books and records provisions of the Exchange Act of 1934 and ordering him to pay a USD 70,000 civil penalty.  On the same date, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, EDS, ATKI's parent company at the time of the conduct, consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order related to ATKI's violations of the issuer reporting and books and records provisions of the Exchange Act of 1934.  EDS was ordered to pay a total of USD 490,902 in civil penalties, including USD 358,800 in disgorgement and USD 132,102 in prejudgment interest.

On 7 April 2009, Latin Node pleaded guilty to a one-count criminal information as part of a plea agreement with the government.  Under the agreement, Latin Node agreed to pay a USD 2,000,000 criminal fine, a USD 400 special assessment and agreed to continue its cooperation with the government.  The DOJ noted that the USD 2,000,000 statutory maximum fine was appropriate in this case, rather than calculating the fine under the Alternative Fines Act, because of the impossibility of calculating the profits or losses under the contracts since eLandia had terminated them upon discovering the illegal payments.  The DOJ also noted eLandia's extraordinary cooperation with the investigation, including its prompt voluntary disclosure to the government and its significant remedial efforts.  In particular, the government noted that eLandia terminated those Latin Node employees who were responsible for the conduct and strengthened its own anti-bribery compliance program even though no eLandia employees were involved in the conduct.  The government also cited Latin Node's acceptance of responsibility for its conduct and the fact that Latin Node only existed as a shell company for purposes of entering into a plea agreement with the government.  On 20 December 2010, Jorge Granados, Latin Node's former chief executive officer, and Manuel Caceres, the former vice president of business development, were arrested and indicted for allegedly paying more than USD 500,000 in bribes to government officials in Honduras.  The 19-count indictment, which was initially returned by a federal grand jury in Miami on 14 December 2010 and was unsealed on 20 December 2010, charged the two men with criminal violations of the FCPA and international money laundering.   Caceres pleaded guilty on 18 May 2011 and Granados pleaded guilty on 19 May 2011.  On 7 September 2011, Granados was sentenced to 46 months in prison, to be followed by two years of supervised release.On 19 April 2012, Caceres was sentenced to 23 months in prison; he is scheduled to begin serving his sentence in a Florida prison in July 2012.On 17 December 2010, Manuel Salvoch, Latin Node's former chief financial officer, and Juan Pablo Vasquez, the chief commercial officer, were charged in a sealed criminal information with conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Salvoch was arrested on 11 January 2011 and pleaded guilty on 12 January 2011.  He faces up to five years in prison and fine of USD 250,000 or more, and three years of supervised released.  Salvoch is serving as a cooperating witness for the DOJ.  Vasquez pleaded guilty on 21 January 2011.Salvoch was sentenced to 10 months of prison on 8 June 2012, to be followed by three years of supervised release.  Vazquez  received three years of probation.In Honduras, the country's Supreme Court on 22 January 2013 acquitted Marcelo Chimirri, former managing director of Hondutel, of all charges of bribery, fraud and abuse of authority.   Several other Hondutel employees are still on trial there.

On April 27, 2009, Perez pleaded guilty to conspiring to commit FCPA violations and money laundering for his role in the payment of bribes to former officials of Haiti Teleco.  On January 21, 2011 Perez was sentenced to 24 months in prison, followed by two years of supervised release, and to forfeit $36,375.  He had faced a maximum of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of $250,000 or twice the gross gain. On May 15, 2009, Diaz pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and money laundering.  He admitted to receiving more than $1 million in bribe money from the telecommunication companies and then laundering the money for a former Haitian official.  On July 30, 2010, Diaz was sentenced to 57 months in prison, to be followed by three years of supervised release.  He was also ordered to pay $73,824 in restitution and to forfeit $1,028,851.  Antoine was extradited from Haiti to the U.S. on December 12, 2009 and held in Miami on $1 million bail.  On March 12, 2010, Antoine pleaded guilty to a money laundering conspiracy count.  He agreed to a forfeiture order of $1,580,771.  On June 2, 2010, Antoine was sentenced to 48 months in prison, to be followed by three years of supervised release.  In addition to the agreed forfeiture amount, he was also ordered to pay $1,852,209 in restitution.  After cooperating with the government and testifying as a witness in two of the Haiti Teleco cases, Antoine's four year sentence was reduced to 18 months, on 29 May 2012, when he had already served 16 months of the original sentence.On February 19, 2010, Fourcand pleaded guilty to laundering money used to bribe former Haiti Teleco officials.  On May 5, 2010, he was sentenced to six months in prison.  As part of his guilty plea, he also agreed to forfeit $18,500.  An order was entered on 3 May 2012 granting Fourcand's motion for a reduction in sentence, requiring Fourcand to serve 2 months in prison, followed by a period of supervised release.  A fine of $100 was levied.On July 20, 2011, Duperval, Grandison and Joseph entered pleas of not guilty in response to the July 13 superseding indictment. On August 4, 2011, a federal jury convicted Joel Esquenazi and Carlos Rodriguez, former executives of Terra Telecommunications Corp., on all counts for their roles in a scheme to bribe Haiti Teleco officials.  They were each convicted of one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and commit wire fraud, seven counts of FCPA violations, one count of money laundering conspiracy, and 12 counts of money laundering. The verdict was reached after five hours of jury deliberations, following a two-and-a-half-week trial.  On October 25, 2011, Esquenazi was sentenced to 15 years in prison and Rodriguez was sentenced to 84 months in prison.On 9 May 2012, both Esquenazi and Rodriguez appealed their guilty verdicts to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals, challenging "whether the District Court erred as a matter of law in its jury instruction regarding what constitutes an â€œinstrumentalityâ€ù of a foreign government for purposes of construing the counts, including the money laundering counts, that were dependent upon the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (â€œFCPAâ€ù)" (Rodriguez), and "Whether the appellant] is entitled to an acquittal because employees of Haiti Teleco were not 'foreign officials' within the meaning of [the] FCPA simply because the National Bank of Haiti owned shares of Haiti Teleco and the Haitian government appoint board members and directors." (Esquenazi).  On 8 February 2012, Patrick Joseph, former director general of Haiti Teleco, changed his initial not- guilty plea to guilty, entering an agreement with the Department of Justice in the hopes of a reduced sentence in exchange for cooperation with the government.  Joseph was sentenced on 6 July 2012 to one year and one day imprisonment to begin on 6 August 2012, plus a fine of USD 100, and one year of supervised release following release from prison, based on one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering.   On 24 February 2012,  U.S. District Court Judge Jose Martinez granted the DOJ's motion to dismiss the case as against Cinergy, on the grounds that the government had determined the company to be "a non-operational entity that exists only on paper for the benefit of two fugitive defendants, Washington Vasconez Cruz and Cecilia Zurita." Jean Rene Duperval, former head of international relations at Haiti Teleco, was convicted on 12 March 2012 on all counts of conspiracy and money laundering for which he was tried.  This included two counts of conspiracy to commit money laundering, and 19 counts of money laundering.  The DOJ statement announcing the conviction noted, â€œTo conceal the payment and receipt of bribes, Duperval participated in a money laundering scheme to funnel about half a million dollars to two shell companies under his control...This verdict confirms that American taxpayers will not tolerate bribery, either at home or abroad,  to obtain unfair business advantages.â€ù  Duperval testified in his own defense at trial, claiming that the payments were "tokens of appreciation," not bribes.  Judge Martinez found Duperval guilty of perjury on the witness stand, and sentenced him 9 years in prison on 21 May 2012.  Duperval was also required to forfeit USD 497,331.On 16 May 2014, the 11th Circuit affirmed the DOJ's expansive view of a "foreign official" under the FCPA, upholding Joel Esquenazi and Carlos Rodriguez's convictions, and keeping intact the longest prison sentence ever imposed in an FCPA case.  A unanimous three-judge panel defined "instrumentality" as "an entity controlled by the government of a foreign country that performs a function the controlling government treats as its own."  On 14 August 2014, Mr. Esquenazi and Mr. Rodriguez petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court to review their convictions on FCPA-related charges and to determine whether "an entity controlled by the government of a foreign country that performs a function the controlling government treats as its ownâ€ù (1) fails to satisfy the constitutional requirement of adequate notice of what specific conduct violates the FCPA, and (2) is erroneously derived from commentary to an unrelated treaty [the OECD anti-bribery convention] that postdates the FCPAâ€™s enactment."The DOJ's investigation and proceedings against other companies and individuals involved in the scheme is ongoing.

On 27 September 2007, without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's complaint, Immucor and De Chirico consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order.  On 28 September 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, De Chirico consented to the entry of a final judgment ordering him to pay a civil penalty of USD 30,000.  The final judgment was entered on 2 October 2007.

On 21 December 2007, Lucent entered into a two-year non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ relating to its violations of the anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  Under the agreement, Lucent admitted to the conduct and agreed to a USD 1 million fine.  Lucent also committed to adopting new  or modifying existing  internal controls, policies and procedures related to FCPA and anti-bribery compliance.  On 21 December 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Lucent consented to the entry of a final judgment enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions and ordering Lucent to pay a civil penalty of USD 1.5 million.

On 7 February 2007, El Paso entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York under which El Paso was to forfeit USD 5,482,363 to the U.S. government, which would then seek to transfer the forfeited funds to the Development Fund of Iraq (established on 21 May 2003, by United Nations Security Council Resolution 1483) to be paid as restitution for the benefit of the people of Iraq.Also on 7 February 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, El Paso consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order.  El Paso was ordered to pay USD 5,482,363 in disgorgement of profits and a civil penalty of USD 2,250,000. The disgorgement obligation was to be satisfied by forfeiting USD 5,482,363 pursuant to the company's non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

On the basis of the IIC reports the Prosecutor for Serious Economic Crime initiated an investigation of the Danish companies, against which IIC claimed to have evidence.Subsequently the Prosecutor for Serious Economic Crime brought action towards 17 Danish companies. In the fall of 2006, the Ministry of Justice decided that the action against the companies should be dropped as the cases had become statute-barred. Instead the investigation continued with the purpose of confiscating the companies proceeds in relation to the Oil-for-Food Program.  In May 2009, Novo Nordisk A/S reached a settlement with U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") and U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") resolving their investigations of the companys sales to Iraq during 2001-2003 under the Oil for Food Program. Under the term of the settlements, Novo Nordisk was to pay a fine, disgorgement of past profits and interest of a total of approximately USD 18 million. Consequently, when learning of the Novo Nordisk settlement with DOJ and SEC, the Danish Prosecutor for Serious Economic Crime resumed the cases filed and Novo Nordisk A/S has, together with the 7 other companies listed above, made similar settlements with the Prosecutor for Serious Economic Crime to pay a disgorgement of past profits totaling DKK 45 million.The remaining 6 companies have not agreed on a settlement and these cases will be settled by the Danish courts.

The Public Prosecutor for Serious Economic Crime initially filed charges of bribery (under s. 122 of the Danish Penal Code (straffeloven)) and receipt of an unlawful commission (kickback) against Missionpharma.On 30 January 2009, the bribery-related charge against the company was dropped, leaving only the kickback charge.  The investigation is ongoing and presumably the case will not be settled for another 1-3 years.
The investigation is ongoing.

News agencies reported that on August 25, 2008, the TDPPO charged PCI, Taga, Sakashita, Takasu and Sakano with violation of the Unfair Competition Prevention Law of Japan ("UCPLJ").On January 29, 2009, the Tokyo District Court reportedly found:(1) PCI guilty and fined it JPY 70,000,000 (approx. US$780,500);(2) Sakashita guilty and sentenced him to two years in prison with a three-year suspended sentence;(3) Takasu guilty and sentenced him to one year and eight months in prison with a three-year suspended sentence; and(4) Sakano guilty and sentenced him to one year and six months in prison with a three-year suspended sentence.On March 24, 2009, the Tokyo District Court reportedly found Taga guilty and sentenced him two years and six months in prison with a three-year suspended sentence for violation of the UCPLJ and an unrelated fraud case.On October 18, 2010, the Vietnamese official at issue was sentenced to life in prison for accepting the bribe.

News agencies reported that on 16 March 2007, the FSDPPO charged Y1 and Y2 with violation of the Unfair Competition Prevention Law of Japan ("UCPLJ").On 17 March 2007, the Fukuoka Summary Court reportedly found:(1) Y1 guilty and fined him JPY 500,000 (USD 4,500); and(2) Y2 guilty and fined him JPY 200,000 (USD 1,800).In this case, KNIT's organizational involvement was reportedly not established and KNIT itself was not charged with any crime.

News agencies reported that the TRTB's position was that the payments to RS as brokerage commissions were not allowable expenses.  The TRTB reportedly made a reassessment and subsequent collection order against the nine NFA members.

On 15 September 2011, Bridgestone agreed to plead guilty to a two-count criminal information charging the company with conspiracy to violate the Sherman Antitrust Act and conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Bridgstone agreed to pay a USD 28 million fine.   The plea agreement acknowledges the company's internal investigation, its ongoing cooperation with the DOJ and its extensive remediation efforts. Previously, in December 2008, Misao Hioki pleaded guilty in U.S. court to two felony counts: conspiracy to violate the Sherman Act and conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Hioki was sentenced to two years in jail and fined USD 80,000. [See TRACE Compendium entry titled Hioki.]In the related antitrust matter, on 28 January 2008, the European Commission imposed a total fine of EUR 58,500,000 (USD 87,750,000) on Bridgestone and its British subsidiary, Bridgestone Industrial, Ltd.  On February 22, 2008, the Japan Fair Trade Commission issued a cease-and-desist order against Bridgestone and other entrepreneurs and imposed a surcharge of JPY 2,380,000 (USD 19,420) against Bridgestone. It is unclear whether Japan's Public Prosecutor Office may still bring bribery charges against the company.
The investigation is ongoing.  The Investigating Magistrate (Judge d'Instruction) reportedly is waiting for an assistance requested to Bolivia.
The investigation is ongoing.  The Investigating Magistrate (Judge d'Instruction), Judge Sergio Torres, has requested assistance from Switzerland and the Philippines.

On September 5, 2008, Nam Nguyen, Joseph Lukas, Kim Nguyen, and An Nguyen were arrested on charges that they violated the FCPA.  They, along with Nexus, were indicted on September 4, 2008 by a grand jury on one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and four substantive counts of violating the FCPA.  On October 29, 2009, the DOJ filed a superseding indictment charging one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA, nine substantive FCPA violations, nine violations of the Travel Act, nine counts of money laundering in furtherance of a crime, aiding and abetting, and a forfeiture provision. Nexus was the first company ever to be indicted for FCPA violations. On June 29, 2009, Joseph Lukas pleaded guilty to the charges and agreed to cooperate with the DOJ.  On September 16, 2010, he was sentenced to two years of probation and ordered to pay a $1,000 fineOn March 16, 2010, Nexus and three employees entered guilty pleas in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia.  Nexus pleaded guilty to conspiracy, violations of the FCPA and violations of the Travel Act violations n connection with commercial bribes and money laundering.  Nam Nguyen and An Nguyen each pleaded guilty to conspiracy, a substantive FCPA violation, a violation of the Travel Act and money laundering.  Kim Nguyen pleaded guilty to conspiracy, a substantive FCPA violation and money laundering.In connection with the guilty pleas, Nexus and the individual defendants admitted that, from 1999 to 2008, they knowingly paid over $250,000 in bribes to Vietnamese officials in order to obtain contracts with the agencies and companies for which the bribe recipients worked, and that the bribes were falsely described as "commissions" in the Nexus's records. Nexus, in pleading guilty, also acknowledged that it operated primarily through criminal means and the company agreed cease operations as a condition of the guilty plea.On September 16, 2010, Nam Nguyen was sentenced to 16 months in prison and ordered to serve two years of supervised release following the prison term. On the same day, An Nguyen (Nam Nguyen's brother) was sentenced to nine months in prison, to be followed by three years of supervised release. Kim Nguyen (sister to Nam and An Nguyen) was sentenced to two years of probation and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine.

On March 20, 2006, Novak pleaded guilty to FCPA and mail and wire fraud charges and was sentenced to three years of probation and three hundred hours of community service.  Novaks co-conspirators pleaded guilty to mail and wire fraud charges and received the following sentences: (i) Steven Karl Randock, Sr. was sentenced to 36 months in prison, three years of court supervision and forfeiture of $500,000 in cash, real property and a 2001 Jaguar XK8; (ii) Dixie Ellen Randock was sentenced to 36 months in prison and three years of court supervision; (iii) Heidi Kae Lorhan was sentenced to 12 months and one day in prison and two years of court supervision; and (iv) Roberta Markishtum was sentenced to four months in prison and one year of court supervision.  Blake Alan Carlson, Kenneth Wade Pearson and Amy Leann Hensley do not appear to have been sentenced yet.

On April 8, 1980, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Page Airways consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from further violations of the reporting and proxy provisions of the Exchange Act.  Under the terms of the settlement, Page Airways agreed to conduct an internal investigation into the matters alleged in the SEC's complaint and to retain a Review Person to evaluate the investigations methods and procedures.  The company also agreed to file a current report on Form 8-K concerning the internal investigation.The charges against the individual defendants were dismissed.  The SEC stated that, in reaching settlement of enforcement action, both the agency and Page Airways took into consideration concerns raised by another U.S. agency regarding certain matters of national interest.

On September 21, 2007, Paradigm entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ.  Under the terms of the agreement, the DOJ agreed not to prosecute Paradigm if the company satisfied its obligations under the agreement for an 18-month period.  Paradigm's obligations included paying a $1 million penalty, implementing rigorous internal controls, retaining outside compliance counsel, and continuing its cooperation with the DOJ.

On 21 February 2008, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Flowserve consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Flowserve was ordered to disgorge USD 2,720,861 in profits, plus USD 853,364 in pre-judgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of USD 3 million.  On the same day, Flowserve entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ in connection with a criminal information filed against Flowserve Pompes, charging the subsidiary with conspiracy to commit wire fraud and to violate the FCPA's books and records provisions.  Flowserve accepted responsibility for the actions of its subsidiary and agreed to a USD 4 million criminal fine.  According to the SEC, Flowserve B.V. was to enter into a criminal disposition with the Dutch Public Prosecutor pursuant to which it will pay a fine.
