Oil States consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order by the SEC without admitting or denying the SEC's findings.  Oil States did not receive a monetary penalty, but was enjoined from committing future violations  of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.

On 1 October 2007, York and the DOJ entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement under which York accepted responsibility for the conduct of YACR and FZE and agreed to pay a USD 10 million criminal penalty.  Under the agreement, York agreed to have its compliance program reviewed by an independent compliance monitor for three years and to cooperate fully with the DOJ's ongoing investigation into the U.N. Oil for Food Program.On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, York consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  York was ordered to disgorge USD 8,949,132 in profits, plus USD 1,083,748 in pre-judgment interest.  The company also agreed to pay a civil penalty of USD 2,000,000 and to retain an independent compliance monitor.Johnson Controls was not prosecuted in connection with the facts admitted by York.

IraqChevron resolved these violations by entering into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the New York Country District Attorney's Office.  Chevron also entered into a separate agreement with the Office of Foreign Assets Control of the U.S. Department of the Treasury ("OFAC") and reached a settlement with the SEC.On 14 November 2007, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Chevron consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Chevron was ordered to disgorge USD 25,000,000 in profits and to pay a civil penalty of USD 3,000,000.  Chevron will satisfy its disgorgement obligation by forfeiting USD 20,000,000 pursuant to its non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and paying USD 5,000,000 in disgorgement the New York Country District Attorney's Office pursuant to the agreement.  Chevron will also pay a USD 2,000,000 civil penalty to OFAC.The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was to transfer the USD 20,000,000 forfeited by Chevron to the Development Fund of Iraq (established on 21 May 2003, by United Nations Security Council Resolution 1483) as restitution to the people of Iraq.

On May 11, 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Novo Nordisk consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Novo Nordisk was ordered to disgorge $4,321,523 in profits plus $1,683,556 in pre-judgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of $3,025,066.Novo Nordisk also entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a $9 million criminal fine.

On 30 September 2009, AGCO entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, under which ACGO acknowledged responsibility for the conduct of its subsidiaries and agreed to pay a USD 1.6 million criminal fine.  On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, AGCO consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  AGCO was ordered to disgorge USD 13,907,393 in profits plus USD 2,000,000 in pre-judgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of USD 2,400,000.The DOJ reported that, also on the same day, AGCO settled an ongoing investigation by the Danish State Prosecutor for Serious Economic Crime in connection with two Oil for Food contracts executed by AGCO Danmark A/S.  AGCO agreed to disgorge USD 630,000 of profits in connection with these charges.

On 22 December 2008, Fiat entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, acknowledging responsibility for the actions of its three subsidiaries and agreeing to pay a USD 7,000,000 criminal fine.  On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Fiat consented to the entry of a permanent injunction enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Fiat was ordered to disgorge USD 5,309,632 in profits plus USD 1,899,510 in pre-judgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of USD 3,600,000.  On 5 March 2012, the government filed an unopposed motion to dismiss the criminal information against Iveco, CNH Italy and CNH France, on the grounds that the terms of the Deferred Prosecution Agreement had been satisfied.

On 31 October 2007, Ingersoll-Rand entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a criminal fine of USD 2.5 million.  Ingersoll-Rand also agreed to engage an outside consultant to complete a thorough review of the companys compliance program with respect to the FCPA and other applicable anti-corruption laws.On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Ingersoll-Rand consented to the entry of a final judgment enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Ingersoll-Rand was ordered to disgorge USD 1,710,034 in profits, plus USD 560,953 in pre-judgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of USD 1,950,000.  The company was also ordered to comply with certain undertakings regarding its FCPA compliance program.   On 31 October 2010, Ingersoll-Rand's deferred prosecution agreement expired.  On 16 February 2011, the DOJ filed a motion to dismiss the Oil-for-Food charges against the company, noting that the company had fully cooperated with the investigation and had met its obligations regarding improving its FCPA compliance policies and procedures.

On 6 June 2004, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Schering-Plough consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order enjoining Schering-Plough from committing future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Schering-Plough also agreed to appoint an independent consultant and to pay a USD 500,000 civil penalty.

On August 23, 2007, Textron entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ under which Textron agreed to pay a $1.5 million criminal fine.  According to the DOJ, it agreed not to file criminal charges against the company or its subsidiaries due to Textron's early discovery and reporting of the improper payments; its thorough review of those payments as well as its discovery and review of improper payments made in other countries; and its implementation of enhanced compliance policies and procedures.On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Textron consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Textron was ordered to disgorge $2,284,579 in profits, plus $450,461.68 in pre-judgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of $800,000.  The company also agreed to comply with certain undertakings with regard to its FCPA compliance program.

On March 20, 2008, Volvo entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, accepting responsibility for the conduct of its two subsidiaries and agreeing to pay a $7,000,000 criminal fine.  On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Volvo consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Volvo was ordered to disgorge $7,299,208 in profits plus $1,303,441 in prejudgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of $4,000,000.In 2007, Swedenâ€™s National Anti-Corruption Unit (Riksenheten mot corruption), launched an investigation of three Volvo executives for transgressions in the Oil-for-Food program, and in March 2009 charged the three with bribery.  On 3 April 2012, two of the former executives, who worked for Volvo Construction Equipment International AB, were found guilty by the Eskilstuna District Court (Sweden) of offering 24 million kroner (USD 3.6 million) in kickbacks to Iraqi officials in order to secure contracts for the sale of construction vehicles.  Rune Lundberg and Hakan Nirstedt received suspended sentences, and were fined USD 18,000 and USD 9,000 respectively.  The prosecutor declined to demand a corporate fine because of Volvoâ€™s payment of the USD 19.6 fine to the U.S. authorities in the 2008 FCPA settlement.

A criminal indictment was filed against Naaman on 7 August 2008.  He was arrested in Frankfurt, Germany on 30 July 2009 and later extradited to the U.S.On 3 May 2010, he initially pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to commit wire fraud and to violate the FCPA in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C.On 25 June 2010, Naaman pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia to a two-count superseding information charging him with one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud, violate the FCPA and falsify the books and records of a U.S. issuer; and one count of violating the FCPA.  On 5 August 2010, Naaman and Innospec's former business director of its TEL group, David Turner, settled civil charges with the SEC. Naaman and Turner consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from violating securities laws. In addition, Naaman agreed to disgorge USD 810,076 and pay pre-judgment interest of USD 67,030. He also agreed to a USD 438,038 civil penalty, which will be offset by any criminal fines he receives. Turner agreed to disgorge USD 40,000 to the SEC. On 22 December 2011, Naaman was sentenced to 30 months in prison and ordered to pay a USD 250,000 fine for his participation in a conspiracy to defraud the United Nations Oil for Food Program (OFFP) and in bribing former Iraqi government officials.  He received his sentence in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.  So far, Namaan is the only individual to be prosecuted in the United States for Innospec's bribery[Please see a separate Compendium entry titled "Innospec" for information regarding the company's settlement with enforcement authorities in the U.S. and United Kingdom.]

On March 11, 1999, Tannenbaum pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the FCPA.  He was ordered to pay a $15,000 criminal fine and sentenced to a one-year prison term, to be followed by three years of supervisory release.

On November 20, 1980, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Tesoro consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of Sections 13(a) and 14(a) of the Exchange Act.  Tesoro undertook to appoint a new director, satisfactory to the SEC, who would also serve as chairman of the audit committee of the companys Board of Directors.  Tesoro also committed itself to not making payments, or offers of payment, directly or indirectly, to any foreign official or foreign political party or leader thereof for purposes of influencing or inducing such officials to affect a foreign government act or decision, per the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  The company also undertook to keep accurate books and records and to file with the SEC a current Form 8-K.

On September 13, 2002, Pitchford pleaded guilty to three counts: (i) conspiracy to commit theft from a government program and to bribe a foreign official in violation of the FCPA; (ii) theft from a government program; and (iii) bribery in violation of the FCPA.  On November 22, 2002, Pitchford was sentenced to a prison term of twelve months and one day, to be followed by three years of supervised release.  Pitchford was ordered to pay $400,000 in restitution to the U.S. government.  The DOJ had submitted a motion arguing for a four-level downward departure from the Federal Sentencing Guidelines in recognition of Pitchford's substantial assistance and commitment to cooperate with the DOJ's ongoing investigations.Also on September 13, 2002, Dickey pleaded guilty to one count of government program fraud, one count of wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to commit fraud.  On November 22, 2002, Dickey was sentenced to an 18-month prison term, to be followed by three years of supervised release.  He was ordered to pay $300,000 in restitution to the U.S. government.  Both men were also ordered to serve 200 hours of community service.Pitchford and Dickey were held jointly and severally liable for $300,000 in restitution owed to the U.S. government.   Proceeds from the sale of a yacht and cash obtained from a brokerage account, both seized by the FBI during the course of its investigation, will be applied toward the restitution.

Flowserve BV, Solvochem Holland BV, OPW Fluid Transfer Group Europe BV, Prodetra BV, NV Organon, Alfasan International BV and Stet Holland BV all reached out-of-court settlements with the Dutch Ministry of Justice, according to a Ministry press release on 15 July 2008.  Without admitting guilt, the companies were ordered to pay the following transaction-fees: Flowserve BV: EUR 256,534Solvochem Holland BV: EUR 280,592OPW Fluid Transfer Group Europe BV: EUR 81,804Prodetra BV: EUR 99,236.95NV Organon: EUR 381.602Alfasan International BV: EUR 41,983.55Stet Holland BV: EUR 174,170The Chief Executive Officer of Saybolt International Group BV received a four-month home detention sentence by a U.S. court and was ordered to pay a USD 20,000 penalty.  The Chairman of the Board was accused in U.S. court, but could be not extradited because of Dutch law.  He will likely not be prosecuted in the Netherlands.Trafigura beheer BV is currently under investigation in the United States and will likely not be prosecuted in the Netherlands.

In 2006, Mr. Wi was sentenced to imprisonment for four years and fined KRW 2,000,000 for bribing a foreign official in violation of the Foreign Bribery Prevention Law and bid interference in violation of the Criminal Code.Mr. Park was sentenced to imprisonment for eight months and fined KRW 2,000,000 for bribing a foreign official in violation of the Foreign Bribery Prevention Law and bid interference in violation of the Criminal Code.Mr. Kim fled and has been put on the wanted list.South Korean government notified the U.S. government of Mr. Choi's crime.  As a result, he was placed on the unattached list.

On April 16, 2006, Tyco, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's books and records provisions and various other federal securities laws.  Tyco was also ordered to pay $1 in disgorgement and a $50 million civil penalty. In related cases, the SEC and Department of Justice charged former Tyco executives Dennis Kozlowski, Mark Swartz and Mark Belnick with the failure to disclose millions of dollars of favorable loans from Tyco, undisclosed related-party transactions and fraudulent stock trading.  A jury convicted Kozlowski, former chief executive officer and chairman of the company, on 22 counts of grand larceny, conspiracy and securities fraud and he was sentenced to 8 to 25 years in prison.  Former chief financial officer, Mark Swartz, was also convicted to 8 to 25 years in prison for securities fraud, grand larceny and conspiracy.  Mark Belnick, Tycos former general counsel, was acquitted of the charges.

On 20 May 2005, DePu pleaded guilty to violations of the FCPA.  Under the terms of the plea agreement, DePu was required to pay a USD 2 million criminal penalty.  On the same day, DPC, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  DPC was required to pay USD 2,038,727 in disgorgement of profits, along with USD 749,895 in pre-judgment interest, for a total of USD 2,788,622.  The DOJ and SEC also required DPC to appoint an independent compliance consultant to audit the company's compliance program and monitor its implementation of new policies and procedures.

On 3 June 2008, Faro entered into a two-year non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ and agreed to pay a USD 1.1 million criminal penalty.  On 5 June 2008, Faro consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order and agreed to pay USD 1.85 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.Faro also agreed to retain an independent corporate monitor (or independent consultant, as described by the SEC) for a two-year period to review and evaluate Faro's internal controls, recordkeeping and financial reporting policies and procedures in the context of FCPA compliance.  At the time of settlement, Faro estimated that the total cost associated with its monitoring obligation would be in the range of USD 1 million to USD 2 million.On 28 August 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Oscar H. Meza consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the FCPA and from aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA.  Meza agreed to pay a USD 30,000 civil penalty, as well as USD 26,707 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.

On 22 July 1992, GE pleaded guilty to violations of the FCPA's books and records provisions, as well as conspiracy to defraud the United States, submitting false claims, and engaging in monetary transactions involving criminally-derived property.  Under its plea agreement, GE agreed to pay USD 9.5 million in criminal penalties.  Separately, GE settled a civil False Claims Act suit, agreeing to pay USD 59.5 million in civil fines. Although initially indicted on numerous other counts, Steindler pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit offenses against the United States, wire fraud, money laundering, and use of the mail in aid of racketeering.  On 18 November 1994, Steindler ordered to forfeit USD 1,741,453 and was sentenced to a seven-year prison term.Klein pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and money laundering.  On 14 January 1994, he was sentenced to prison for eighteen months, to be followed by two years of supervised release.Dotan was prosecuted and convicted in Israel for his role in the diversion schemes, receiving a 13-year prison sentence.

David Uri was found guilty of aggravated professional money laundering, forgery and support of criminal organization. He was fined but escaped a jail sentence because he cooperated fully with the investigation and was judged to have shown sincere contrition.  He nevertheless lost USD 1 million in profits he made from the scheme.  In 2004, Swiss banking regulators publicly reprimanded UBS for failing to conduct proper checks in the case.In December 2004, the son of the late General Abacha was arrested in Germany while allegedly attempting to close an account of which he was the sole holder and was facing extradition in Switzerland in connection with looted funds stashed away in the country's bank.  Abba Abacha was arrested when German authorities were alerted by the Deutsche Bank Branch in Essen.  The account which Abba allegedly attempted to close is said to be containing part of the USD 700 million frozen by the Swiss authorities in 1999, after Nigeria asked for assistance in investigating the financial network allegedly set up by the former head of state.  Funds embezzled by the Abacha clan include several million Deutsche marks paid in bribes by the Ferrostaal steel group in connection with the building of an aluminum factory in Nigeria.  In November 2009, a magistrate in Geneva found Abba Abacha guilty of participation in a criminal organization, sentenced him to a suspended prison term and ordered confiscation of USD 350 million in funds held in Luxembourg and the Bahamas. In the course of their investigation into Ferrostaal's former parent company, engineering group MAN, Munich prosecutors obtained certain key documents related to potential bribery by Ferrostaal in connection with the sale of eight oceangoing tugs to a Hamburg shipping company.  This prompted a raid on Ferrostaal offices in Essen in July 2009.According to press reports, Munich prosecutors commenced proceedings (case number 565 Js 33037/10) against Ferrostaal in late March 2010 and are relying on extensive testimony by two witnesses. On 11 April 2011, it was reported that two former Ferrostaal managers were charged by Munich prosecutors in connection with EUR 62 million (USD 89.7 million) in alleged bribes paid between 2000 and 2007 to receive contracts to supply submarines to Greece and Portugal. According to press reports on 14 October 2011, these proceedings are ongoing. On 14 October 2011, it was reported that Ferrostaal shareholders had approved paying a EUR 149 million fine to settle the Greek submarine bribery case, although no formal agreement has yet been reached with prosecutors.The Greek and Argentine investigations are ongoing.

On March 1, 2005, Titan pleaded guilty to one count of falsifying its books and records, one count of violating the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA and one count of aiding or assisting with filing false tax returns.   Titan was required to pay a $13 million criminal fine and serve three years of probation for each count.  As a condition of probation, the company was required to implement a robust compliance program designed to detect and deter future violations of the FCPA. On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Titan consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  In addition, Titan was required to pay a total of $15,479,195.47, including $12,620,000 in disgorgement and $2,859,195.47 in pre-judgment interest.

Norwegian EnforcementThe Norwegian National Authority for Investigation and Prosecution of Economic and Environmental Crimes ("Okokrim") seized documents from Statoil's offices and, on 29 June 2004, imposed approximately USD 3 million in penalties under Norway's Trading in Influence statute. Okokrim also charged the executive responsible for international business development and imposed a USD 30,000 penalty.  Statoil and the senior executives paid the penalties without admitting or denying the conduct. In October 2004, Statoil accepted a NOK 20,000,000 criminal fine issued by Okokrim's District Attorneys Office for violating the anti-bribery provisions of the Norwegian Criminal Act article 276(c).U.S. EnforcementThe SEC began its investigation on 23 September 2003.  On 13 October 2006, without admitting or denying the charges, Statoil consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA and requiring the company to disgorge USD 10.5 million and appoint an independent compliance consultant.  The SEC noted Statoil's extensive cooperation with their investigation, including providing documents that were protected by the attorney-client privilege and its  implementation of a robust remedial program. Statoil entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ on the same date, under which the company agreed to an additional USD 10.5 million criminal penalty and appoint an independent compliance consultant.  USD 3 million of the criminal penalty was deemed satisfied by the penalty paid to the Okokrim.  In its press release, the DOJ highlighted that the FCPA applies to foreign issuers and emphasized its commitment to prosecute international businesses over which it has jurisdiction. On 18 November 2009, upon motion by the DOJ, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed with prejudice the charges against Statoil, finding that the company had fully complied with all of its obligations under its deferred prosecution agreement, including the obligation to adopt the compliance-related recommendations of the compliance consultant.

CEI, Crawford, Hall, Garcia, Eyster, Smith, Beltran, Gonzalez, McLean, and Uriarte were charged with conspiracy and multiple counts of the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  CEI pleaded no contest, was found guilty and was ordered to pay a fine in the amount of USD 3,460,000.Crawford, the President and owner of CEI, pleaded no contest, was found guilty and was fined USD 309,999.  Hall, the Executive Vice President of CEI, pleaded no contest, was found guilty and was ordered to pay a fine in the amount of USD 150,000.  Garcia, who assisted Grupo Delta, CEI and Crawford in communicating with Pemex officials, pleaded no contest, was found guilty and was fined USD 75,000.  Eyster and Smith, the president and vice president of Ruston respectively, pleaded no contest, were found guilty and were each ordered to pay a fine in the amount of USD 5,000.  Beltran, the President and majority shareholder of Grupo Delta, and Gonzalez, who assisted Grupo Delta, CEI and Crawford in communicating with Pemex officials, appear to be fugitives.  The substantive charges against McLean, Vice President of Solar, and Uriarte, Regional Manager of Solar, were dismissed.  The court stated that under the FCPA an employee may not be convicted of a criminal offense for acts committed for the benefit of the employer unless the employer is also convicted.  [This provision, known as the Eckhardt Amendment, was removed by the 1988 Trade Act.]   McLean's and Uriarte's employer, International Harvester, pleaded guilty to conspiracy violation of the FCPA, but not to a substantive violation of the FCPA.  The company paid a USD 10,000 fine and USD 40,000 of prosecution costs.  McLean was acquitted of conspiracy.  Uriarte pleaded guilty and was sentenced to one year, suspended and placed on unsupervised probation. McLean filed suit to have his name expunged from the court records.  The court refused this request.  He later filed suit against International Harvester claiming that his civil rights had been violated and that the company had made him a scapegoat.  All charges were dismissed.  The appeals court ordered International Harvester to pay McLean's legal expenses. In 1982 Solar entered into a plea agreement, agreed to pay civil reimbursements of USD 40,000 and was fined USD 10,000.Ruston pleaded guilty to one count of a FCPA bribery violation and was fined USD 750,000.  Cemco pleaded guilty to one count of a FCPA bribery violation and was fined in the amount of USD 20,000.  Miller pleaded guilty to one bribery count and was placed on probation for three years and ordered to perform 500 hours of community service.King, the Executive Vice President and member of the Board of Directors of Cemco, entered into a cooperation agreement and was charged with violations of the Currency and Foreign Transactions Reporting Act.  He was placed on probation for 14 months and paid a civil reimbursement for prosecution costs in the amount of USD 5,000.In 1981, the DOJ entered into a cooperation agreement with Applied. Under the agreement, Applied pleaded guilty to bribing a foreign official, a felony violation of the FCPA.  The company consented to a permanent injunction prohibiting future violations and was ordered to pay a fine in the amount of USD 5,000.  In 1983, the DOJ entered into a cooperation agreement with Bateman, who pleaded guilty to misdemeanor violations of the Currency and Foreign Transactions Reporting Act and consented to a permanent injunction prohibiting future violations.  He was sentenced to probation for three years.  He received a civil penalty in the amount of USD 229,512.  Bateman was ordered to pay a civil tax payment to the Internal Revenue Service in the amount of USD 300,000.  He also paid USD 5,000 for costs related to his prosecution.
UNC/Lear pleaded guilty to mail fraud, false statement, and FCPA books and records violations and agreed to pay a $75,000 fine, $768,000 in restitution and $132,000 in civil penalties.

On 27 January 1995, the Lockheed Corporation pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Lockheed was assessed penalties of USD 24.8 million, double the amount of the profits (USD 12.4 million) earned by virtue of the illicit conduct and the maximum amount allowed by law.  The fine was comprised of a USD 21.8 million criminal fine and a USD 3 million civil penalty.  In January 1995, Love pleaded guilty to lying to investigators and was ordered to pay a USD 20,000 fine.Nassar, who is a Syrian citizen living in Switzerland, initially agreed to appear in court in June 1994 and the DOJ agreed not to seek his arrest and extradition from Europe.   Nassar fled to Syria, however, which has no extradition treaty with the U.S.  The DOJ proceeded to block the transfer of proceeds from Nassar's sale of two condominiums in Washington, DC and to freeze his worldwide assets.   In September 1994, the Syrian police arrested Nassar pursuant to an Interpol warrant and the Syrian government announced that it would try him in Syrian court for FCPA violations under the doctrine of extraterritoriality.  In July 1995, Nassar arranged to leave Syria and voluntarily enter U.S. custody.  In September 1995, Nassar pleaded guilty to two counts of violating the FCPA and was sentenced to an 18-month prison term.  The four months he served in a Syrian prison were to be deducted from his U.S. sentence.  Nassar was also ordered to pay a USD 125,000 criminal fine, to be paid from his frozen funds before they were released.  Nassar was the first person ever imprisoned for violating the FCPA.
On August 4, 2006, Salam pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA.  He was sentenced to three years in prison on February 5, 2007.

The FBI arrested Mr. Shu on September 24, 2008 and he pleaded guilty on November 17, 2008 to two counts of violating the Arms Export Control Act and one count of violating the FCPA.  On April 7, 2009, Mr. Shu was sentenced to 51 months in prison.  He was also required to forfeit USD $386,740.

On February 8, 2008, Wabtec entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ, under which Wabtec agreed to comply with the terms of the agreement for a three-year term and pay a $300,000 criminal fine.  The terms of the agreement prohibit Wabtec from committing additional crimes, require Wabtec cooperate fully with any investigation brought by the government and disclose all criminal conduct or any criminal investigations of Wabtec or its senior management.  In addition, Wabtec was required to take certain steps to enhance its FCPA compliance policies and procedures. On February 14, 2008, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Wabtec consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  In addition, Wabtec was required to disgorge $259,000 in profits, pay $29,351 in pre-judgment interest and pay a $87,000 civil penalty.  The SEC also required Wabtec to appoint an independent consultant to review and make recommendations concerning its compliance program.

On August 13, 1981, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Wallace Company and Rodriguez consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining them from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery and books and records provisions and other federal securities laws.  On February 23, 1983, the Wallace Company pleaded guilty to violations of the anti-bribery and books and records provisions of the FCPA and was ordered to pay a $530,000 criminal fine.On April 19, 1983, Alfonso Rodriguez pleaded guilty to bribery of a foreign official in violation of the FCPA and was sentenced to two years of probation and a fine of $10,000.O'Halloran left Trinidad & Tobago before he could be prosecuted, and died in Canada in 1985.  Subsequently (in 1991), the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, the Trinidad and Tobago Airways Corporation (â€œBWIA International), the Trinidad-Tesoro Petroleum Company Ltd., and the Trinidad and Tobago Racing Authority obtained a civil judgment of USD 7.2 million against the estate of O'Halloran, and worked under the StAR to recover the judgment from O'Halloran's estate in Canada.  The government of Trinidad and Tobago also brought a civil RICO  in US District Court for the Southern District of New York against Tesoro Petroleum Corporation and its officials (Case no. 1:89-cv-01663-LLS), and obtained a settlement of $7.5 million from the company.

On 14 May 2008, Willbros and WII entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, under which Willbros was required to pay a USD 22 million criminal penalty.  The criminal information contained six counts, including one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA, two counts of substantive FCPA violations and three counts of falsifying books and records related to corrupt payments.  In addition to the criminal penalty, Willbros was required to appoint an independent corporate monitor.  On the same day, Willbros, Steph, Jansen, Biggers and Galvez, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of, in various combinations, the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions and other federal securities laws.  Willbros agreed to pay USD 8.9 million in disgorgement and USD 1.4 million in pre-judgment interest.  Jansen was required to pay a USD 30,000 civil penalty and Galvez was required to pay a USD 35,000 civil penalty.  On 14 September 2006, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Jim Bob Brown consented to the entry of final judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  Upon a motion by the SEC, the court was to determine at a later date whether or not to assess a civil penalty against Brown.  Also on 14 September 2006, Brown pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the FCPA.  On 28 January 2010, he was sentenced to 12 months and one day in prison, two years of supervised release and ordered to pay a fine of USD 1,000 a month while on supervised release.  Brown cooperated with the DOJ's ongoing investigations, which was acknowledged by the court at his sentencing hearing.On 5 November 2007, Jason Steph pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the FCPA.  On January 28, 2010, he was sentenced to 15 months in prison, two years of supervised release and ordered to pay a USD 2,000 fine.  Steph cooperated with the DOJ's ongoing investigations, which was acknowledged by the court at his sentencing hearing.A grand jury indicated Paul Novak and James Tillery on charges of conspiring to violate the FCPA as well as substantive violations of the FCPA.  Novak was arrested on 19 December 2008 when he returned to the United States from South Africa after his passport had been revoked.  On 12 November 2009, Novak pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy and one substantive count of violating the FCPA. On 3 May 2013, the DOJ announced that Novak has been sentenced to 15 months in prison and is required to pay a USD 1 million fine. James Tillery remains a fugitive. Following expiration of the period of monitorship stipulated in the DPA, the Company's attorneys filed a motion to dismiss the criminal charges stemming from the documented conduct in Nigeria and South America prior to 2006.  On 2 April 2012, the U.S. District Court in Houston signed an order of dismissal of all charges, with prejudice.

On June 22, 2001 Rothrock pleaded guilty to one count of knowingly and willfully falsifying and causing to be falsified, certain books, records, and accounts of his former employer, Allied Products Corporation, in violation of the FCPA's books and records provisions.  On September 26, 2001, he was sentenced to one year of unsupervised probation and ordered to pay a special assessment of $100.

The SFO investigation, which commenced on the receipt of a report from AMEC, determined that no criminal proceedings should be commenced against AMEC or any of its associated companies.  The SFO concluded that AMEC had failed to keep accurate records as required by law and this was a matter that could be dealt with by way of civil restitution as opposed to the use of criminal law.In October 2009, in a Consent Order agreed before the High Court of Justice of England and Wales, AMEC agreed to a settlement payment of GBP 4,943,648 plus costs incurred as a result of the Civil Recovery Proceedings.Following detection of the irregularities, AMEC has worked to improve its ethics, compliance and accounting standards.  As part of the settlement, AMEC agreed to appoint an independent consultant to review these improvements and to report the findings to the SFO.The SFO acknowledged that, upon completion of the internal investigation, AMEC acted promptly and responsibly in referring the case, and cooperated with the SFO's investigation.

United KingdomOn 6 January 2009, the FSA issued a Final Notice and imposed a penalty of GBP 5.25 million on Aon Limited.  The FSA investigation was settled at an early stage, allowing for a 30% discount.  But for Aon Limited's cooperation and prompt settlement, the financial penalty that would have been imposed by the FSA would have been GBP 7.5 million.  The FSA recognized that Aon Limited's senior management had taken steps to mitigate the seriousness of its failings.  Aon Limited had promptly reported the matter to SOCA and the FSA after discovering two groups of potentially improper payments.  On discovery of the third case Aon Limited had established a dedicated steering committee which reported directly to its Board and this committee had overall responsibility for reviewing both the inappropriate payments and the systems and controls related to intermediaries.  Aon Limited had instructed a leading firm of accountants to review its systems and controls in place to control the payments to intermediaries.  Aon Limited implemented the short recommendations made by the external accountants.  Aon Limited also retained its law firms to carry out detailed investigations of potentially inappropriate payments and, where appropriate, had taken responsive action including termination or other disciplinary action against staff.  Aon Limited, in conjunction with Aon Corporation, designed and implemented a global anti-corruption program described by the FSA as a "model of best practices that other firms may wish to adopt."  Contained within that program was a general prohibition on the use of intermediaries whose only service was to obtain and retain business solely through client introduction in countries where the risk of corrupt practices was anything other than low.  Both Aon Limited and Aon Corporation have implemented robust risk based procedures to review all its existing and proposed relationships with intermediaries.  Further, both Aon Limited and Aon Corporation have taken significant actions to ensure a clear anti-corruption compliance culture within the business.  Top-down management-led initiatives designed to ensure a significant change in the culture of the organization globally have been implemented.  Both Aon Limited and Aon Corporation have also strengthened their processes and controls in relation to the use of intermediaries, and implemented other elements of a best practices compliance program, including customized enhanced training.United StatesIn 2011, AON entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ and agreed to pay a USD 1.76 million penalty to resolve violations of the FCPA (see below).  Aon also reached a settlement with the SEC and agreed to pay approximately USD 14.5 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest. Aon Corporation described the now concluded investigation by the DOJ and SEC as follows in its SEC Form 10-K filed on 25 February 2011: "Following inquiries from regulators, the Company commenced an internal review of its compliance with certain U.S. and non-U.S. anti-corruption laws, including the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act ('FCPA'). In January 2009, Aon Limited, Aon's principal U.K. brokerage subsidiary, entered into a settlement agreement with the Financial Services Authority ('FSA') to pay a Â£5.25 million fine arising from its failure to exercise reasonable care to establish and maintain effective systems and controls to counter the risks of bribery arising from the use of overseas firms and individuals who helped it win business. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC') and the U.S. Department of Justice ('DOJ') continue to investigate these matters. Aon is fully cooperating with these investigations and has agreed with the U.S. agencies to toll any applicable statute of limitations pending completion of the investigations. Based on current information, the Company is unable to predict at this time when the SEC and DOJ matters will be concluded, or what regulatory or other outcomes may result."U.S. Enforcement Result for Costa RicaOn 20 December 2011, Aon Corporation entered into a Non Prosecution Agreement ("NPA") with the DOJ, settling all claims regarding the company's conduct in Costa Rica.  The DOJ noted that it "enters into this Non-Prosecution Agreement based, in part, on the following factors: (a) Aon's extraordinary cooperation with the Department and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC"); (b) Aon's timely and complete disclosure of the facts described in Appendix A as well as facts relating to Aon's improper payments in Bangladesh, Bulgaria, Egypt, Indonesia, Myanmar, Panama, the United Arab Emirates, and Vietnam that it discovered during its thorough investigation of its global operations; (c) the early and extensive remedial efforts undertaken by Aon, including the substantial improvements the company has made to its anti-corruption compliance procedures; (d) the prior financial penalty of Â£5.25 million paid to the United Kingdom's Financial Services Authority ("FSA") by Aon Limited, a U.K. subsidiary of Aon, in 2009, covering the conduct in Bangladesh, Bulgaria, Indonesia, Myanmar, the United Arab Emirates, and Vietnam; and (c) the FSA's close and continuous supervisory oversight over Aon Limited."The NPA stipulates that Aon pay a "substantially reduced" fine of USD 1,764,000, based on the DOJ's intention "to credit meaningfully Aon for its extraordinary cooperation with the Department, including its thorough investigation of its global operations and complete disclosure of facts to the Department, and its early and extensive remediation," taking into account also the prior assessment of a larger fine by the FSA in the UK for conduct in countries other than Costa Rica.  The duration of the NPA is two years.

The matter concluded on 6 October 2008 with a Consent Order being made in the High Court of England and Wales.  The Order was the first Civil Recovery Order made under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002.  Such Orders have only been available since April 2008. Balfour Beatty agreed to a payment of GBP 2.25 million together with a contribution towards the cost of the Civil Recovery Order proceedings.  The company also agreed to continue to review and improve its compliance function and to engage in an agreed external monitoring programme.
Mr. Williamson was acquitted.

The convictions in this case, in September 2008, were the first convictions achieved by the newly formed specialist squad at the City of London Police.  Niels Tobiasen pleaded guilty and was given a jail sentence of five months suspended for a year. Ananias Tumukunbe who had been a Private Secretary in the Ugandan Government's Science and Technology Department, pleaded guilty and was jailed for a year.  He has since been deported to Uganda.  Tumukunbe appears to still be serving as an adviser to the Ugandan President.   Rusoke Togaswire, the Ugandan military officer, is still wanted by the City of London Police.

On 22 February 2008, Shinder Singh Gangar and Alan White were convicted and both men received seven and a half years imprisonment in total.  They were sentenced to six years for conspiracy to defraud and eighteen months for conspiracy to corrupt.  The sentences were to be served consecutively.  In addition, they were disqualified from being directors for twelve years. Nigel Heath pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit corruption and on 17 October 2008 was sentenced to six months imprisonment.  He had previously been struck off as a solicitor by the Law Society in 2007 as a result of his acting as a middle-man in relation to high yield investment products.
At the time of writing (November 2009) the individuals involved had been charged but the trial has not yet taken place.

On 25 September 2009, Mabey & Johnson received the following sentence: (i) for bribes paid for work in Ghana, the company was fined GBP 750,000 and (ii) for bribes paid for work in Jamaica, the company was fined GBP 750,000; for breach of the UN sanctions in Iraq, the company was fined GBP 2 million.Under the Confiscation Order in relation to money received under contracts secured by illegal payments, the company was ordered to pay GBP 1.1 million.Mabey & Johnson was also ordered to pay the following amounts as reparations: (i) GBP 658,000 to Ghana; (ii) GBP 139,000 to Jamaica; and (iii) GBP 618,000 to Iraq. The company was ordered to pay GBP 350,000 in SFO costs.As part of the agreement reached with the SFO, Mabey & Johnson agreed to strengthen its compliance code and work with a compliance monitor.  The company was expected to spend up to GBP 250,000 in first year monitoring costs.The total financial penalties were approximately GBP 6.5 million.On 10 February 2011, two former directors of Mabey & Johnson - Richard Charles Edward Forsyth (former Managing Director) and David Mabey (former Sales Director) - were found guilty by a jury in Southwark Crown Court of making illegal payments to Iraq during 2001 and 2002 in breach of United Nations sanctions. Another defendant, Richard Gledhill who was Sales Manager for contracts in Iraq, pleaded guilty to sanctions offences at an earlier hearing and gave evidence for the Prosecution.On 23 February 2011, Richard Charles Edward Forsyth was sentenced to 21 months imprisonment, disqualified from acting as a company director for five years and was ordered to pay prosecution costs of GBP 75,000.  David Mabey was sentenced to eight months imprisonment, disqualified from acting as a company director for two years and was ordered to pay prosecution costs of GBP 125,000.  Richard Gledhill was sentenced to eight months imprisonment, suspended for two years.

The corporation pleaded guilty to one count of violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions, agreed to a permanent civil injunction, and was fined $150,000.In a related civil case, Hughes, Richardson, Noble and Sherman agreed to the entry of permanent injunctions prohibiting them from future violations of the FCPA.

On 12 June 2003, Williams pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracty to defraud the Internal Revenue Service ("IRS") and one count of tax evasion.  He was sentenced to 46 months imprisonment and 3 years of supervised release.  He was also ordered to pay a USD 25,000 fine and USD 3.512 million in restitution to the IRS.  On 6 August 2010, Giffen pleaded guilty to one count of failing to disclose information on his income tax return. According to the DOJ Press Release, Giffen's personal income tax return for 1996 did not report his interest in and signing authority over a bank account in Switzerland held by Condor Capital Management, a company under his control. On the same day, Mercator pleaded guilty to one count of violating the FCPA and faces either a USD 2 million fine or a fine of up to twice the gross gain or loss resulting from the conduct. In a sentencing hearing on 19 November 2010, Giffen faced up to one year in prison and a USD 25,000 fine.  At the hearing, Giffen received no jail time or probation.  The judge appeared to agree with Giffen's assertions that his actions were sanctioned by the CIA, referring to Giffen as a "patriot."  Mercator was ordered to pay a USD 32,000 fine.

The books and records, bribery and conspiracy trial against the two individual and one corporate defendant began on 4 March 1991, and was dismissed on 18 March by the judge without any presentation of a defense.  The judge ruled that there was insufficient evidence for any jury to convict the defendants on any of the five charges.

In December 1979, ISC, Kenneally and Frietsch, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, consented to the entry of a final order enjoining future violations of the federal securities laws.   ISC was required to appoint a special agent to oversee the company books and records and overseas business activities.

On 2 October 1991, without admitting or denying the allegations in the DOJ's complaint, Eagle consented to the entry of a permanent injunction prohibiting future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions.Previously, in 1990, Morton pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  He was sentenced to three years probation.The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas found that, based upon the language of the statute and its legislative history, Castle and Lowry could not be prosecuted under the general conspiracy statute for conspiring to violate the FCPA.  The Court stated that the facts of the case supported Congress's decision to forego prosecution of foreign officials since foreign nations could and should prosecute their own officials for accepting bribes.  The Court continued saying that prosecution and punishment should be accomplished by the government which most directly suffered the abuses perpetrated by its own officials and that there was no need to contravene Congress desire to avoid such prosecutions by the United States.  The indictment against Castle and Lowry was dismissed.Blondek and Tull were acquitted at trial.

On December 10, 2002, Syncor Taiwan pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA and agreed to pay a $2 million criminal fine. On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Syncor consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  Syncor also consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order.  The SEC also imposed a $500,000 civil penalty.  In a related action, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Monty Fu consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining him from violating the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  He also agreed to pay a $75,000 civil penalty.

UNITED STATESOn 22 December 2014, Alstom agreed to pay a USD $772,290,000 fine to resolve charges related to a widespread scheme involving tens of millions of dollars in bribes in countries around the world, including Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the Bahamas.Alstom pleaded guilty to a two-count criminal information filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut, charging the company with violating the FCPA by falsifying its books and records and failing to implement adequate internal controls.  In addition, Alstom Network Schweiz AG, Alstomâ€™s Swiss subsidiary, pleaded guilty to a criminal information charging the company with conspiracy to violate the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  Alstom Power and Alstom Grid, two U.S. subsidiaries, both entered into deferred prosecution agreements, admitting that they conspired to violate the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  Individual (US)On 16 April 2013, the DOJ announced charges for two individuals associated with Alstom.  Frederic Pierucci (Alstom sales executive) was arrested on 14 April 2013 and charged with money laundering and violating the FCPA and conspiracy to launder money and conspiracy to violate the FCPA. Pierucci pleaded guilty on 30 July 2013 to the two FCPA charges.  As of 7 April 2014, Alstom faces an expanded probe including power projects in China and India, according to court documents in a related case. David Rothschild (former vice president of sales of Alstom USA) pleaded guilty on 2 November 2012 to conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  His charges were unsealed by the DOJ on 16 April 2013. On 1 May 2013, the DOJ announced charges for another former executive, William Pomponi - money laundering and violating the FCPA and conspiracy to launder money and conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Mr. Pomponi pleaded guilty on 17 July 2014 in connection with the awarding of the Tarahan power project in Indonesia. The DOJ announced the same charges for another former Alstom executive, Lawrence Hoskins, on 30 July 2013. UNITED KINGDOMOn 24 March 2010, the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) in the United Kingdom carried out dawn raids at nine locations, including five business locations and four personal residences, in a sting codenamed Operation Ruthenium. Three board members of Alstom's UK subsidiaries were arrested during the raids on suspicion of bribery and corruption, conspiracy to pay bribes, money laundering and false accounting. Stephen Burgin, Robert Purcell and Alan Cledwyn Davies were released later the same day without being charged. The SFO stated that it is working closely with Swiss authorities to investigate allegations of overseas bribery within the Company. Alstom stated that it is cooperating with the investigation.The Times of London reported on 7 September 2011 that a "senior figure" from Alstom had met with the SFO to discuss a possible settlement of the investigation. No settlement has occurred. The Telegraph reported, however, on 22 November 2011 that the amount that the SFO would require Alstom to pay under a settlement would be higher than the EUR 31 million paid by the Company under its settlement with Swiss authorities.In June 2014, the Attorney General gave the SFO permission to prosecute Alstom and its former employees for alleged overseas bribery, and on 24 July 2014, the SFO started criminal proceedings against Alstom's UK subsidiary, charging it with three corruption offenses, and three counts of conspiracy to corrupt.  On 10 September 2014, the trial of a U.K. subsidiary of Alstom began, with the SFO alleging in filings that the company paid USD $8.5 million in bribes for large transportation contracts in India, Poland, and Tunisia. A former managing director at the industrial giant Alstom appeared in court on 27 October 2014 after he was accused of bribing Indian transport officials to win lucrative contracts.  Robert Hallett, who worked for the companyâ€™s UK business, was accused of paying agents of Delhi Metro Rail Corporation USD $3.82 million (Â£2.44 million) and 19.9 million rupees (USD $316,792) â€œas inducements or rewards for showing favor to the Alstom in relation to the award or performance of a contract."Graham Hill, a former director of Alstom, was charged by a British court on 15 January 2015 with corruption and conspiring to dishonestly obtain services in relation to transportation contracts in India and Poland.  Two of the charges relate to Mr. Hill corruptly giving or agreeing to give payments to an official or officials or other agents of the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation Limited.  According to the allegations, Mr. Hill improperly gave "the sum of INR 19,895,000 disguised as payments in respect of a Consultancy Agreement with Indo European Ventures Pte Ltd."  Mr. Hill also allegedly gave "the sum of 3,131,600 euros disguised as a payment in respect of a Consultancy Agreement with Global King Technology Ltd dated 3rd May 2002 as inducements or rewards for showing favour to the Alstom Group in relation to the award or performance of a contract with the said Delhi Metro Rail Corporation Ltd for a Train Control, Signalling and Telecommunications System for the Delhi Metro Phase 1."  Mr. Hill's case was sent to Southwark Crown Court in London for a preliminary hearing on 28 January 2015.BRAZILDomestic bribery investigations in Brazil appear to be ongoing.  According to one press report on 2 March 2011, Brazil's Ministry of Justice received relevant documents from the Swiss and French authorities in early February 2011. According to news reports, in February 2015 a Brazilian court blocked approximately $104 million of assets belonging to Alstom, three former employees and a Sao Paulo judge.ITALYDomestic bribery investigations in Italy appear to be ongoing.  MEXICOAccording to a 2007 OECD report, in 2001 Mexican authorities brought civil charges against Alstom for bribing two high-ranking Mexican officials in 1999 in order to win a tender.  In 2004, Mexico's Ministry of Public Administration fined Alstom MXN 341,100 and barred the Company from participating in public tender procedures for two years. (Areva, another French company, was similarly charged and penalized in connection with the matter.)SLOVENIAAfter an investigation into the contract for the power plant in Sostanj, the Slovenia Commission for the Prevention of Corruption (SCPC) released its findings in February 2012, saying that "there was (and still is) high risk of corruption and conflict of interest" in the project. Reuters reported on 20 April 2012 that the Slovene Parliament voted to guarantee the loan provided for the project in spite of the SCPC's report of potential corruption. Aspects of Alstom's winning bid for the project appear to still be under investigation by the Slovenian National Investigations Office.SWITZERLANDOn 6 May 2010, Swiss prosecutors indicted Swiss banker Oskar Holenweger for money laundering and fraud in connection with his management of Alstom funds.  According to press reports, the indictment alleges that he received about CHF 1 million (USD 900,000) in exchange for arranging bribe payments from Alstom to business partners.  On 21 April 2011, it was reported that a Swiss court acquitted Holenweger of the charges and awarded him more than CHF 400,000 (USD 450,000) in damages, having found the evidence to be insufficient. On 22 November 2011, the Swiss Office of Attorney General (OAG) closed its investigation into Alstom.  Prosecutors identified three cases in which improper payments were made by Alstom Network Schweiz AG to civil servants in Latvia, Malaysia and Tunisia.  The Company was sanctioned for "corporate negligence" and fined CHF 2.5 million (around EUR 2 million), as well as  an amount corresponding to the estimated profits in the order of CHF 36 million (around EUR 29 million).  The OAG noted the Company's cooperation and remedial compliance measures. WORLD BANKOn 22 February 2012, a Negotiated Resolution Agreement was reached between Alstom and the World Bank.  This settlement includes (1) the debarment of Alstom Hydro France and Alstom Network Schweiz AG and their affiliates for a period of three years, and (2) payment of approximately USD 9.5 million in restitution by the two companies.  The period of debarment could be reduced to 21 months with enhanced oversight if all conditions are complied with.  Alstom SA and its affiliates are conditionally non-debarred.  However, Alstom Hydro France and Alstom Network Schweiz are subject to cross-debarment by other development banks.  The penalties are based on a finding that Alstom made an improper payment of a USD $145,000 (EUR 110,000) consultancy fee to an entity controlled by a former senior government official in Zambia in 2002.  Alstom did not admit the allegations.On 24 February 2015, Alstom disclosed that its subsidiaries Alstom Hydrom France, Alstom Network Schweiz and their affiliates had been released from the World Bank debarment based on the World Bank's Integrity Compliance Office's determination that Alstom had satisfied the conditions of its 21 February 2012 settlement with the World Bank. As part of its determination, the Integrity Compliance Office determined that Alstom had implemented a compliance program that is "in line with the World Bank's integrity compliance guidelines."EUROPEAN INVESTMENT BANK AND EUROPEAN BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENTIn April 2012, media reports stated that the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) had initiated investigations into the leak of information during the 2007 bidding process. Prior to this announcement, on 16 March 2012, the EBRD suspended payments on the TES project, pending the conclusion of an investigation into bidding and procurement corruption.ANCILLARY CONSEQUENCES: INSTITUTIONAL INVESTORSIn December 2011, the Norwegian Ministry of Finance placed Alstom on the Norwegian Government Pension Fund's watch list because of the corruption allegations. The Fund owns about USD $250 million worth of Alstom shares; its Ethics Board will now monitor Alstom's activities for four years before deciding whether to divest or not.

SwedenThe (former) Swedish Chief Prosecutor had to withdraw one of the preliminary investigations since it could not be established that any company representative had acted premeditatedly in connection with the alleged bribe payments.  The (former) Swedish Chief Prosecutor stated, when commenting on the decision, that Swedish law does not effectively cover these types of arrangements between intermediaries and consultants.  The Swedish investigation was criticized for having had very limited resources.  It was formally closed in June 2009 but, in May 2011, it was reported that a new investigation had been opened into an aspect of the deal with the South African government.  Swedish news channel TV4 reported that Sanip, a Saab subsidiary, entered into a consulting contract in 2003 with an adviser to the South African Minister of Defense at the time.  Sanip allegedly paid  50 million Swedish kronor (USD 7.9 million) in 19 installments between 2003 and 2005, through the adviser, to Ministry of Defense officials in order to prevent the termination of the Gripen deal entered into in 1999.  On May 20, 2011, Saab issued a press release stating that it was conducting an internal investigation into the matter but that so far there was no indication that Saab had any knowledge or involvement in any wrongdoing.  Saab stated: "At the time, Sanip was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Saab in South Africa whose operations were being run by BAE Systems plc. In 2004, the operations were formally transferred from Sanip to BAE and the company has been dormant since then."Czech RepublicThe Czech government opened an investigation into the Gripen fighter deal in 2002. The investigation was closed after the police determined that while the deal was most likely tainted with corruption, it could not find any evidence related to the individuals involved. The investigation was re-opened in 2007, but closed again in 2009 for the same reason. In March 2010, the Supreme State Attorney pushed for the police to re-open the investigation for a third time.  It is unclear for a time whether the investigation remained open. According to press reports on August 30, 2011, the Czech investigation remains open and recently received assistance from the SFO in the UK.  The SFO reportedly sent documents on August 8th related to the Czech attempt to buy the 24 JAS Gripen jet fighter planes.  The assistance was reportedly moved forward following Czech Prime Minister Petr Necas's decision to raise the issue with his British counterpart, David Cameron, when the latter visited Prague at the end of June.The Czech government has received information from the Polish and Austrian authorities but still awaits replies to its assistance requests to the US and Switzerland.HungaryIn June 2007 the Hungarian government set up an investigative committee to look into the Gripen affair. The report was completed in November 2007 and was not made fully public. The committee did not investigate the questions of corruption or political responsibility, and said that these will be the task of a parliamentary committee to be formed later. This parliamentary committee, however, was never established.
The case is still pending.  Prosecutions against three VEC employees have been initiated and the main proceedings were to begin in 2010.

On 8 July 1986, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Ashland Oil and Orin Atkins each consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining them from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions.

US Prosecution of IndividualsOn 20 November 2006, Christian Sapsizian, a French citizen, was arrested at Miami International Airport when his flight landed from Panama on the way to Paris.  He was indicted on 19 December 2006 on charges of violating the FCPA and money laundering.  A ten-count superseding indictment was handed down on March 20, 2007.  On 6 June 2007, Sapsizian pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate the FCPA and one substantive FCPA violation.  He was sentenced to 30 months in prison and three years supervised release on 23 September 2008.  The court also ordered him to forfeit USD 261,500.  Sapsizian admitted that from February 2000 through September 2004, he conspired with Valverde and others to make millions of dollars in bribe payments to Costa Rican officials in order to obtain a telecommunications contract on behalf of Alcatel.  In its plea agreement with Sapsizian, the government agreed not to charge him with FCPA violations related to corrupt payments in other parts of Latin America. On 20 March 2007, Edgar Valverde Acosta, a Costa Rican citizen, was indicted for violating the FCPA.  He remains a fugitive.DOJ and SEC SettlementsOn 27 December 2010, the DOJ filed a criminal information in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida charging Alcatel with one count of violating the internal control provisions of the FCPA and one count of violating the books and records provisions of the FCPA.  The DOJ and Alcatel agreed to resolve the charges by entering into a deferred prosecution agreement for a term of three years.  The DOJ also filed a criminal information charging three subsidiaries - Alcatel-Lucent France S.A. (formerly known as Alcatel CIT S.A.), Alcatel-Lucent Trade International A.G. (formerly known as Alcatel Standard A.G.) and Alcatel Centroamerica S.A. (formerly known as Alcatel de Costa Rica S.A.) - with conspiring to violate the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions.  Each of the three subsidiaries agreed to plead guilty to the charges.  Alcatel and the three subsidiaries agreed to pay a combined USD 92 million criminal fine.  Alcatel also agreed to retain an independent compliance monitor (who is a French national) for a three year period.  The settlement and guilty pleas were finalized in Miami federal court on 1 June 2011. Also on 27 December 2010, the SEC filed a settled civil enforcement action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida to resolve charges that Alcatel violated the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions.  Alcatel agreed to pay USD 45,372,000 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.French InvestigationThe French Investigating Magistrate (Tribunal de grande instance de Paris) appears to be continuing its investigation into the activities of Alcatel-Lucent France in Costa Rica, Kenya, Nigeria and French Polynesia.  Costa Rican InvestigationThe Public Prosecutor's Office in Costa Rica opened investigations into company employees as well as the government officials who were the recipients of the alleged bribes.  Alcatel reportedly made a USD 10 million payment in January 2010 to the Costa Rican government for "societal damages," settling the government's case against the company.  On 27 April 2011, Former President Miguel Angel Rodriguez was convicted of accepting at least USD 800,000 in bribes from Alcatel and was sentenced to a five year prison term.  Eight other people charged along with the ex-president were reportedly convicted as well and sentenced to varying terms.In Alcatel-Lucent's SEC Form 6-K filed on 8 August 2012, the company added, "ICE on May 3, 2012 filed before the Tribunal Contencioso Administrativo y Civil de Hacienda of Costa Rica a new claim against a number of Alcatel-Lucent legal entities with regards to the corruption matter that was investigated by and settled with the Costa Rican and United States authorities. The ICE claim totals 14 million euros. No reserves have been booked as it is Alcatel-Lucent's position that this matter has been fully settled with the Costa Rican Prosecution Office in 2010."Malaysian InvestigationAccording to press reports on 25 March 2011, Malaysian authorities also began investigating Alcatel in December 2010 following the company's settlement with the U.S. government.  According to press reports on 19 July 2011, Radziah Ani - a former regional customer account leader for Alcatel Malaysia - was charged by Malaysian prosecutors under the Anti Corruption Act of 1997, with bribing a Telekom Malaysia assistant manager.  On 13 August 2012, the Court in Malaysia announced that the prima facie case against Radziah had been proved, and that she would now be required to enter her defense.  Radziah is accused of offering a RM 25,000 bribe to Telekom Malaysia Bhd assistant manager Mohd Asri Idris so that the latter would provide information about an ongoing tender at that time (2006) for the supply of Wideband Code Division Multiple Access Mobile Communications Systems.  The tender, which was ultimately awarded to Alcatel, was valued at RM 320 million (approx. USD 106 million). The offense is alleged to have been committed at the Shangri-la Hotel in Jalan Sultan Ismail on 17 February 2006. Trial is scheduled to resume on 19 September 2012.Meanwhile, Telekom Malaysia and mobile operator Axiata Group Bhd (Celcom) have reportedly barred Alcatel from bidding for new tenders for a year as a result of the matter.

On 17 December 2002, Basu pleaded guilty to conspiring to steer World Bank contracts to consultants and assisting a contractor with bribing foreign officials in violation of the FCPA.  He was sentenced on 15 April 2008 to 15 months in prison, two years of supervised release and 50 hours of community service. Sengupta pleaded guilty the same charges in February 2002 and was sentenced to two months in prison and required to pay a USD 6,000 fine.

On 1 July 2004, Thompson and Reilly were indicted for conspiracy and violations of the Travel Act and the FCPA.  A jury found both men not guilty on 20 May 2005.  On 22 April 2004, Nico pleaded guilty to a wire fraud charge, agreeing to forfeit USD 1,005,602 million in ill-gotten gains based on the kickbacks he received and a USD 631,502 bonus received as a result of securing and maintaining the contract with the Saudi foundation.  On 9 June 2005, Nico was sentenced to 36 months of probation and ordered to pay a USD 250,000 fine.On 27 April 2004, Carman pleaded guilty to making a false statement to the FBI; on 3 August 2005 he sentenced to 36 months of probation and ordered to pay a USD 500 fine.  Both men are cooperating with the DOJ's ongoing investigation.

In 1979, Kenny International pleaded guilty to one count of bribery of a foreign official in violation of the FCPA.  The company consented to the entry of a final judgment of permanent injunction against future FCPA violations and was fined USD 50,000. Also in 1979, Kenny, without admitting or denying the DOJ's allegations, consented the entry of a final judgment of permanent injunction against future FCPA violations.  Kenny also pleaded guilty to a criminal charge in the High Court of Cook Islands and agreed to cooperate with the Government of the Cook Islands whenever requested.  He agreed to pay restitution in the amount of NZD 337,000 to the government of the Cook Islands.

On 21 November 1996, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Montedison consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's books and records provisions and other federal securities laws.  The company was also ordered to pay a USD 300,000 civil penalty. According to the SEC's Litigation Release, most of the senior management involved in the conduct were convicted under Italian criminal law and sued by Montedison.

In June 2001, Robert King and Pablo Barquero Hernandez were charged with conspiracy to violate the FCPA, substantive violations of the FCPA and violations of the Travel Act.  King stood trial and was convicted on all counts.  He was sentenced to 30 months in prison and ordered to pay a $60,000 fine.  The conviction was upheld on appeal.  Hernandez remains a fugitive in Costa Rica.  Costa Rica will not extradite its citizens. Also in 2001, Albert Reitz pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA, mail fraud, false statements and filing false income tax returns.  Richard Halford pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Both Reitz and Halford agreed to testify against King at his trial and, as a result, both received probation and community service.

On 11 May 1989, GIC pleaded guilty to one substantive count of violating the FCPA. Under the plea agreement, GIC agreed to pay a USD 250,000 criminal fine.In September 1988, Janasik pleaded guilty to filing a false tax return on the USD 75,000 he received as a kickback from the Iraqi official.  He was fined USD 10,000 and sentenced to two years of probation.
On 21 January 1993, without admitting or denying the DOJ's allegations, American Totalisator agreed to the entry of a permanent injunction enjoining them from future violations of the FCPA.
On 9 April 1979, without admitting or denying the DOJ's allegations, Carver and Holley each consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining them from future violations of the FCPA.

UNITED STATESOn 15 December 2008, Siemens settled charges with the DOJ and the SEC for a record-breaking USD $800 million in fines and penalties.Under its plea agreement with the DOJ, Siemens pleaded guilty to two counts of violating the books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  Siemens Argentina pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and Siemens Venezuela and Siemens Bangladesh each pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the anti-bribery and books and records provisions of the FCPA.  Siemens was required to pay a USD 448.5 million criminal fine and Siemens Argentina, Bangladesh, and Venezuela were each required to pay a USD 500,000 criminal fine, bringing the total amount in criminal fines in the United States to USD 450 million. Siemens, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the Company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions.  Siemens was also required to pay USD 350 million in disgorgement of profits. Both the DOJ and SEC noted Siemens' extraordinary cooperation during the investigation and the extensive remedial measures undertaken by the Company, including the scope of its internal investigation after disclosing the conduct to the U.S. enforcement authorities, disciplinary actions against individuals involved, and the restructuring of the Company's compliance program.On 9 January 2009, the DOJ announced that it had filed a forfeiture action against Siemens' accounts in Singapore held by multiple account holders.  The funds in the accounts were allegedly related to bribes paid by Siemens and China Harbor Engineering to Arafat "Koko" Raman, the son of Bangladesh's former prime minister in connection with the award of a public works project in Bangladesh.  The funds allegedly were paid in U.S. dollars and flowed through banks in the United States before being deposited into accounts in Singapore.   Individual ProsecutionsOn 13 December 2011, the DOJ charged eight former executives and agents of Siemens AG and its subsidiaries for allegedly engaging in a decade-long scheme to bribe senior government officials in Argentina to secure, implement, and enforce a USD 1 billion contract with the government of Argentina to produce national identity cards.  The defendants in the DOJ action, Uriel Sharef, Herbert Steffen, Andres Truppel, Ulrich Bock, Eberhard Reichert, Stephan Signer, Carlos Sergi, and Miguel Czysch, are not U.S. citizens and reside outside of the United States.  Unless the U.S. government obtains extradition of the men, they cannot be tried on the criminal charges.The SEC also filed a civil action on related charges against seven men, alleging that over USD $100 million in bribes were paid in connection with Siemens' efforts to secure the contract and obtain the profits from that contract. As for these charges, legal process requires that the defendants be served with the complaint in the lawsuit, but SEC lawyers were unable to serve the four German defendants (Sharef, Signer, Steffen, and Bock) via the Hague Convention, absent the cooperation of the German government, which responded to requests for assistance in service by stating:  "The German government has recently advised that an action by the SEC seeking civil penalties for violations of U.S. federal securities laws is not, under German law, a 'civil or commercial matter' within the meaning of the Hague Convention." Therefore, the SEC attorneys requested permission to serve the four men through newspaper notices and emails to their attorneys.  On 26 June 2012, the U.S. court agreed to this request. On 12 October 2012, Herbert Steffen filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction and for failure to satisfy the statute of limitations. On 19 February 2013, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York granted Steffen's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, saying that Steffen did not have sufficient contacts with the United States to meet the requirements of personal jurisdiction and that exercising jurisdiction over him would be unreasonable due to his age and other factors. Regendantz settled the SEC charges in December 2011 without admitting or denying the allegations by consenting to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining him from committing future violations. He paid a EUR 30,000 (USD $ 40,000) administrative fine ordered by the Munich prosecutor.The Wall Street Journal reported on 15 April 2013 that Uriel Sharef agreed to pay USD $275,000 to settle the SEC's civil suit against him. Sharef did so without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations. On 4 February 2014, two former Siemens executives were ordered to pay a combined USD $1.46 million for their roles in a USD $1 billion Argentine government contract bribery scheme, the largest Foreign Corrupt Practices Act penalties ever levied against individuals.  U.S. District Judge Shira A. Scheindlin entered a default judgment against Mr. Signer and Mr. Bock and ordered each to to pay a USD $524,000 civil penalty and Mr. Block to pay an additional USD $413,957 for disgorgement.
