The two German nationals allegedly bribed Argentine government officials as part of a decade-long scheme to retain a USD $1 billion government contract to produce Argentine national identity cards.On 14 August 2014, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the dismissal of a lawsuit filed by a former Siemens compliance officer in China who said the company retaliated against him after he internally reported alleged corrupt sales practices.  The court granted Siemensâ€™s motion to dismiss with prejudice, holding that the anti-retaliation provision of the Doddâ€êFrank Act (15 U.S.C. Â§ 78uâ€ê6(h)(1)) does not apply extraterritorially.ARGENTINAOn 14 December 2012, La Nueva reported that a federal judge in Argentina held a hearing regarding the possible extradition of former Siemens AG CFO Andres Truppel to the United States to face criminal charges. Main Justice reported on 18 March 2013 that Truppel is one of four defendants who also have failed to respond to the civil suit brought by the SEC, and that the SEC is seeking to have Truppel be considered in default of the civil charges. On 14 June 2011, it was reported that a Siemens management board member had been charged in connection with breach of trust in connection with bribes paid (through slush funds, phony companies and middlemen) in Argentina between 2003 and 2007. Argentinian authorities searched the offices of Siemens Argentina and Siemens IT Services S.A. in Buenos Aires in August 2008 and February 2009. The Argentinean investigative judge requested judicial assistance from the Munich public prosecutor and the federal court in New York.In a separate suit arising out of the earlier investigation, Carlos Moran, formerly a government investigator in Argentina, brought a claim in federal court in Miami against Siemens AG and Siemens' subsidiary in Argentina.  Moran claims that Siemens paid people to physically attack him after he blew the whistle on Siemens' bid for the national identity card project.CHINAShi Wanzhong, former chairman and general manager of China Mobile Anhui Province, was sentenced to death in May 2011 in the Intermediate Court of Hebei City, Henan Province, for receiving USD $5.1 million in bribes from Siemens.  Shi received a two-year reprieve (which usually means that the sentence will not be carried out).  The trial was closed to the public. Tian Qu, who served as sales agent for Siemens and was responsible for brokering the deals between Siemens and China Mobile Anhui and for transferring the kickbacks to Shi, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for facilitating Shi's corruption. The Chinese investigation appears to have concluded in June 2011. On 15 January 2013, a former compliance officer for Siemens' Chinese subsidiary filed a lawsuit against Siemens in federal court in New York.  The former employee, a Taiwanese man named Meng-Lin Liu, claimed that in May 2011, one week after presenting evidence of Siemens' continued internal controls violations and the Company's  circumvention of its plea agreement with U.S. authorities, he was notified that his contract would not be renewed, and that he should not report to work. In the complaint, Liu alleges that the evidence he submitted to the SEC and Siemens' executives revealed the Company's practice of submitting inflated bids for the sale of medical imaging equipment in China, and then selling the equipment at lower prices to intermediaries, for resale to public hospitals.GERMANYIn its settlement with the Munich Prosecutor's Office, Siemens (apart from its telecommunications group) pleaded guilty to charges related to a corporate failure to supervise its officers and employees and paid a total of EUR 395 million (approximately USD 569 million), including a EUR 250,000 corporate fine and EUR 394.75 million in disgorgement of profits.  In a related action, Siemens' telecommunications operating group settled charges with the Munich Prosecutor's Office in October 2007, and paid EUR 201 million in fines and penalties (approximately USD 287 million), including a EUR 1 million fine and EUR 200 million in disgorgement of profits. In addition to monetary fines and penalties, the German public prosecutors required Siemens to retain an independent compliance monitor for a four-year period.  Siemens and the enforcement agencies agreed to the appointment of Dr. Theodor Waigel, the former German finance minister, as its independent monitor.  Joseph Warrin of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP was appointed to serve as counsel to the monitor with respect to the requirements of the FCPA. On 20 April 2010, Michael Kutschenreuter, the former financial head of Siemens' telecommunications unit, was found guilty of breach of trust and abetting bribery in a Munich court.  He was placed on probation for two years and fined EUR 160,000.  On the same day, Hans-Werner Hartmann, head of accounting for the telecommunications unit, was placed on probation for 18 months and fined EUR 40,000.On 19 May 2011, it was reported that Berlin prosecutors dropped its case against former Siemens board member, Thomas Ganswindt, who used to run the Company's telecommunications unit, in exchange for Ganswindt agreeing to make a payment of EUR 175,000 euros (USD 250,000) to five charities.  Siemens' former finance chief Heinz-Joachim Neubuerger is still fighting charges. GREECEAccording to press reports on 25 November 2011, Greek finance and justice ministers sought an out-of-court settlement with Siemens in the range of EUR 200 million to EUR 250 million.  In February 2012, Siemens entered into an agreement with the Greek government, pledging to forgo EUR 80 million in outstanding Greek debt in exchange for no claims for reparations resulting from the bribery scandal, which purportedly cost Greek taxpayers EUR 2 billion in overpayment of Siemens contracts.  All told, Greece owes Siemens approximately EUR 150 million.  The arrangement requires Greece to invest EUR 90 million with Siemens in new projects. In a press release on 5 April 2012, Siemens confirmed the arrangement, announcing that the Greek Parliament had ratified the settlement agreement.  The settlement approves Siemens' forgiving of EUR 80 million owed to it by the Greek government, for supplies delivered to Greek medical facilities over a period of years.  Siemens has agreed to spend up to EUR 90 million on "transparency initiatives and anti-corruption programs," and on research.  Siemens also agreed to spend over EUR 100 million on its own commercial activities in Greece, thereby encouraging economic growth and increasing employment within Greece. According to media reports, on 9 March 2015 Greek authorities indicted 64 people to stand trial for bribery or money laundering. Former Siemens and OTE officials are included in those indicted. HUNGARYInvestigations are ongoing into Siemens Zrt. Hungary and certain of its employees in connection with consulting agreements with a variety of shell corporations and alleged bribery relating to the awarding of a contract for the delivery of communication equipment to the Hungarian Armed Forces.ISRAELOn 17 March 2013, Reuters reported that Dan Cohen, former director of the state-owned Israel Electric Corporation (â€œIECâ€ù), was extradited to Israel from Peru and arrested on bribery and other charges based on allegations that he accepted EUR 1 million in exchange for ensuring that Siemens won a lucrative contract with IEC in 1999. Cohen had left Israel in 2005, and Peru had previously denied requests for extradition. On 11 July 2013, The Times of Israel reported that Cohen has entered into a plea bargain with prosecutors, agreeing to spend five years and six months in prison and pay a fine of ILS 6 million (USD 1.65 million). The story also reported that prosecutors will also take ILS 4 million (USD 1.1 million) in assets from Cohen as part of the agreement.On 5 January 2015, six current and former executives from state-owned Israel Electric Corporation were detained in connection with allegedly accepting bribes paid by Siemens.  Investigators from the Israel Securities Authority arrested Yacov (Yasha) Hain, a senior vice president for engineering projects.  Mr. Hain said he was resigning from the Israel Electric Corporation for health reasons.  He is accused of taking hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes.  According to local news media, there is court-ordered gag order on the release of details about Mr. Hain's case.ITALYThe public prosecutor in Milan filed charges against a current and a former employee of Siemens S.p.A., against the company itself, and against one of its subsidiaries. Siemens S.p.A. and its subsidiary entered into a 'patteggiamento' (plea bargaining agreement without the recognition of any guilt or responsibility) with the Milan public prosecutor which was confirmed by the Milan court on April 27, 2009. Under the terms of the patteggiamento, Siemens S.p.A. and the subsidiary were each fined â‚¬40,000 and ordered to disgorge profits in the amount of â‚¬315,562 and â‚¬502,370, respectively.On 14 May 2007, the two individuals, Andreas Kley, the former finance chief at Siemens' power-generation unit, and Horst Vigener, a former consultant to Siemens' power-generation unit, were convicted in a Darmstadt court for paying about EUR 6 million in bribes from 1999 to 2002.  Kley received a two-year suspended sentence and Vigener a nine-month suspended sentence.  According to press reports, both sentences were less than prosecutors had requested.MEXICOMexican officials are investigating whether officials in the state-owned PEMEX received bribes from the Conproca consortium, composed of Siemens AG and SK Engineering and Construction Co.The new foreign bribery investigations remain ongoing at this time. NIGERIAOn 22 November 2010, it was reported that Siemens agreed to pay NGN 7 billion (approximately USD 46.5 million) to the Nigerian government in exchange for the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission's withdrawal of criminal charges against Siemens, its Nigerian subsidiary, Siemens Ltd. Nigeria and four of its officials.  The payment was described variously as "restitution" and "disgorgement" in press reports.  NORWAYOn July 3, 2009, the trial court in Oslo, Norway, found the two former Siemens AS Norway employees not guilty on charges related to payments made for golf trips attended by officials from the Norwegian Department of Defense. Norwayâ€™s anti-corruption force, Oekokrim, stated on July 16, 2009, that the proceedings against Siemens AS Norway have also been discontinued.RUSSIAOn July 5, 2011, the Russian investigation was closed with respect to all material charges.SWITZERLANDIn November 2013, the Swiss authorities issued fines and seized CHF 60 million (approximately USD $65 million) relating to the Siemens â€œslush fundâ€ù scandal.  In doing so, the Federal Prosecutor's Office signaled the conclusion of an eight year investigation into executives and shell companies that used the Swiss financial system to channel massive bribes used to win lucrative contracts for the German industrial giant.  In addition to the CHF 60 million of bribe money seized by the Attorney General, a further sum of â‚¬630,000 (CHF 776,000) was paid to Transparency International Switzerland, the Geneva foundation La Maison de Tara and to the SOS Childrenâ€™s Village in Munich. UNITED NATIONSSiemens provided the following update regarding its United Nations debarment in its SEC Form 6-K filed on 10 November 2011:"As previously reported, on March 9, 2009, Siemens AG received a decision by the Vendor Review Committee of the United Nations Secretariat Procurement Division (UNPD) suspending Siemens AG from the UNPD vendor database for a minimum period of six months. The suspension applied to contracts with the UN Secretariat and stemmed from Siemens AG's guilty plea in December 2008 to violations of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. On December 22, 2009, Siemens AG filed a request to lift the existing suspension. Effective January 1, 2011, the UNPD lifted the suspension against Siemens AG."Related Civil LitigationCompany suit against directors: Siemens AG asserted claims against former members of the Managing and Supervisory Board for breaches of organizational and supervisory duties in view of the accusations of illegal business practices that occurred in the course of international business transactions in the years 2003 to 2006 and the resulting financial burdens for the Company. On December 2, 2009 Siemens reached a settlement with nine out of eleven former members of the Managing and Supervisory Board. The Company reached a settlement agreement with its directors and officers (D&O;) insurers regarding claims in connection with the D&O; insurance of up to â‚¬100 million, of which â‚¬84 million resulted from the settlement agreement with the D&O; insurers and â‚¬12 million resulted from settlement agreements with former board members. The former board members used claims they had against the Company to offset a portion of their obligations under the aforementioned settlement agreements. The remaining amount was or will be settled by the former board members in cash. On January 25, 2010, Siemens AG filed a lawsuit with the Munich District Court I against the two former board members who were not willing to settle, Thomas Ganswindt and Heinz-Joachim Neuburger. Derivative shareholder suit: An alleged holder of Siemens American Depositary Shares filed a derivative lawsuit in February 2007 with the Supreme Court of the State of New York against certain current and former members of Siemens' Managing and Supervisory Boards as well as against Siemens as a nominal defendant, seeking various forms of relief relating to the allegations of corruption and related violations at Siemens. The shareholder voluntarily withdrew the derivative action in September 2009.Class action suit: A securities class action was filed in December 2009 against Siemens AG with the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York seeking damages for alleged violations of U.S. securities laws. In March 2011, the Court granted the Company's motion to dismiss the action. The plaintiffs' motion to reconsider was denied by the court. Plaintiffs did not appeal the court's decision. Iraq Oil-for-Food civil suit: In June 2008, the Republic of Iraq filed an action requesting unspecified damages against 93 named defendants with the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York on the basis of findings made in the 'Report of the Independent Inquiry Committee into the United Nations Oil-for-Food Programme.' Siemens S.A.S. France, Siemens A. S. Turkey and OSRAM Middle East FZE, Dubai, are among the 93 named defendants. Argentinian arbitration:Siemens AG filed a request for arbitration against Argentina with the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) of the World Bank. Siemens AG claimed that Argentina had unlawfully terminated its contract with Siemens for the development and operation of a system for the production of identity cards, border control, collection of data and voters' registers (DNI project) and thereby violated the Bilateral Investment Protection Treaty between Argentina and Germany (BIT). Siemens AG sought damages for expropriation and violation of the BIT of approximately U.S. $500 million. A unanimous decision on the merits was rendered by the ICSID arbitration tribunal on February 6, 2007, awarding Siemens AG compensation in the amount of U.S. $217.8 million, plus compound interest thereon at a rate of 2.66% since May 18, 2001. The tribunal also ruled that Argentina is obligated to indemnify Siemens AG against any claims of subcontractors in relation to the project (amounting to approximately U.S. $44 million) and, furthermore, that Argentina would be obligated to pay Siemens AG the full amount of the contract performance bond (U.S. $20 million) in the event this bond was not returned. The time period set by the tribunal for returning the contract performance bond subsequently elapsed without delivery. As previously reported, Argentina subsequently filed applications with the ICSID aiming at the annulment and reversal of the decision and a stay of enforcement of the arbitral award. On August 12, 2009, Argentina and Siemens AG reached an agreement to mutually settle the case and discontinue any and all civil proceedings in connection with the case without acknowledging any legal obligations or claims. No payment was made by either party.Civil Suit by Hellenic Telecommunications Organization S.A.: In July 2008, the Hellenic Telecommunications Organization S.A. ("OTE") filed a lawsuit against Siemens AG in the District Court of Munich.  The lawsuit sought disclosure by Siemens AG of information pertaining to "allegations of undue influence and/or acts of bribery in connection with contracts concluded between Siemens AG and OTE from 1992 to 2006."  After being granted access to some of Siemens' files, OTE expanded its claim, requesting at least EUR 57.07 million in damages from Siemens for alleged bribes to its employees.  Siemens and OTE are currently negotiating a settlement.PEMEX civil suit: PEMEX filed a Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (â€œRICOâ€ù) lawsuit against Siemens AG and SK Engineering & Construction Co., claiming USD $500 million in damages for bribery conducted by the two companies in 1997 and thereafter, in connection with the Cedereyta project.  U.S. District Judge Louis Stanton of Manhattan dismissed the lawsuit brought by PEMEX against Siemens.  The dismissal was upheld by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on 17 July 2014.

In November 1990, MEI and Mason each pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  MEI and Mason were ordered to pay, jointly and severally, a criminal fine of $75,000, as well as $160,000 in restitution to the Federal Republic of Germany.  Mason was also senteced to five years of probation.

On July 25, 1994, Vitusa pleaded guilty to one count of violating the FCPA and was ordered to pay a $20,000 criminal fine.  On the same day, Herzberg pleaded guilty to one count of violating the FCPA.  He  was sentenced to two years of probation and ordered to pay a $5,000 criminal fine, to be applied toward the $20,000 owed by Vitusa.

On December 3, 1998, Saybolt North America and Saybolt, Inc. pleaded guilty of violating the FCPA and the Clean Air Act.  The companies were sentenced to five years of probation, a $3.4 million fine and an $800 special assessment for their violations of the Clean Air Act, and five years of probation, a $1.5 million fine and an $800 special assessment for violations of the FCPA.  Saybolt, Inc. was also required to implement and maintain an effective compliance program.  In addition, the company agreed to cooperate with the government in its ongoing investigation. On April 17, 1998, Frerik Pluimers and David Mead were indicted on charges of conspiring to violate the FCPA, substantive violations of the FCPA and violations of the Travel Act.  Mead stood trial and was convicted of the charges in October 1998.  He was sentenced to four months in jail, four months of home confinement, three year's supervised probation and was required to pay a $20,000 fine. During his trial, Mead raised the defense that he was acting on advice of counsel.  According to Mead, Philippe Schreiber, an attorney with New York-based Walter, Conston, Alexander & Green P.C. and a Director of Saybolt North America, advised during a Board meeting in November 1995 that the company would only be criminally liable for the bribe if it was paid by Saybolt North America.  Schreiber allegedly advised that the bribe could be paid legally by the Dutch entity, Saybolt International.  The jury instruction specifically stated that Mead could not be convicted if he believed that the transaction was legal.  The jury convicted Mead, rejecting his argument that he believed the transaction was legal.Pluimers, who was in the Netherlands when he was indicted, has not returned to the U.S. to stand trial.  The U.S. government requested the Netherlands to extradite him in 2000 but Dutch authorities have refused the request.  In March 2008, his attorney entered an appearance for an arraignment and guilty plea, but Pluimers never appeared in court.  He remains a fugitive and is on the EPA's most wanted list. In a related case, Saybolt North America's shareholders sued Schreiber for malpractice, arguing that the company relied on his advice in paying the bribe. The parties settled the case on August 12, 2005. The settlement was never publicly disclosed.

Hydro Kleen, Watts and Bakke were each charged with two counts of violating Section 3(1)(a) of Canada's Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act ("CFPOA").  On January 10, 2005, Hydro Kleen entered a plea of guilty in the Court of Queen's Bench in Red Deer, Alberta.  The company admitted to one count under Section 3(1)(a) of the CFPOA and was ordered to pay a CAD 25,000 fine. The charges against Watts and Bakke were stayed.  In July 2002, the U.S. official, Hector Ramirez Garcia, pleaded guilty to accepting bribes.  He was sentenced to six months in jail and subsequently deported to the United States.

On February 27, 1997, Triton, without admitting or denying the charges, consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining it from violating the books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA. Triton paid a $300,000 civil penalty.  In the same action, Philip Keever consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining him from violations of the FCPA's books and records provisions.  He was ordered to pay a $50,000 civil penalty. On the same day and in a related action, the SEC brought administrative proceedings against David Gore, Robert Puetz, William McClure and Robert Murphy. Without admitting or denying the allegations, Gore, Puetz, McClure and Murphy consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order enjoining them form committing future violations of the books and records requirements of the Exchange Act.

Civil SuitAs part of the settlement of a civil case in Bangladesh relating to the explosions in June 2005, Niko paid a total of CAD 625,000 to the families of those affected by the disaster and to replant trees.  The Bangladeshi government has also sued Niko seeking CAD 100 Million in compensation for lost gas and environmental damage. Bangladesh InvestigationIn 2007, the Bangladesh Anticorruption Commission ("ACC") was given special powers to investigate, indict and arrest.  That year, the ACC opened a case against Niko.  In April 2008, approximately 20 people, including two former prime ministers, were charged in connection with corrupt Niko deals with the government.  Niko was allegedly â€œvery inefficientâ€ù in different respects, including technical know-how for oil explorations, and the deal was allegedly approved in violation of proper procedures.  No Canadian executives or officers were charged in this investigation.On 12 February 2012, a case was filed in criminal court in Bangladesh against Mosharraf Hossain and Kashem Shari, alleging  violations of the Corruption Prevention Act as well as provisions in the penal code.  On 3 August 2012, the prosecutor (called the Investigation officer ("IO") in Bangladesh), along with ACC Assistant Director Shahidur Rahman, submitted the charge sheet to the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate's court of Dhaka, naming 15 prosecution witnesses.  The charge sheet claims that Kashem is a fugitive., and the IO requested that the court issue an arrest warrant against Kashem.During the previous caretaker government, a criminal complaint was also filed against former prime minister Khaleda Zia for graft in the redeveloped the Feni Gas Field in 2004, for which a joint venture with Niko and Bangladesh Petroleum Exploration and Production Company Limited ("Bapex") was formed.  The status of this case, and the case against nine other individuals, is not clear. Canada InvestigationIn early 2009, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police began their own investigation into possible violations by Niko of the Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act ("CFPOA").  On June 24, 2011, Niko reached a settlement with the RCMP, pleading guilty to one count of violating the CFPOA in connection with the two incidents in 2005 and agreeing to pay CAD 9,499,000 in penalties and a probation order requiring compliance audits for a three-year period.  The Canadian authorities made note of the expenses of the investigation:  the RCMP spent CAD 870,000 and worked in cooperation with the Bangladesh Anti-Corruption Commission, the DOJ's Justice Fraud Section, the U.S. FBI International Corruption Unit, and law enforcement in Japan, the United Kingdom, Switzerland and Barbados.

On November 13, 2009, Jumet pleaded guilty to a two-count information charging him with conspiracy to violate the FCPA and making a false statement.  Under his plea agreement, Jumet has agreed to cooperate with the DOJ in its ongoing investigation.  On April 19, 2010, Jumet was sentenced to 87 months in prison, followed by three years of supervised release.  He was also ordered to pay a $15,000 fine.  The prison sentence is the longest ever imposed for violating the FCPA.On December 15, 2009, Warwick was indicted by a federal grand jury for conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  On February 10, 2010 he pleaded guilty to the one-count indictment.  Under his plea agreement Warwick agreed to forfeit $331,000, which represents the proceeds that he and his engineering firm received as a result of the contracts awarded to PECC by the Panamanian government. On June 25, 2010, Warwick was sentenced 37 months in prison to be followed by two years of supervised release; he was also ordered to forfeit $331,000 in proceeds of the crime.The conspiracy counts Jumet and Warwick face carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of $250,000 or twice the gross gain or loss from the scheme. Jumet's false statement count carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of $250,000.

On 6 September 2006, Amoako pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  On 26 July 2007, he was sentenced to 18 months in prison, including 6 months in a halfway house, and 2 years of probation.  Amoako agreed to a criminal fine of USD 7,500.  On 25 July 2007, Ott pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act.  On 21 July 2008, he was sentenced to 5 years of probation (including 6 months in a community corrections center and 6 months in home confinement) and agreed to a criminal fine of USD 10,000 plus interest.  On 25 July 2007, Young pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act.  On 2 September 2008, he was sentenced to 5 years of probation (including 3 months in community confinement and 3 months in home confinement) and agreed to a criminal fine of USD 7,000 plus interest.  On 18 April 2008, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Amoako, Ott and Young each consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining them from future violations of the FCPA.  Amoako was also ordered to pay USD 188,435 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.

Under Italian law (Legislative Decree n. 231 of 2001), companies may be held liable for a number of criminal offences through the concept of vicarious criminal liability, including corruption, bribery, extortion committed abroad.  This is in addition to the personal criminal liability of the individual who committed the offence.The following basic requirements must be satisfied in order for a legal person to be administratively liable for the relevant offences:1. The offence must be committed for the benefit or interest of the legal person. There is no offence committed where the person responsible commits the offence exclusively in his/her own interest or in the interest of a third party.2. The offence must be committed by a person acting as a representative, director or manager (de facto), a person exercising powers of management and control or a person subject to the direction or control of one of the aforementioned persons.3. The offence must be committed through non-compliance with the duties connected to the functions of the responsible person.  In order to avoid administrative liability, companies must prove that they have, in a timely manner, adopted effective organisation, management and control programs aimed to prevent the above crimes.In 2006, the Court of Milan adopted an interim decision ordering seizure of the profits of the illicit behavior.  The amount of said profits was established by an independent expert appointed by the Court.  Subsequently, Cogep, NRG and the various convicted individuals were admitted to trial. The legal proceedings ended in March 2009 when the Court adopted its final decision, the first one in Europe of this kind with regard to the Oil for Food scandal.The court condemned three involved individuals to two years of imprisonment. In addition, the Court debarred them from participating in public tenders for one year and ordered confiscation of the amounts previously seized.  The court rejected the individuals' argument that their crime was merely to violate U.N. sanctions, instead finding them guilty under Italy's anti-bribery laws.Cogep and NRG have not been condemned due to the application of statute of limitations.The three individual defendants appealed the decision and, according to press reports on 16 April 2010, the convictions were overturned and the EUR 1.2 million fine returned to the accused.

On 25 May 1989, Napco pleaded guilty to a three-count information charging it with conspiracy to violate the FCPA, substantive violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery and books and records provisions and aiding and assisting in the filing of false corporate tax returns.  The company was ordered to pay a USD 785,000 criminal fine.  It was also ordered to make restitution in the amount of USD 140,000 for full payment of its civil tax liability to the Defense Security Assistance Agency, to be credited toward the Foreign Military Sales account of the Republic of Niger.Napco was also required to make USD 75,000 in restitution to the Internal Revenue Service for full payment of all criminal and civil tax liabilities, interest and penalties. In late 1991, Liebo was convicted of one count of aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions and one count of making a false statement to the Defense Security Assistance Agency.  On 28 January 1992, he was sentenced to 18 months in prison.  In the end, Liebo only served two of the 18 months, having petitioned for, and eventually received, a retrial.  At the conclusion of the retrial, Liebo was convicted again and sentenced to three years probation, two months home detention and 400 hours of community service.  Separately, the DOJ charged Dornier with violating the FCPA in connection with its role as a subcontractor to Napco.  Dornier allegedly made USD 175,000 in improper payments to the Chief of Maintenance in the Niger Air Force in order to obtain over USD 3.5 million in business.  Without admitting or denying the DOJ's allegations, Dornier consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA.

Thomas Ferrell pleaded guilty in 2003 to violating the FCPA and conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  He is currently awaiting sentencing.On 5 August 2003, Bodmer was indicted on charges of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and conspiracy to engage in money laundering. In 2004, Bodmer pleaded guilty to the money laundering conspiracy charge. The court dismissed the FCPA charge because the United States did not have jurisdiction over Bodmer (a non-U.S.-resident foreign national who served as an agent of a domestic concern) at the time the  conduct occurred (prior to the 1998 amendment to the FCPA). Bodmer cooperated with the government in its investigation of Bourke, including testifying against him at trial.  As of June 2012, he was free on bail, living in Switzerland, and ostensibly awaiting sentencing.  On 7 March 2013, Bloomberg News reported that Bodmer has been sentenced to time already served in prison. U.S. District Judge Shira Scheindlin also ordered Bodmer to pay a USD 500,000 fine and forfeit USD 131,906.On 10 February 2004, Clayton Lewis pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA and conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  He testified against Bourke during trial.  His sentencing had been repeatedly pushed back as the DOJ works on bringing Kozeny to trial (at which Lewis would testify). On 4 April 2013, Bloomberg News reported that Clayton Lewis has been sentenced to time already served in prison. Lewis must also pay a fine of USD 100 for court costs.On 12 May 2005, David Pinkerton was indicted for his role in the bribery scheme. The government dropped the charges against him in July 2008 for lack of evidence.On 5 October 2005, Viktor Kozeny was arrested in the Bahamas, where he had fled in 1999.  He was released on bail in April 2007.  The United States sought Kozeny's extradition, but Kozeny won an appeal to prevent extradition in 2010.  The UK Privy Council ruled on 28 March 2012 that Kozeny, a Czech citizen, could not be extradited to the United States.On 6 July 2007, Omega Advisors entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the government for its role in the investment in the privatization program. Omega acknowledged that Clayton Lewis, one of its employees, knew of the bribery scheme prior to Omega's investment. As part of its agreement, Omega agreed to forfeit USD 500,000. On 10 July 2009, Frederic Bourke was found guilty of conspiring to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act, as well as making false statements to the FBI. Bourke was acquitted of one count of money laundering. He was sentenced to one year and one day in federal prison on 10 November 2009.  He was also ordered to pay a USD 1 million fine and serve three years of supervised release after his prison term.  Bourke has been released on bail pending appeal of his conviction.At trial, Bourke raised a number of defenses, including requesting a jury instruction on the local law defense, which states that payments that are legal under the laws of the country in which they are made cannot be prosecuted. According to Bourke's attorneys, bribe payments cannot be prosecuted in Azerbaijan if they are a result of extortion and subsequently disclosed to the government. The judge in the case rejected this argument, holding that in order for the payments to fall under the local law defense the payments themselves must be legal under local law. In this case, the bribe payments were illegal under Azeri law, even though Bourke would have been absolved from criminal liability had he faced an extortionate situation and disclosed the payments.  On 14 December 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed Frederic Bourke's 2009 conviction of conspiring to violate the FCPA and the Travel Act.  The court rejected Bourke's challenge, finding sufficient evidence to uphold both theories presented by the government that Bourke both knew of the bribes and "consciously avoided" learning about them.  The court stated that a "rational juror could conclude that Bourke deliberately avoided confirming his suspicions" and that the same evidence "may also be used to infer that Bourke actually knew about the crimes."  The court also rejected Bourke's petition for a new trial.Bourke appealed a second time, asking for an en banc review of his conviction.  He remains on bail pending a decision on this appeal.  In the second appeal, Bourke's attorneys argue based on revelations by prosecutors during the first appeal, that they knew that Hans Bodmer's testimony (which helped convict Bourke) was false, but prosecutors neither disclosed the information to Bourke's trial attorneys, nor confronted Bodmer at the trial.  This prosecutorial misconduct, claims Bourke, tainted the jury's verdict.  Specifically, Bourke's conviction was based largely on Bodmer's assertions that Bourke knew of the Azeri bribery scheme, and that he (Bodmer)  told Bourke about the scheme during a walk taken by Bourke and Bodmer in Baku on 6 February 1998; knowledge of the scheme at this date would establish Bourke's awareness prior to his investment in the venture.  But flight records in the government's possession show that Bourke was not in Baku on that date. A hearing on Bourke's appeal took place on 6 November 2012.  On 28 November 2012, the three-judge panel for the U.S. Court of Appeals issued a ruling denying  Bourke's appeal on the grounds that the district court did not abuse its discretion in denying Bourke's motion to hold an evidentiary hearing, as there was no evidence that the government's witness committed perjury. On 25 October 2012, Bourke filed a petition for a writ of certiorari with the United States Supreme Court. On 15 April 2013, the Supreme Court denied the petition.

On 23 March 1990, Mr. Gurin pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  On 23 May 1990, he was sentenced to five years of probation and 100 hours of community service.On 10 April 1990, Mr. Guasch pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  On 11 June 1990, he was sentenced to four years probation, one month of house arrest and 75 hours of community service.   Duran pleaded not-guilty to a one count indictment charging him with conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  His defense was premised on the argument that Mr. Duran did not intend any improper payments under the FCPA but, rather, that he intended to make facilitating or expediting payments to secure the performance of a routine government action.  Following the court's exclusion of evidence related to Mr. Pou, who had fled the U.S., Mr. Duran was acquitted.  Mr. Pou became a fugitive.  On 6 November 1990, the court ordered the forfeiture of a USD 50,000 personal surety bond made by Mr. Pou and a USD 50,000 corporate surety bond made by the American Bankers Insurance Company of Florida.

On May 29, 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, UIC consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order enjoining it from future violations of the books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA. In addition, UIC was required to pay a total of $337,679.42 in penalties, including $267,571 in disgorgement and $70,108.42 in pre-judgment interest.  In its complaint, the SEC noted that Wurzel and ACL did not submit the necessary due diligence forms prior to engaging the agent even though UIC had instituted policies in 1999 requiring that any employee who wanted to use a foreign agent needed to submit such forms to corporate counsel. Instead, ACL did not conduct due diligence on the Egyptian agent until 2002, after he had allegedly been working on behalf of ACL for over seven years. In addition, the agentâ€™s agreement allegedly did not have the required FCPA clauses until 2003, even though UIC required these provisions to be included in all agreements with foreign agents as early as 1997.  On the same day, Wurzel, without admitting or denying the charges, consented to the entry of a final judgment enjoining him from committing and from aiding and abetting violations anti-bribery provisions and the books and records provisions of the FCPA. He was also required to pay a $35,000 civil penalty.

In 1990, Young & Rubicam pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA, but conceded that there was no evidence that Abrahams ever received any payments.  After this admission, the government dropped the FCPA and Racketeering and Corrupt Organizations Act ("RICO") charges against Klein, Spangenberg, Foote, Abrahams and McKenna. Young & Rubicam paid a USD 500,000 criminal fine. In 1992, Abrahams filed suit against Young & Rubicam for RICO violations, violations of the Connecticut Unfair Trade Practices Act, intentional infliction of emotional distress, negligence and defamation. He claimed that the widespread dissemination of his role in the bribery scheme injured his reputation and his emotional, financial, political and social status. He also sought damages for the loss of his consulting bridges as a result of the charges. The case was dismissed by the court.

United KingdomThe SFO opened an investigation into Al Yamamah sales to Saudi government in July 2004. It is understood that by 2005 concern had been expressed by UK government officials as to the impact that the investigation was having on national security because of the deterioration in relations with Saudi Arabia due to the investigation. It was thought that as the investigation progressed that the continued deterioration in the UK/Saudi relations could have resulted in the Saudi authorities deciding not to cooperate with the UK in the fight against terrorism. The difficulties with the Saudi authorities increased as the investigation progressed and greatly increased with an attempt by the SFO to gain access to Swiss bank accounts to see if payments had been made by BAE to any agent or public official of Saudi Arabia. The Director of the SFO ("the Director") was informed of the increasing difficulties with the Saudi authorities. He took advice from other officials and met on three occasions with the UK's Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. On 14 December 2006, the Director decided that the Al Yamamah investigation should be terminated because of the "need to safeguard national and international security."  The SFO denied that there were any commercial grounds for calling off the probe.The Director's decision was challenged by two not-for-profit organizations.  In a judgment given on 10 April 2008, the UK High Court found that the Director's decision to discontinue the investigation of the alleged corruption was unlawful. This was largely due to the fact that the High Court found that the Director had succumbed to threats made by Saudi officials.  The Court found that the Director was required to act independently and his actions should be independent of any influence either from the UK government or from threats issued by foreign government.  The Director appealed the matter to the House of Lords, which was then the final court of appeal for cases in England and Wales.  The House of Lord's judgment was published on 30 July 2008 and, in summary, held that the Director's decision was not unlawful as the polycentric character of the official decision making did not make it susceptible to judicial review.  It was not within either the constitutional function nor the practical competence of the Court to assess the merit of the decision made by the Director.  The person to whom the power to make a decision had been delegated had been given decision-making powers that were very broad and on unprescribed terms.  During the investigation allegations had been made against a number of individuals connected with BAE; it is presumed that the UK investigation into those associated allegations came to an end with the conclusion of the main Al Yamamah investigation.With regard to the SFO investigation into BAE's activities in Central and Eastern Europe and Africa, in the fall of 2009 the SFO had, after giving BAE a deadline in which to come to an agreement with the SFO, made a public announcement that it intended to seek the Attorney General's consent to prosecute BAE.  It was not clear from the press statement when papers were to be submitted to the Attorney General.  In the end, no prosecution occurred.  On 5 February 2010 the SFO announced that it has reached a settlement with BAE to end the long-running investigation into alleged bribery.  Under the settlement, BAE will plead guilty in the Crown Court to violating Section 221 of the Companies Act 1985 by failing to keep reasonably accurate accounting records in connection with commission payments made to a former marketing adviser that assisted the company in selling a radar system to the Tanzanian government in 1999.  The company agreed to pay a penalty of GBP 30 million (approximately USD 47 million), comprising a fine to be determined by the Crown Court and the balance to be made as a charitable donation for the benefit of Tanzania.  On 21 December 2010, Southwark Crown Court approved the plea agreement between BAE and the SFO, sentencing BAE to pay a GBP 500,000 (USD 775,000) fine, plus GBP 225,000 in costs incurred by the SFO.  BAE will make an ex gratia payment of GBP 29.5 million for the benefit of the people of Tanzania, through a mechanism yet to be determined.  This brings to an end the SFO's six-year investigation into foreign bribery allegations connected to BAE's defense contracts.  On 29 January 2010, the SFO had charged Count Alfons Mensdorff-Pouilly with conspiracy to corrupt, contrary to section 1 of the Criminal Law Act 1977, in connection with his role as a BAE agent in Central and Eastern Europe between 2002 and 2008.  Following the SFO's settlement with BAE on February 5, the SFO announced that its charges against Mensdorff-Pouilly would be withdrawn.  Mensdorff-Pouilly is still under investigation by Austrian prosecutors and may still face charges there.  On 15 March 2012, the SFO, BAE, and the Department for International Development (DFID) signed a Memorandum of Understanding, requiring BAE to pay GBP 29.5 million plus accrued interest for educational projects in Tanzania.  The sum will be used to purchase the following goods and services:  textbooks for all 16,000 primary schools in the country (benefiting 8.3 million children); teachers' guides and syllabi for 175,000 primary school teachers; desks for schools in nine of the neediest districts (GBP 5 million).  The Director of the Serious Fraud Office, Richard Alderman, expressed satisfaction at the arrangement, saying, "This agreement is a first for the SFO which piloted it through the UK legal system. It provides a satisfactory outcome for all concerned but most of all for the Tanzanian people and I am personally delighted that SFO staff were able to achieve this."United StatesOn 5 February 2010, BAE also reached a settlement with the U.S. Department of Justice (â€œDOJâ€ù).  Under the settlement, BAE agreed to plead guilty to one charge of conspiring to make false statements to the U.S. government in connection with certain regulatory filings and undertakings.  The Company agreed to pay a USD 400 million fine and to make additional commitments concerning its ongoing compliance.  The DOJ settlement covers misconduct related to BAE's business activities in multiple countries, including the company's involvement in Sweden's lease of Gripen fighter jets to the Czech Republic and Hungary in the late 1990s, as well as the company's "Al Yamamah" sales of Tornado aircraft and other defense materials to Saudi Arabia between the mid-1980s and early 2000s.According to the criminal information, from 2000 BAE agreed to and knowingly and willfully made certain false, inaccurate and incomplete statements to the U.S. government and failed to honor certain undertakings given to the U.S. government, as follows: (i) BAE agreed to create and implement policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the FCPA and OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, which it failed to comply with; (ii) BAE made false, inaccurate and incomplete statements to the U.S. government with regard to certain regulatory requirements, including applications for arms export licenses under the Arms Export Control Act ("AECA") and the International Traffic in Arms Regulations ("ITAR").  BAE failed to follow-through on commitments made to the Department of Defense and the DOJ in 2000 regarding the company's anti-bribery compliance program, as demonstrated by the company's internal controls failures that allowed substantial payments to third party "marketing advisers" around the world to go under-scrutinized.  Many of these payments were made through offshore shell entities and in circumstances where there was a high probability that a portion of the payments were being passed on to foreign officials to secure business for BAE.  The company took various measures to conceal its relationships with certain of these advisers and its undisclosed payments to them, including by maintaining the adviser contracts and related materials in secretive legal trusts in offshore locations.  According to the criminal information, after making representations to the U.S. government regarding its anti-bribery compliance program in 2000, BAE made payments of over GBP 135 million and USD 14 million to certain of its marketing advisers through an offshore entity in the British Virgin Islands.BAE also made false statements to the Department of State by failing to disclose commission payments made to third parties who assisted in the sale of defense articles abroad.  With regard to the lease of Saab Gripen fighter jets by the Swedish government to the Czech Republic and Hungary - for which BAE provided various marketing services - the company caused false statements to be made in export license applications.  BAE made over GBP 19 million to an individual to help promote the deals in circumstances where there was a high probability that part of the payments would be used to favor BAE in the tender process.  BAE did not subject these payments to proper review and scrutiny and caused the Swedish government to omit the payments in its export license applications made to the Department of State.   Finally, the criminal information also discusses a series of undisclosed payments made to Saudi officials in connection with BAE's sale of Tornado aircraft and other defense materials under the "Al Yamamah" arrangement between the UK and Saudi governments since the mid-1980's.  Over the course of the arrangement, BAE provided substantial benefits to one key Saudi official (believed to be Prince Bandar bin Sultan) and his associates, for which no adequate review, verification or due diligence was conducted.  Such benefits included over USD 5 million in invoices submitted between May 2001 and early 2002 for travel, lodging, security services, real estate, automobiles and personal items.  BAE also used intermediaries and shell entities to conceal various payments to certain advisers that assisted in securing contracts related to the Saudi fighter deal.  Between May 2001 and early 2002, BAE transferred over GBP 10 million and over USD 9 million to a Swiss bank account controlled by an intermediary in circumstances demonstrating a high probability that the intermediary would transfer a part of the sums to the key Saudi official.  According to the criminal information, the various false statements made to the U.S. government resulted in a USD 200 million gain for BAE.  On 1 March 2010, BAE formally pleaded guilty as planned in the U.S. District Court in the District of Columbia, with the court approving the DOJ settlement and sentencing the company to pay a USD 400 million criminal fine. Under the terms of the plea agreement, BAE agreed to retain an independent compliance monitor for a three year term to assess the company's compliance program.  The monitor was to be retained within 90 days of the agreement, but BAE missed this deadline due to disagreements with the DOJ over the candidates put forward.  On 4 June 2010, the court granted BAE a 90-day extension for appointing a monitor.  In August, BAE finally appointed British attorney David Gold of Herbert Smith LLP as its corporate monitor.  In a related export controls enforcement action, on 16 May 2011, BAE entered into a Consent Agreement with the US Department of State's Directorate of Defense Trade Controls (DDTC) related to 2,591 ITAR violations.  BAE agreed to pay USD 79 million in civil penalties and to undertake extensive remedial compliance measures over a 4 year period.  Three non-US BAE affiliates were barred from receiving export licenses.  The case is unique in that it involves violations by a non-US person of ITAR Part 129 (brokering provisions) and Part 130 violations due to a failure to submit reports of commissions paid.  AustriaThe Vienna Prosecution Office investigated the case against Alfons Mensdorff-Pouilly and eventually brought charges against the Count for acting as a middleman for BAE to pay 12.6 million euros in bribes in order to obtain contracts for the sale of weapons systems in Central and Eastern Europe.On 17 January 2013, Mensdorff-Pouilly was acquitted, as the prosecution had not proved the money laundering and perjury charges that had been brought.  The prosecutor noted that he had declined to bring bribery charges because of lack of proof regarding the recipients of the bribes.South AfricaAccording to press reports on 15 October 2010, South African authorities had closed their decade-long investigation into BAE's alleged bribery of South African officials in connection with sales of fighter jets and other defense equipment.  The investigation would have reportedly taken at least another five years to complete and was not in the best interests of the public, according to Anwa Dramat, the head of the Hawks investigative unit in the National Prosecuting Authority.According to press reports on 15 September 2011, President Zuma will be setting up a commission of inquiry to look into the broader scandal.

United StatesOn 29 May 2013, Total settled its FCPA charges with the SEC and DOJ for a combined amount of USD 398.2 million. Total agreed with the SEC to pay USD 153 million in disgorgement, and its agreement with the DOJ required it to pay a criminal penalty of USD 245.2 million. The DOJ charged Total with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA, one count of violating the FCPA's books and records provisions, and one count of violating the FCPA's internal controls provisions. The SEC charged Total with violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions, books and records provisions, and internal controls provisions. According to a press release issued by the DOJ, the French authorities cooperated with the SEC and DOJ, representing "the first coordinated action by French and U.S. law enforcement in a major foreign bribery case."FranceThe Company's activities in Iraq under the United Nations Oil-for-Food Program had been subject to a French criminal investigation since 2002.  On 6 April 2010, Total confirmed that corruption charges had been instituted against the Company on 22 February 2010.  Regarding the Iran allegations, Total's SEC Form 20-F from 26 March 2012 reveals that "TOTAL and its Chief Executive Officer, President of the Middle East at the time of the facts, have been placed under formal investigation, following a judicial inquiry initiated in France in 2006."  Total's Chief Executive Officer, Christophe de Margerie, who was formerly President of the Group's Exploration & Production Division, was placed under formal investigation in October 2006.  The criminal investigation was closed in 2007 and the matter was transferred to the Prosecutor's Office.  In 2009, the Prosecutor's Office recommended dismissing the case for the CEO and all of the Group's current and former employees.  In late 2009 a new Investigating Judge, Serge Tournaire, placed Total under formal investigation for bribery of a foreign public official, complicity and benefiting from influence peddling. The Company's Form 20-F submitted to the SEC on 26 March 2012 provides the following chronology of the events:"In 2009, the Prosecutor's office recommended to the investigating judge that the case against the Group's current and former employees and TOTAL's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer not be pursued.  In early 2010, despite the recommendation of the Prosecutor's office, a new investigating judge, having taken over the case, decided to indict TOTAL S.A. on bribery charges as well as complicity and influence peddling. The indictment was brought eight years after the beginning of the investigation without any new evidence being introduced."In October 2010, the Prosecutor's office recommended to the investigating judge that the case against TOTAL S.A., the Group's current and former employees and TOTAL's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer not be pursued. However, by ordinance notified in early August 2011, the investigating judge on the matter decided to send the case to trial."On 21 January 2013, the trial against Total, Christophe de Margerie, and 17 other defendants began before the 11e Chambre du Tribunal Correctionnel in Paris.  The trial lasted until 20 February 2013. The Wall Street Journal reported on 29 May 2013 that prosecutors in France recommended that Total and de Margerie be sent to trial for corruption and embezzlement.On 8 July 2013, a French court acquitted Total, its chief executive, Christophe de Margerie, former government minister, Charles Pasqua, and more than a dozen other defendants of corruption charges. The court ruled there had been "no corruption, influence-peddling or misuse of assets" linked to the $64 billion UN program that allowed Iraq to sell limited quantities of oil to buy humanitarian supplies, even though the nation was under sanctions at the time.On 25 November 2014,  the Paris prosecutor's office announced that Total will face trial in France over claims of corruption related to Iranian contracts dating from the 1990s and early 2000s.ItalyThe Financial Times reported on 17 December 2008 that Italian authorities arrested three Total employees as part of a bribery investigation of Total's Tempa Rossa (Gorgoglione) oilfield concession. Among these employees were the French head of operations for Total Italia, Lionel Levha, and two Italian employees of the subsidiary. Authorities also searched two Total Italia offices. Multiple Italian politicians and businessmen were also arrested or are facing investigations of bribery allegations in relation to the oilfield concession. Among these was the former head of the Tempa Rossa concession, Jean Paul Juguet, for whom an arrest warrant was issued.In its Form 20-F submitted to the SEC on 26 March 2012, Total provided the following information regarding the investigation being conducted by the Prosecutor of the Republic of the Potenza Court: "On February 16, 2009, as a preliminary measure before the proceedings go before the Court, the preliminary investigation judge of Potenza served notice to Total Italia of a decision that would suspend the concession for this field for one year. Total Italia has appealed the decision by the preliminary investigation judge before the Court of Appeal of Potenza. In a decision dated April 8, 2009, the Court reversed the suspension of the Gorgoglione concession and appointed for one year, i.e. until February 16, 2010, a judicial administrator to supervise the operations related to the development of the concession, allowing the Tempa Rossa project to continue."The criminal investigation was closed in the first half of 2010. The preliminary hearing judge, who will decide whether the case shall be returned to the Criminal Court to be judged on the merits, held the first hearing on December 6, 2010."In its Form 20-F submitted to the SEC on 28 March 2013, Total added that "[i]n May 2012, the Judge of the preliminary hearing decided to dismiss the charges for some of the Groupâ€™s employees and refer the case for trial on a reduced number ofcharges. The trial started on September 26, 2012." The trial appears to be ongoing.

The French authorities' investigation was closed in 2008 due to lack of evidence.  On May 3, 2010, a Paris-based International Court of Arbitration under the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) ordered Thales to pay approximately USD 591 million in damages (including interest and legal expenses) to the Taiwanese government.  While Thales (Thomson-CSF at the time) spearheaded the deal, French state-owned shipbuilder DCN held the main stake in the contract and the French government guaranteed the contract. In June 2011, the Paris Court of Appeals ruled that Thales was obligated to make the payment awarded by the arbitration court, now amounting to 630 million euros (USD 913 million).  Thales announced that it would not appeal the ruling.  The French government will reportedly contribute 72.5% of the payment.

The AFP reportedly closed its investigation in August 2009.  ASIC has slowly made progress in its civil cases against former AWB directors.Lindberg ProsecutionOn 31 May 2012, ASIC announced "a significant milestone" in its case against Andrew Alexander Lindberg, former Managing Director of AWB.  At a hearing, Lindberg admitted to four violations of the Corporations Act of 2001 arising out of the organization's supply of wheat under the Oil-for-Food Program and in the subsequent investigation by AWB.The four violations acknowledged by Lindberg are described in an ASIC press release:   Allegations had been made publicly regarding the Iraq transactions, leading to the commencement of Project Rose, the code name for AWB's internal investigation into AWB's wheat exports to Iraq, in June 2003.  The investigation covered sales between 1999 and 2002, including inland transport of wheat within Iraq.  Lindberg's first admitted contravention was his failure to inform the Project Rose investigators that the information they needed might be accessible through interviews with former, not current, AWB employees and the former Chairman, and that these individuals had not been interviewed. Lindberg's second contravention is the failure to ascertain whether AWB's decision to help the Tigris Petroleum Corporation Limited to recover a debt owed to it by the Iraqi Grains Board violated UN Security Council resolutions, and whether the UN knew of the plan to help Tigris recover the debt.The third contravention acknowledged by Lindberg is that he knew that AWB had been paid an inflated price designed to cover the Tigris debt, from a UN escrow account.  Moreover, a December 2004 agreement between AWB and Tigris failed to reveal that AWB had helped Tigris recover its debt in exchange for a USD 500,000 fee, showing instead that Tigris had rendered services to help procure contracts for the sale of AWB wheat to Iraq, and that AWB would pay a USD 7,087,202 "service fee" to Tigris.  This was the amount payable to Tigris after the deduction of the USD 500,000.  The agreement described the USD 500,000 as a "success fee."  Lindberg's fault was in his failure to inform the AWB that the USD 8 million Tigris debt had been recovered from UN accounts through the inflation of sales prices for AWB wheat.  Lindberg also failed to reveal the existence of the Tigris agreement.The fourth contravention acknowledged by Lindberg is that he was on the conference call for a meeting with AWB's in-house and external lawyers on 20 February 2005, at which reference was made to allegations that AWB paid a 10% mark-up to the IGB through Alia;  furthermore, Lindberg was present at a meeting with the attorneys at which the 10% mark-up was questioned specifically and in detail.  Eight days later, on 28 February 2005, Lindberg was interviewed by investigators representing the UN Independent Inquiry Committee ("IIC").  He was specifically informed that the Iraqi Minister of Trade had told the IIC that all suppliers under the OFFP had paid kickbacks to the Iraqi government, that AWB was the biggest supplier, that it always paid a 10% "after sales service" fee through Alia.  And yet, between February and September 2005, Lindberg did not inform the AWB board of the information conveyed to him by the IIC, and the serious allegations therein.Mr. Lindberg agreed to a fine of AUD 100,000 and disqualification from managing corporations until 15 September 2014.  The Supreme Court of Victoria entered the order confirming this sentence on 9 August 2012.  The judge noted that Lindberg's  "contraventions did not involve deliberate wrongful acts, dishonesty or any moral turpitude but that Mr Lindberg had nonetheless 'failed to perform his duties as a reasonable director or officer would in his situation.'"Ingleby ProsecutionOn 13 June 2012, a second AWB defendant admitted to breach of fiduciary duty.  In a civil action brought by ASIC against former AWB CFO Paul John Ingleby, violations of section 180(1) of the Corporations Act of 2001 were confirmed.  Ingleby acknowledged that between December 2001 and September 2004, he knew that AWB's trade was conducted under the OFFB, which prohibited direct payments to the Iraqi government.  He nevertheless co-authorized payments to the Jordanian trucking company, Alia for Transportation, despite having information available to raise questions as to the legitimacy of these fees, and furthermore took no steps to ascertain whether indeed payments were being made to the government of Iraq.  On 10 August 2012, the judge found Ingelby in contravention of Section 180(1) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Corporations Act) and ordered that he be disqualified from managing corporations until 31 December 2012 and pay a pecuniary penalty of AUD 10,000.  The penalty was less severe than anticipated, as both ASIC and Mr Ingleby had recommended  a disqualification of 15 months and apenalty of AUD 40,000.   On 27 August 2012, ASIC filed a notice of appeal against the court's judgment, claiming (1) that the penalties it had recommended were within the range of penalties appropriate to Ingleby's contravention, and (2) Ingleby had agreed that such penalties were appropriate, in the joint statement he signed and submitted, with ASIC, to the court.Other ProsecutionsASIC's proceedings against the four other named former officers of AWB are ongoing.

United States In February 2009 Halliburton and KBR settled FCPA charges related to its involvement in the scheme, resulting in USD 579 million in combined penalties.  The DOJ and SEC have been investigating other joint venture partners since.  On 12 February 2010, Technip announced in its fourth quarter earnings release that the company had reserved EUR 245 million for an exceptional charge related to a potential settlement of FCPA offenses with the DOJ and SEC in connection with its role in the TSKJ joint venture in Nigeria (subject of the Halliburton/KBR settlement in February 2009).  According to Technip, the EUR 245 million reflects the estimated costs of resolution of the matter based on the current status of the ongoing discussions.  The company stated that it did not expect a criminal conviction for its role in the joint venture.On 28 June 2010, the Department of Justice filed a deferred prosecution agreement and two-count information against Technip in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas, charging the company with one count of conspiracy and one count of violating the FCPA.  Under the terms of the two-year deferred prosecution agreement, Technip agreed to pay a USD $240 million criminal fine, to retain an independent compliance monitor for a two-year period, and to cooperate with the DOJ in its ongoing investigations.On the same day, Technip reached a settlement of a related civil complaint with the SEC.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Technip agreed to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions.  Technip agreed to pay USD 98 million in disgorgement of profits and pre-judgment interest.  NigeriaThe press reported that Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission ("EFCC") had arrested ten Halliburton employees in Nigeria during a raid of the offices of Halliburton Energy Services Nigeria Limited in Lagos on 25 November 2010.   The EFCC also arrested one employee each from Saipem Contracting Nigeria and Technip Offshore Nigeria.  On 7 December 2010, the EFCC reportedly filed corruption charges against Halliburton, former U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney (who was the CEO of Halliburton during the period at issue), Albert Stanley (former CEO of KBR), David Lesar (current CEO of Halliburton) and William Utt (current CEO of KBR).  Technip, Snamprogetti and JGC Corp. were reportedly also charged on the same day.  The case number is Federal Republic of Nigeria v. Halliburton and others, CV/435/10, High Court of Justice, Abuja Judicial Division (Abuja).According to press reports, on 15 December 2010, Halliburton and the EFCC reached a USD $250 million settlement agreement to resolve the charges.  Halliburton will pay USD $120 million in penalties and USD $130 million in frozen assets in Switzerland will be repatriated to Nigeria.  In exchange, Nigeria dropped the charges.  Former U.S. President George H. W. Bush and former Secretary of State James Baker reportedly assisted with the negotiations.  On 20 December 2010, Saipem announced that Snamprogetti had entered into a settlement agreement and non-prosecution agreement with the Federal Government of Nigeria to resolve the investigation.  Snamprogetti agreed to the payment of a criminal penalty of USD $30 million, along with USD $2.5 million in reimbursement for legal costs and expenses incurred by the Nigerian authorities.  Nigeria agreed to dismiss all charges against Snamprogetti and to renounce to any civil claims and criminal charges in any jurisdiction.FranceAccording to several news sources, on 30 January 2013, Technip's former General Manager, Jean-Marie Deseilligny, was found guilty by a Paris court in relation to the Bonny Island affair and ordered to pay a EUR 10,000 fine.  That same day, Technip's former commercial manager for Africa, Etienne Gory, was sentenced by the Paris court to a EUR 5,000 fine.  These fines fell short of the EUR 100,000 fine that prosecutors had reportedly requested.African Development BankOn 21 March 2014, the African Development Bank levied a USD $5.3 million fine against Technip for corrupt practices in connection to contracts for natural gas production plants on Bonny Island, Nigeria from 1995 until 2004.

United NationsAccording to a 2 May 2008 article in the New Zealand Herald, Radiola's managing director Brent Albiston said that "[w]e were suspended while the UN was conducting its investigations and we can confirm we have since been reinstated and are now an approved supplier." New ZealandOn 22 October 2008, the Serious Fraud Office issued a letter to Radiola stating that the office had found no evidence of fraud or corruption and was closing the file.

Norconsult was "offered", as an employer, a settlement deal under which it would pay a penalty of NOK 4 million.  On November 20, 2009, the company declined the settlement and has stated that it will contest the charges.  The trial started in May 2011.  In a press release on May 9, 2011, Norconsult reiterated its denial of any wrongdoing. In the township court, Norconsult was acquitted, but on appeal, the court found Norconsult guilty of corruption and bribery in 2012.In the appeal court, one of the employees was acquitted, and the fine upheld for the company. The appeal court rated the legal circumstances different from the town court. They considered the corruptive actions to be considerable, and found without reasonable doubt that one or more employees had participated in illegal payments for about 100 000 USD on behalf of Norconsult. The main reasons for the appeal court to convict Norconsult for grand corruption was the following: It was documented an organized bribery system in a poor country and by that general deterrence considerations was relevant. There was lack of preventive measures related to anti-corruption in Norconsult. There was no specific anticorruption policy or guidelines for the employees in order to deal with corruptive issues.  The project was documented to be important for Norconsult, even if there was a deficit in the project. Norconsult did not allow internal and external investigation reports to be documented for the authorities, and there was an internal struggle in order to report the matter to the authorities. If the top management not was informed of the illegal payments, this was not of major significance due to lack of reporting.
The investigations may still be ongoing, but no further information about the matter has been identified since late 2008.
The case appears to have closed.  No further information has been located.
It appears that the corruption investigation was closed without action.

ItalyIn February 2003, the Milan District Attorney's Office initiated a criminal investigation against Enelpower's top executives, among others, for alleged offenses of criminal conspiracy, bribery, embezzlement and false accounting.In connection with the same investigation, on 5 March 2003 Enelpower was served an "avviso di garanzia" informing that the company was under investigation for alleged administrative responsibilities pursuant to article 25 of Legislative Decree no. 231/2001.On 16 January 2008, a preliminary hearing was held, following which the judge responsible for preliminary inquiries granted the request of Enelpower to be recognized as injured parties. The case is continuing and subsequent hearings have yet to be scheduled.  Recently, after a long preliminary investigation phase, Luigi Giuffrida was committed to trial.Private SuitEnel Group started legal action against the suppliers involved, which led to settlements also with the agent Emirates Holdings.State Audit CourtBased on the information that emerged during the criminal proceedings, the State Audit Court ("Corte dei Conti"), which has jurisdictional power to act against civil servants for damages caused to the State or other public bodies, sued Luigi Giuffrida and Gabriele Caressa, for damages caused, among others, by their above illicit behavior. In a ruling of 22 February 2006, the State Audit Court, finding that the former directors and managers cited in the suit were liable, awarded Enelpower damages in the amount of about EUR 14 million. The ruling was appealed by the State Audit Court - Lombardy Section and the former directors and managers. On 3 December 2008, the Central Jurisdictional Appeals Section of the State Audit Court issued ruling no. 532/2008, which amended part of the first ruling and condemned the former directors and managers to refund around EUR 22 million as damages. In particular, Luigi Giuffrida and Gabriele Caressa have to pay damages in the amount of EUR 5,830,478.44 in connection with the Middle East contracts. The ruling also confirmed the seizure of assets of the appellants ordered by the Regional Public Prosecutor and sentenced them to pay court costs for both proceedings. In February 2009 the ruling was appealed to the Court of Cassation.
No new information has been identified regarding this investigation.  It appears that it may have closed.

On 6 July 2004, the ABB Vetco Gray and ABB Vetco Gray UK pleaded guilty to charges of bribing government officials in violation of the FCPA.  Each company agreed to pay a fine of USD 5.25 million. ABB Vetco Gray UK was only the second company charged under the provisions of the FCPA that cover foreign companies that take an act in furtherance of bribing a foreign official while in the territory of the United States.  The acts in question included making improper payments to U.S. bank accounts and reimbursing ABB Vetco Gray for bribes paid to Nigerian officials.   On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, ABB consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from committing future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions. ABB was required to pay a total of USD 16.4 million in penalties, including USD 5.9 million in disgorgement of profits and a USD 10.5 million civil penalty. The SEC also required ABB to retain an independent consultant to review the company's FCPA compliance policies and procedures.  In a related case, on 5 July 2006, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Samson, Munro, Campbell and Whelan consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining each of them from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions. In addition, Samson was ordered to pay a USD 50,000 civil penalty and USD 64,674 in disgorgement and pre-judgment interest and Campbell and Munro were each required to pay a USD 40,000 civil penalty.  On 6 February 2007, Vetco Gray UK, Vetco Gray Controls and Vetco Gray Controls, Ltd. pleaded guilty to violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions and conspiracy to violate the FCPA. The companies were required to pay a combined criminal fine of USD 26 million, broken out as follows: Vetco Gray Controls - USD 6 million; Vetco Gray Controls, Ltd. - USD 8 million; and Vetco Gray UK - USD 12 million. In addition, the companies were required to appoint an independence compliance monitor; undertake a complete investigation of the companies' conduct in other countries, as promised under Opinion Procedure Release 04-02; and ensure that any sale of the companies binds the purchaser to comply with the monitoring and investigating obligations. On the same date, Aibel entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the government for its role in the bribery scheme. The DOJ agreed not prosecute Aibel if it complied with the terms of the agreement. On 21 November 2008, Aibel pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA and one substantive count of violating the FCPA and was required to pay a USD 4.2 million criminal fine. According to the DOJ, Aibel had not complied with the terms of its deferred prosecution agreement.

On 1 July 2005, both Kay and Murphy were sentenced to prison for violating the FCPA. Kay was sentenced to 3 years and 1 month in prison and was ordered to pay USD 1,300 in criminal penalties. Murphy was sentenced to 5 years and 3 months in prison and was ordered to pay USD 1,400 in criminal penalties. In 2004, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed a 2002 lower court ruling that had dismissed the charges against the defendants. The lower court had ruled that the FCPA did not prohibit bribes to foreign officials that were intended to reduce customs duties. The decision turned on language in the FCPA that prohibits bribes that are made for the purpose of "obtaining or retaining business for or with, or directing business to, any person." Based on this language, the lower court determined that the FCPA was only intended to prohibit bribes made to obtain specific foreign government contracts. The Fifth Circuit disagreed with the lower court's holding that as a matter of law, bribes to reduce foreign tax and customs obligations were not prohibited by the FCPA and concluded that such bribes could in certain circumstances violate the act. On 6 October 2004, a jury found defendant Murphy guilty of 12 counts of violating the FCPA, one count of a conspiracy to violate the FCPA and one count of obstruction of justice. Defendant Kay was found guilty of 12 counts of violating the FCPA and one count of a conspiracy to violate the FCPA. Kay and Murphy appealed their convictions based on arguments that the court retroactively enlarged the scope of the statute so that the defendants were not given fair notice that the conduct in which they engaged could be prosecuted under the FCPA. Part of their argument was that the statute was unconstitutionally vague as to the definition of "obtain or retain business." On 24 October 2007, the Fifth Circuit rejected the defendants' arguments, stating that while the term "obtain or retain business" was ambiguous it did not rise to the level of being unconstitutionally vague.
