The Fifth Circuit denied Kay and Murphy's petition for a rehearing en banc on 10 January 2008, and the Supreme Court denied their petition for cert on 6 October 2008. Murphy is currently serving out his sentence at the Federal Correctional Institution in El Reno, Texas. Kay is serving his sentence at Texarkana.   On 1 August 2002, the SEC filed a civil action, requesting that the court permanently enjoin Kay, Murphy and Theriot from committing future violations of the anti-bribery, books and records and internal control provisions of the FCPA.  In addition, the SEC requested that Kay and Murphy each pay USD 187,000 civil penalty.  On 7 January 2005, Theriot consented to the entry of a final judgment without admitting or denying the allegations. The SEC's civil actions against Kay and Murphy are still pending. On 30 January 2003, American Rice, Joseph Schwartz, and Joel Malebranche Allen Sturdivant consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order permanently enjoining them from committing future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.

On 4 June 2007, Jefferson was indicted on 16 counts including conspiracy to solicit bribes by a public official, conspiracy to commit wire fraud and conspiracy to violate the FCPA; solicitation of bribes by a public official; wire fraud; violations of the FCPA; money laundering; obstruction of justice; and racketeering.  On 5 August 2009, Jefferson was convicted of 11 counts, including conspiracy to solicit bribes by a public official, conspiracy to deprive citizens of honest services by wire fraud, and conspiracy to violate the FCPA; conspiracy to solicit bribes by a public official; solicitation of bribes; wire fraud; money laundering and racketeering.  Jefferson was acquitted of substantive FCPA violation, several counts of wire fraud and obstruction of justice.  Although Jefferson was convicted on count one of the indictment, which included conspiracy to violate the FCPA, it is impossible to determine whether the jury found that he actually did conspire to violate the FCPA. Count one listed three separate conspiracies, including conspiracy to solicit bribes and conspiracy to deprive citizens of honest services. The judge instructed the jury that in order for them to find Jefferson guilty of count one, they only needed to find that he engaged in two of the three conspiracies. The jury was not required to specify which conspiracies they believed he was guilty of. On 13 November 2009, Jefferson was sentenced to 13 years in prison. He was also ordered to forfeit USD 470,653.  He has been released on bail pending appeal of his conviction.On 26 May 2006, Pfeffer was sentenced to 96 months in prison and fined USD 24,000 for bribing a public official and aiding and abetting the solicitation of bribes by a member of Congress. He pleaded guilty to the charges on 11 January 2006.  On 8 September 2006, Jackson was sentenced to 87 months in prison and two years of supervised release. Jackson pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit bribery and bribery of a public official on 3 May 2006.

On 12 January 2004, the Huddinge District Court convicted the defendants for bribing S and B in relation to the first set of transactions described above. Fjellner was also convicted of gross false accounting. Fjellner was sentenced to one year and six months imprisonment and Karlsson was sentenced to one year imprisonment. The charges relating to R and the funds from N were dismissed.The judgment was appealed and on 1 December 2005 the Svea Court of Appeal upheld the convictions in all relevant parts.

AustraliaOn July 1, 2011, the Australian Federal Police ("AFP") charged Securency and its sister company, Note Printing Australia ("NPA"), with bribery of foreign public officials in connection with alleged bribes paid to public officials in Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam between 1999 and 2005 - through international sales agents - in order to secure banknote contracts.  Six individuals from Victoria - who previously worked for Securency or NPA as chief executives, chief financial officers or sales agents - were arrested and charged as well.  According to the AFP, the Australian arrests coincided with related bribery charges laid against two individuals in Malaysia by the Malaysian Attorney Generalâ€™s Chambers, following an investigation by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission.  The charges against Securency and NPA carry a maximum fine of AUD 330,000 per offense.  The charges against the six individuals carry a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment and/or a fine of AUD 1.1 million, under sections 11.5(1) and 70.2(1) of the Criminal Code Act 1995. On 27 October 2011, both NPA and Securency entered guilty pleas at the Melbourne Magistrateâ€™s Court to three charges each of bribing or conspiring to bribe foreign officials to obtain a business advantageOn 12 March 2012, the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) released a statement that it did not intend to prosecute  Securency International Pty Ltd and Note Printing Australia Limited, noting, "ASIC considers a range of factors when deciding to investigate and possibly take enforcement action. In line with its normal practice, ASIC has reviewed this material from the AFP for possible directorsâ€™ duty breaches of the Corporations Act and has decided not to proceed to a formal investigation. ASIC intends to make no further comment on this matter."Australia: ElleryOn 18 July 2012, David John Ellery, who served as Securencyâ€™s CFO, pleaded guilty to a charge of false accounting in relation to a AUD 79,502 payment to Kuala Lumpur arms broker Abdul Kayum Syed Ahmad.  Specifically, Ellery admitted that he created a false document to facilitate a payment to Kayum even though he knew the latter  was not entitled to it.  Ellery is one of nine individuals to have been indicted by the Australian Federal Police.  In accepting his guilty plea, the Victoria Supreme Court acknowledged Ellery's willingness to testify against the eight remaining defendants.  Ellery's counsel noted that his client had not been involved in a wider conspiracy, and falsified documents at the behest of his superiors, and even that Ellery had warned senior colleagues at Securency that Kayum was not entitled to any money from the company. Following a hearing on 18 July 2012, the Supreme Court of Victoria (Melbourne) issued a sentencing judgment on 20 August 2012.  Ellery's offenses could invoke a maximum 10 year prison sentence.  The judge went to great lengths to explain Ellery's offense and the court's reasoning.  Ellery approved a commission payment to Kayum in Malaysia of AUD 79,502.  Later, when an invoice fabricated by Kayum reflected the same amount but showed an itemized list of "expenses," Ellery forwarded it for payment.  When questioned about the "expenses" subsequently, Ellery concealed the nature of the payment.  In his favor, the judge noted that Ellery did not create the false document, did not at first wish to approve it, ultimately approved it without any idea of personal gain.  When confronted, Ellery pleaded guilty early in the proceedings, and agreed to cooperate in ongoing investigations both of Securency and NPA offenses in Malaysia and other jurisdictions.The judge therefore sentenced Ellery to 6 months' imprisonment suspended for two years, meaning that the sentence could be imposed if, at any time during the coming two years, Ellery commits another offense punishable by imprisonment.Australia: Other IndividualsAmended charge sheets were issued against 8 individuals on 14 August 2012:  Anderson, Boillot, Brady, Curtis, Gerathy, Hutchinson, Leckenby and  Marchant.  A summary of the charges follows:Mitchell Anderson â€“ Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and June 2000 in one instance, and February 2001 in another instance,  to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia.Christian Boillot and Barry Brady  â€“ Charged with conspiring between October 2001 and December 2003 to offer to provide a benefit to another person to whom such benefit was not legitimately due, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with Bank Negara Malaysia.Myles Curtis - Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and June 2000 in one instance, and February 2001 in another instance,  to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia.  Curtis is also charged with conspiring between October 2001 and December 2003 to offer to provide a benefit to another person to whom such benefit was not legitimately due, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with Bank Negara Malaysia.Curtis is also charged with conspiring between January 2001 and September 2004, and again between January and October 2003, with offering to provide a benefit to a person when not legitimately due to that person, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties, in order to obtain or retain business with the State Bank of Vietnam.Curtis is also charged with dishonestly falsifying documents made or required for an accounting purpose (by concurring in the making of a false debit note), between June and July 2006, with a view to gain for another.Clifford Gerathy - Charged with conspiring between January 2001 and September 2004, and again between January and October 2003, with offering to provide a benefit to a person when not legitimately due to that person, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties, in order to obtain or retain business with the State Bank of Vietnam.Gerathy is also charged with dishonestly falsifying documents made or required for an accounting purpose (by concurring in the making of a false debit note), between June and July 2006, with a view to gain for another.Peter Hutchinson - Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and February 2001 to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia.John Leckenby - Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and February 2001 to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia. Leckenby is also charged with conspiring between October 2001 and December 2003 to offer to provide a benefit to another person to whom such benefit was not legitimately due, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with Bank Negara Malaysia.Rognvald Marchant â€“ One charge was withdrawn.  Leckenby is charged with conspiring between January 2001 and September 2004 to provide, and again between January and October 2003, with conspiring to offer to provide a benefit to a person when not legitimately due to that person, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties, in order to obtain or retain business with the State Bank of Vietnam.Australian authorities are seeking the extradition of an Indonesian intermediary hired by the RBA, Radius Christanto, who was in custody in Singapore.   Together, Ellery and the other eight defendants are alleged to have made or authorized over AUD 1.6 million in improper payments.United KingdomOn 8 September 2012, the SFO charged William ("Bill") Lowther with one count of conspiracy to corrupt during 2003.  Lowther first appeared in court on 20 September, and pleaded not guilty at a hearing in March.  On 26 November 2012, his trial began Southwark Crown Court.At the trial, prosecutors claimed that Lowther was the driving force behind Securency, and that the company was desperate to turn a profit and pay back start-up loans.  In order to secure two dozen note printing contracts with Vietnam worth GBP 90 million, Lowther arranged to send the son of the governor of the State Bank of Vietnam to Durham Business School in Britain.  Lowther is alleged to have arranged for an interview at the school, driven Le Duc Minh, Le Duc Thuy's son, to the interview, and thereafter arranged for the payment of GBB 18,000 in tuition, in addition to GPB 3,400 for rooming expenses for Minh. Media reports dated 24 October 2012 that the SFO is also investigating corruption by Securency in certain African nations.MalaysiaThe Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) investigation -  On 1 July 2011, the MACC reported that Abdul Kayum bin Syed Ahmad, 62 years, Director of Aksavest Sdn. Bhd had been charged with having "corruptly given a gratification of RM50,000.00 to Datoâ€™ Mohamad Daud bin Dol Moin through a middleman on the 24th November 2004 at EON Bank, Jalan Taipan, Subang Jaya, Selangor as an inducement to assist Note Printing Australia Ltd to secure currency printing contracts for RM5 polymer bank notes from Bank Negara Malaysia. The second charge is for a similar offence allegedly committed on 15th February 2005 at the same venue." Likewise, another press release was issued by the MACC on the same day, noting that "Datoâ€™ Mohamad Daud bin Dol Moin was earlier charged this morning at the Special Courts for Corruption at Jalan Duta, Kuala Lumpur Court Complex on two counts of charges for accepting the gratification from the accused, Abdul Kayum bin Syed Ahmad."NigeriaMedia sources allege that on 11 January 2013, the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission of Nigeria (the EFCC) arrested Charles Chukwuma Soludo at his Abuja residence, and detained him for questioning in connection with the note printing contract with Securency.  Soludo served as the governor of the Central Bank of Nigeria between 2006 and 2008.  Media reports indicated that in addition to Soludo, 12 senior former CBN and Nigerian Security Printing and Minting Company officials were also arrested.     IndonesiaThe Indonesian investigation into the companies may be ongoing, as well as investigations in Vietnam and Nepal.
A Paris Investigating Magistrate was appointed in 2008 and the Attorney General of Paris began a preliminary investigation in July 2009.  It appears that the investigation is ongoing.

On 16 November 2009, a federal grand jury in the Southern District of Texas returned an 18-count indictment charging John Joseph O'Shea with conspiracy, violations of the FCPA, international money laundering and falsification of records in a federal investigation. O'Shea was arrested on 18 November 2009, at which time the indictment was unsealed.  For the conspiracy count and the falsification of records in a federal investigation count, separately, O'Shea faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 250,000 or twice the value gained or lost.  He faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 100,000 or twice the value gained or lost for each of the 12 FCPA counts.  For each of the four international money laundering counts, he faces a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 500,000 or twice the value of the property involved in the transaction.  The indictment also gave notice of criminal forfeiture.On 16 November 2009, Fernando Maya Basurto pleaded guilty to a one-count information charging him with conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  Under this plea agreement, he admitted that, while acting as a sales representative for the ABB Sugar Land, he conspired with others to make improper payments to CFE officials, he helped launder the monies and he engaged in a cover up to obstruct the DOJ and SEC's investigations.  He also admitted to submitting false invoices and helping to fabricate correspondence in contemplation of the government's investigations.  Basurto agreed to cooperate with the DOJ's ongoing investigation.  He faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 250,000 or twice the value gained or lost.  (Basurto was previously arrested in Dallas, Texas on 25 April 2009 in connection wtih a criminal complaint charging him with conspiracy to structure transactions and structuring transactions to evade currency reporting requirements.  He was subsequently detained and, on 10 June 2009, was indicted on those charges.)  In April 2012, Judge Hughes dismissed the original charges against Basurto, and granted the prosecution's request that Basurto's sentence not extend beyond the twenty-two months he spent in jail between his arrest in 2009 and his release on bail in July 2011.  The judge agreed to limit the sentence to "time served."  The requirement in his plea agreement that he forfeit approximately USD 2 million in illegal profits remains in place.On 29 September 2010, the SEC filed a settled civil action against ABB Ltd., charging the company with violating the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions in connection with bribes allegedly paid, through its subsidiaries, to Mexican government officials to obtain business with state-owned electric utilities, and to the former Iraqi regime to obtain contracts under the U.N. Oil-for-Food Program.  Without admitting or denying the allegations the SEC's allegations, ABB Ltd. consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA.  ABB Ltd. was ordered to pay USD 22,804,262 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest and a USD 16,510,000 civil penalty, and is also required to comply with certain undertakings regarding its FCPA compliance program.Also on 29 September 2010, ABB Ltd. and two of its subsidiaries reached settlements with the DOJ regarding the agency's criminal investigation into the matter.  At a plea hearing in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas, ABB Ltd.'s U.S. subsidiary, ABB Inc., pleaded guilty to a criminal information charging it with one count of violating the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA and one count of conspiracy to violate these provisions.  ABB Inc. was ordered to pay a criminal fine of USD 17.1 million.  ABB Ltd. itself entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to cooperate with the ongoing investigations of the DOJ and foreign authorities, as well as to various enhanced corporate compliance and reporting obligations, including the recommendations of an independent compliance consultant.  ABB Ltd. also agreed to the DOJ's filing of a criminal information charging its Jordanian subsidiary, ABB Near East Trading Ltd., with one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and to violate the FCPA's books and records provisions of the FCPA, and agreed to pay a criminal penalty of USD 1.9 million.The DOJ and ABB had originally agreed to a USD 28.1 million criminal fine.  U.S. District Court Judge Lynn Hughes, however, reduced the fine to USD 17.1 million, disagreeing with the DOJ's assessment of ABB as a recidivist company and refusing to "rubber stamp" the agency's settlements. The bribery and cover up trial against O'Shea's opened on 11 January 2012 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.   Earlier in January, Judge Lynn Hughes had denied O'Shea's motion to dismiss the indictment based on the claim that the state-owned Mexican electric company, Comision Federal de Electricidad (CFE) whose employees allegedly received payments were not "foreign officials" within the meaning of the FCPA.On 16 January 2012, the Court acquitted O'Shea of all bribery and cover-up charges, on the grounds that the evidence did not sufficiently demonstrate a link between O'Shea and the illegal conduct.  Then, on 9 February 2012, the Department of Justice filed a motion to dismiss all remaining charges against O'Shea.  The remaining charges included conspiracy, obstruction of justice and money laundering.It  is unclear what become of the Italian investigation into ABB Italy's alleged bribery of Italian officials.  While discussed in ABB's SEC Form 20-F for 2009, there is no mention of the Italian investigation in its Form 20-F for 2010 (filed on 17 March 2011).

In 2011, Johnson & Johnson paid USD $70 million to resolve criminal and civil FCPA charges arising from DePuy's overseas bribery. Johnson & Johnson's U.K. subsidiary, DePuy International Limited, separately paid Â£4.8 (USD $7,864,559.18) to settle civil corruption charges brought by the Serious Fraud Office.According to a Wall Street Journal report from 12 February 2013, Greek authorities have charged five DPI executives with bribery and money laundering stemming from allegations of over EUR 16 million in bribes paid between 1998 and 2006 to state hospital doctors in order to promote DPI products. The executives were not named.

On 10 December 2009, the public prosecution authorities at the Munich District Court imposed a EUR 75.3 million fine against MAN Nutzfahrzeuge and a EUR 75.3 million fine against MAN Turbo.  Both companies acquiesced in the decisions.  These fines mark the closure of the investigations against the companies of the MAN Group regarding the alleged bribery between 2002 and 2009.  According to MAN, the settlements were possible due to the extensive measures taken by MAN's Executive Board and Supervisory Board to conduct an internal investigation and cooperate with the public prosecution authorities.  According to press reports, on 11 December 2009, Munich prosecutors filed charged against Heinz Juergen Maus, the former chief executive of MAN Turbo, in connection with EUR 9 million in bribes - described as "market entry fees" - allegedly paid to Kazakh officials between 2005 and 2008 in order to secure a gas pipeline modernization contract and gas turbine compressor orders in Kazakhstan.  According to press reports, the CEO of MAN Diesel & Turbo, Klaus Stahlmann, resigned on 22 February 2011 and is also the target of the Munich prosecutors' investigation.On 5 September 2012, it was reported that prosecutors in Germany were investigating former Man SE Chief Executive Officer Hakan Samuelsson and former Chief Financial Officer Karlheinz Hornung for allegations of corruption.  Weinmann, Hornung and CEO Hakan Samuelsson left the company in November 2009.MAN reportedly terminated 20 employees in connection with the bribery allegations and is considering whether to sue certain former employees for damages.According to press reports, the cost of MAN's internal investigations have totaled around EUR 50 million since commencing in May 2009.On 22 August 2013, the former CEO of MAN, Hakan Samuelsson, agreed to settle a German investigation into possible corruption in Slovenia linked to his tenure by paying EU 500,000 to charity and EU 1.25 million to MAN in response to a financial claim brought by the company related to the probe.On 10 April 2014, MAN AG disclosed in the proxy materials for its annual general meeting of shareholders that the five-year old bribery scandal has cost the company â‚¬250 million (approximately USD $344 million) in fines and penalties and investigation costs, exceeding earlier estimates.

A ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems spokesperson was cited by South Africa's Mail & Guardian newspaper in June 2008 as stating that the investigation was closed without charges or penalty.  However, it appears that at least other aspects of the German investigation may be ongoing.

United StatesOn 22 March 2010, a two count criminal information was filed against Daimler in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia charging the company with one count of conspiracy to falsify its books and records and one count of violating the books and records provision of the FCPA. Two days later the government filed a deferred prosecution agreement in the case.  Under the terms of the deferred prosecution agreement, Daimler Russia and Daimler Export were to plead guilty to FCPA violations and Daimler would be required to appoint a compliance monitor for a three-year period.  In addition,  the company would be required to adopt a number of remedial measures. The deferred prosecution agreement names former FBI Director Louis Freeh as the company's preferred compliance monitor. On 1 April 2010, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, Daimler Russia and Daimler Export each pleaded guilty to criminal informations charging the companies with one count of conspiracy to violate the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA and one count of violating those provisions.  Under the plea agreements, Daimler Russia and Daimler Export agreed to pay criminal fines of USD 27.26 million and USD 29.12 million, respectively.On 25 April 2012, the Investigative Committee elected not to open cases against officials from the Defense Ministry and the Ufa administration or against employees of the companies Daimler Chrysler Avtomobili RUS, Urengoigazprom, Mashinoimport, and Dorinvest, all of whom were implicated in the case by U.S. authorities.  Press reports indicate that Russian investigators never requested  materials regarding the case from U.S. authorities, as Russian authorities had earlier indicated. Like the Russia DPA and on the same date, 1 April 2010, Daimler formally entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, per the terms described above, consenting to the filing of a criminal information charging it with one count of conspiracy to violate the books and records provisions of the FCPA and one count of violating those provisions. Daimler China also entered into a deferred prosecution agreement, consenting to the filing of a criminal information charging it with one count of conspiracy to violate the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA and one count of violating those provisions. In total, Daimler and its three subsidiaries agreed to pay USD 93.6 million in criminal fines and penalties.  The three subsidiaries are covered by the monitoring provisions of the deferred prosecution agreement entered into by Daimler. On the same day, a separate judgment was entered against Daimler resolving a related civil complaint filed by the SEC.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's charges, Daimler consented to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  Daimler agreed to pay USD 91.4 million in disgorgement of profits relating to those violations and agreed to certain remedial measures, including retaining an independent consultant for a three-year period.Under its settlement with the government, Daimler entities agreed to pay a total of USD 185 million in fines and penalties, comprising USD 93.6 million in criminal fines and USD 91.4 million in civil penalties. According to the deferred prosecution agreement, the USD 93.6 million criminal fine represents a 20 percent reduction from the lowest fine recommended by the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines due to Daimler's extensive cooperation with the investigation. RussiaAccording to reports from the Moscow Times on 29 April 2010, in early April Russian prosecutors sent a request to the DOJ requesting information about bribes paid by Daimler in Russia.  The request was apparently prompted by a personal order from President Dmitry Medvedev following a Russian internet petition signed by thousands asking the Prosecutor General's Office and the Interior Ministry to begin an investigation.  The Moscow Times on 30 April 2010 reported that Moscow City Hall had asked Daimler to "clarify the situation" regarding bribes reportedly paid to Moscow city government officials to secure sales contracts for its Mercedes vehicles.  The mayor's press secretary said that Moscow does not own any Mercedes vehicles.  City Hall considers the allegations inaccurate and Daimler could face legal action as a result.On 20 May 2010, Bloomberg reported that the DOJ had given documents to prosecutors in Moscow, prompting Russia to open a formal investigation into the matter.  On 12 November 2010, Russian prosecutors confirmed that they had opened a criminal investigation into the matter.EgyptOn 14 May 2010, several media outlets reported that the Egyptian government had also opened an investigation into Daimler's alleged payment of bribes to Egyptian officials.NigeriaAccording to press reports in June 2010, Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission ("EFCC") is also investigating the matter, looking at alleged bribery involving Daimler and Anammco, a partially state-owned Nigerian vehicle assembly company.LatviaAccording to a 15 February 2011 press release by Latvia's Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau ("KNAB"), the agency is investigating alleged bribery of Riga city officials by Daimler's subsidiary EvoBus GmbH. EvoBus, through intermediaries, allegedly paid more than EUR 4.3 million between July 2002 and December 2006 to city officials in connection with the purchase of 117 Mercedes Benz buses for the Riga municipality.  According to The Baltic Course's article from 13 June 2013, prosecutors said that the amount of bribes exceeded EUR 5 million. The KNAB  investigation is being conducted in coordination with the Stuttgart Prosecutor's Office and Baden-Wurttemberg police.On 4 November 2013, prosecutors in Latvia brought charges against six people accused of taking bribes from German vehicle-maker Daimler.  The six facing charges include Leonards Tenis, an advisor to a former mayor of Riga. The others were members of the city council.

On August 5, 2010, Joe Summers consented to the entry of a permanent injunction, enjoining him from committing future violations of the anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA. He also agreed to pay a USD 25,000 civil penalty. The SEC's complaint against Bobby Benton seeks a civil penalty, disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and injunctive relief to prevent future violations of the federal securities laws.On November 4, 2010, the DOJ filed a criminal information charging Pride with conspiring to violate the FCPA's anti-bribery and books and records provisions; violating the anti-bribery provisions; and violating the books and records provisions. The DOJ and Pride entered into a deferred prosecution agreement to resolve the charges.  The DOJ also filed a criminal information charging Pride Forasol with conspiring to violate the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions; violating the anti-bribery provisions; and aiding and abetting the violation of the books and records provisions. Pride Forasol agreed to plead guilty to the charges, which the company did on December 7, 2010 in U.S. District Court in Houston. The two agreements require the payment of a USD 32.625 million criminal penalty.  The DOJ noted that "During the course of the investigation, Pride provided information and substantially assisted in the investigation of Panalpina."Also on November 4, 2010, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Pride consented to the entry of a final judgment ordering disgorgement plus pre-judgment interest and permanently enjoining it from violating the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions.  Pride was ordered to disgorge USD 19,341,870 in profits, plus pre-judgment interest of USD 4,187,848.In the first such move ever in an FCPA case, on 2 November 2012, the government filed a motion to terminate the period of probation under the December 2010 DPA.  The government explained in its motion that since Pride's merger with Ensco plc, the latter has conducted appropriate due diligence on agents and business partners, and has assumed responsibility for the implementation and oversight of compliance.  "In light of the foregoing circumstances, continuing the term of the defendant's probation is not required to 'protect the public from further crimes of the defendant.'... the sentence ... has promoted respect for the law and 'adequate deterrence' against international corruption... The government, therefore, has determined that no further purpose of the United States in the enforcement of the federal criiminal laws would be served by continuing the term of probation imposed on Pride Forasol." The motion was unopposed, and the three-year DPA was terminated early.   The government simultaneously filed a motion to dismiss the criminal information filed against Pride.  The judge signed the order granting the government's motion on 5 November 2012.

On 31 December 2009, UTSI entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ under which the company acknowledged responsibility for the conduct of UTS-China's employees and agents and agreed to pay a USD 1.5 million penalty, implement rigorous internal controls and cooperate fully with the DOJ.Also on 31 December 2009, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, UTSI consented to the entry of a permanent injunction against future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  UTSI also agreed to pay a USD 1.5 million civil penalty and to provide the SEC with annual FCPA compliance reports and certifications for four years.Previously, on 1 May 2008, in a prior action involving multiple accounting irregularities unrelated to the FCPA, the SEC issued an order finding that UTSI and certain UTSI executives violated the corporate reporting, books and records and internal controls provisions of the federal securities laws between 2000 and 2005. Without admitting or denying the findings, UTSI agreed to cease and desist from committing such violations.

On 11 January 2010, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, NATCO consented to the entry of a final judgment requiring the company to pay a USD 65,000 civil penalty.  On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, NATCO also agreed to the entry of a cease-and-desist order prohibiting the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.

On 11 December 2009, a grand jury in Washington, D.C. returned indictments against the 22 individuals, each alleging that the Defendants conspired to violate the FCPA, conspired to engage in money laundering and engaged in substantive violations of the FCPA.  The indictments also seek criminal forfeiture of the Defendantsâ€™ ill-gotten gains.On 18 January 2010, approximately 150 FBI agents executed fourteen search warrants in locations across the country, and the United Kingdomâ€™s City of London Police executed seven search warrants in connection with their own investigations into companies involved in the foreign bribery conduct that formed the basis for the indictments. On 19 January 2010, the indictments were unsealed and the twenty-two Defendants were arrested.  Twenty-one were arrested in Las Vegas, Nevada, where they were preparing to attend the 2010 Shooting, Hunting & Outdoor Trade ("SHOT") Show in Las Vegas.  The final individual was arrested in Miami, Florida. On 3 February 2010, nineteen of the Defendants entered pleas of not-guilty at their arraignments, challenging prosecutors' single-conspiracy theory.  The remaining three Defendants were expected to be arraigned sometime during the week of 8 February. Under the original indictments, the Defendants each face a maximum prison sentence of five years for the conspiracy count and five years for each FCPA count.  The  money laundering conspiracy charge carries a maximum sentence of twenty years in prison.As discussed above, on 5 March 2010, prosecutors filed a superseding information against Daniel Alvirez, in which he is charged with two counts of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  The information also seeks forfeiture of Alvirez's ill-gotten gains.  Alvirez now faces up to five years in prison for each of the two conspiracy counts.  He no longer faces the possible twenty-year sentence in connection with the previous money laundering charge, nor the possible five years in prison for each of the substantive FCPA offenses in the initial indictment.On 19 April 2010, the grand jury issued a superseding indictment against the 22 defendants, thereby consolidating the 16 separate cases.  The superseding indictment consists of 44 counts, including conspiracy to violate the FCPA, substantive FCPA violations, conspiracy to commit money laundering and aiding and abetting.  The same day, prosecutors filed a notice with the court proposing a plan for grouping the defendants into four manageable units for trial.  The presiding judge, Richard Leon, had stated on 3 February that he would not try all 22 defendants together. On 28 April 2010, 21 of the defendants (all but Daniel Alvirez) entered pleas of not guilty to the superseding indictment.  On 1 March 2011, Daniel Alvirez pleaded guilty to two counts of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  He is expected to testify at trial against the other defendants.   On 29 March 2011 Jonathan Spiller pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  The substantive FCPA charges and the money laundering conspiracy charges were dropped.  Spiller faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison.  He could be expected to testify at trial against the other defendants.  On 28 April 2011, Haim Geri pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  The other charges were dropped.  He faces 18 to 24 months in prison and a USD 250,000 fine.On 7 July 2011, after seven days of jury deliberations following the six-week trial of the first four defendants - Pankesh Patel, Andrew Bigelow, John Benson Weir and Lee Allen Tolleson - U.S. District Judge Richard Leon declared a mistrial.  The jurors could not reach a unanimous verdict. On 22 December 2011, U.S. District Judge Richard J. Leon entered judgment acquitting Stephen G. Giordanella of conspiracy to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA). The Judge found that the Government's evidence was insufficient to sustain a conviction after a twelve week jury trial in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. On 30 January 2012, a jury acquitted  R. Patrick Caldwell and John Godsey of FCPA violations.   At the time of his arrest, Caldwell was CEO of Protective Products of America, Inc., a body armor company.  Godsey owned an ammunition and law enforcement equipment business.  A day later, on 31 January 2012, U.S. District Judge Richard Leon declared a mistrial in the case against defendants John and Jeana Mushriqui and Marc Morales, after the jury deliberated for ten days without reaching a consensus.On 21 February 2012, the government filed a motion in the US District Court for the District of Columbia, to dismiss with prejudice the superseding indictment and all underlying indictments against  the remaining defendants pending trial in the case.  In its motion, the government cited "the impact of certain evidentiary and other legal rulings in the first two trials" as well as cost, as its motives for seeking to close the case.  Earlier, news reports had accused the FBI of conducting the Sting operation in a highly unprofessional manner.Granting the government's motion to dismiss, U.S. District Court Judge Richard Leon noted, "This appears to be the end of a long and sad chapter in the annals of white collar criminal enforcement.  Unlike takedown day in Las Vegas, however, there will be no front page story in the New York Times or the Post for that matter tomorrow reflecting the governmentâ€™s decision today to move to dismiss the charges against the remaining defendants in this case.  Funny isnâ€™t it what sells newspapers."The good news, however, is that for these defendants, agents, prosecutors, defense counsel and the Court we can get on with our professional and personal lives without the constant strain and burden of three to four more eight week trials hanging over our heads."I for one hope this very long, and Iâ€™m sure very expensive, ordeal will be a true learning experience for both the Department and the FBI as they regroup to investigate and prosecute FCPA cases against individuals in the future."Following dismissal of the charges against all defendants except those who had pleaded guilty following their arrest at the outset of the investigation, the question remained what the Government would decide to do about the "guilty" defendants.  On 27 March 2012, the Government answered this question by filing a Motion to Dismiss with prejudice the superceding indictment filed against Jonathan Spiller, Haim Geri, Daniel Alvirez in March 2010.  The only charge left open for future prosecution is the conspiracy charge against Alvirez, which the government dismissed without prejudice, noting, "The government has also concluded that it is in the interests of justice not to prosecute defendant Alvirez on the Georgia conspiracy count at this time, but rather to continue the investigation of that and related conduct. Following such investigation, the government will determine whether to bring criminal charges relating to that conduct."The primary informant used by the FBI in the Sting operation, Richard Bistrong, was sentenced on 31 July 2012 to 18 months in prison and three years of supervised release for his role in FCPA violations while employed by Armor Holdings prior to the Sting.

On 21 January 2010, the one-count criminal information against Bistrong was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.On 16 September 2010, Bistrong pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA and other statutes.  He faces up to five years in prison and a USD 250,000 fine.  Although prosecutors in the case requested leniency for Bistrong, he was sentenced on 31 July 2012 to 18 months in prison and three years of supervised release.  Bistrong began serving his sentence in October 2012, and is scheduled to be released on 15 January 2014.According to a Transparency International report, the National Police Services Agency in the Netherlands has initiated an investigation into the allegations involving the Dutch police.On 13 July 2011, Armor Holdings entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ in connection with the above-described USD 222,750 in improper payments to an agent, a portion of which was passed on to the UN procurement official, and the USD 4.4 million improperly recorded third party commissions used to assist the company in obtaining business from foreign government customers.  The company agreed to pay a USD 10.2 million criminal fine.  In its press release, the DOJ explicitly acknowledged the company's voluntary disclosure, cooperation and remedial measures:"The Justice Department's agreement recognizes Armor's complete voluntary disclosure of the conduct; its internal investigation and cooperation with the department and the SEC; the fact that the conduct took place prior to the acquisition of Armor by BAE; and Armor's extensive remedial efforts undertaken before and after its acquisition by BAE.  Due to Armor's implementation of BAE's due diligence protocols and review processes, its application of BAE's compliance policies and internal controls to all Armor businesses, its extensive remediation and improvement of its compliance systems and internal controls, as well as the enhanced compliance undertakings included in the agreement, Armor is not required to retain a corporate monitor.   Armor will be required to report to the department on implementation of its remediation and enhanced compliance efforts every six months for the duration of the agreement.  In addition to the $10.29 million penalty, the agreement requires that Armor continue to implement rigorous internal controls and that it cooperate fully with the department."Also on 13 July 2011, Armor Holdings reached a settlement with the SEC regarding the USD 222,750 in improper payments to an agent, a portion of which was passed on to the UN procurement official, and the USD 4.4 million improperly recorded third party commissions.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Armor Holdings agreed to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  The company agreed to pay USD 1,552,306 in disgorgement, USD 458,438 in prejudgment interest, and a civil money penalty of USD 3,680,000, along with certain FCPA compliance undertakings.

Global SettlementIn its 2009 Form 10-K, filed on 19 February 2010, Innospec announced that it had set aside USD 40.2 million in total accruals for an anticipated global settlement of the DOJ, SEC and SFO investigations.The DOJ, SEC and SFO each publicly acknowledged their mutual cooperation in reaching this USD 40.2 million global settlement.  United States On 18 March 2010, Innospec pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court to the twelve-count information, agreeing to pay a USD 14.1 million criminal fine and to retain an independent compliance monitor for a minimum of three years.  On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Innospec consented to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, internal controls, and books and records provisions.  Innospec was ordered to pay USD 60,071,613 in disgorgement, provided that the SEC waive all but USD 11,200,000 of disgorgement and permitting payment in four installments based upon Innospec's sworn Statement of Financial Condition; and ordering the company to comply with certain undertakings regarding its FCPA compliance program, including retaining an independent monitor for a three-year period.On the same day, Innospec also settled USD 2.2 million to resolve outstanding matters with OFAC related to the company's violation of the embargo against Cuba.In its Sentencing Memorandum, the DOJ noted that the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines called for a criminal fine ranging between USD 101.5 million and USD 203 million and the company's total liability to all of the enforcement agencies including criminal fines, civil penalties, disgorgement and pre-judgment interest would be in excess of USD 400 million. The USD 40.2 million global settlement with the DOJ, SEC and SFO represents a significantly reduced amount due to the fact that larger fines and penalties would have jeopardized Innospec's continued viability. On 5 August 2010, David Turner and Innospec's third-party agent, Ousama Naaman, settled charges with the SEC. Turner and Naaman consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from violating securities laws. In addition, Turner agreed to disgorge USD 40,000 to the SEC. Naaman agreed to disgorge USD 810,076 and pay pre-judgment interest of USD 67,030. He also agreed to a USD 438,038 civil penalty, which will be offset by any criminal fines he receives.[Please see a separate Compendium entry titled "Naaman" for information regarding Ousama Naaman's guilty plea.]On 24 January 2011, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Paul Jennings consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining him from future violations of the FCPA.  Jenning allegedly violated the FCPA and aided and abetted Innospec's violations beginning in mid to late 2004 during his tenure as Chief Financial Officer (CFO) and continuing after he became Chief Executive Officer (CEO) in 2005.  Jennings agreed to disgorge USD 116,092 (plus prejudgment interest of USD 12,945) and to pay a USD 100,000 civil penalty that, according to the SEC, takes into consideration Jennings' cooperation with the government's investigation.United Kingdom On 18 March 2010, Innospec Ltd. appeared in Southwark Crown Court  and pleaded guilty to bribing employees of Pertamina (an Indonesian state-owned refinery) and other  Indonesian in order to secure sales of tetraethyl lead.  A USD 12.7 million financial criminal penalty is to be imposed on Innospec Ltd.  On 26 March 2010, Innospec Ltd. entered a plea of guilty and was fined USD 12.7 million.  At the hearing in the Southwark Crown Court, Lord Justice Thomas  criticized the settlement, stating that the SFO had acted beyond its remit in negotiating the trans-Atlantic plea bargain and that the USD 12.7 million fine was "inadequate."  On 27 October 2011, Dennis Kerrison and Paul Jennings appeared before Westminster Magistrates' Court on charges related to alleged corrupt payments to gain public contracts in Indonesia.  Mr Jennings is also charged in connection with corrupt payments in Iraq.  The case was transferred for Southwark Crown Court.  On 11 June 2012, Paul Jennings pleaded guilty in Southwark Crown Court to charges that he conspired to corrupt public officials in Indonesia between 2002 and 2008, and in Iraq between 2003 and 2009, in order to secure contracts for the supply of Innospec products such as tetraethyl lead.  Two other former Innospec executives who are defendants in the case, Miltos Papachristos and Dennis Kerrison, pleaded not guilty.  On 30 July 2012, Jennings pleaded guilty to an additional charge of conspiracy to corrupt Iraqi officials, by making payments designed to induce government inspectors to produce unfavorable test results of a competitor product. On 18 June 2014, Dennis Kerrison, a former Innospec chief executive, and Miltiades Papachristos, a former regional sales director, were convicted by a jury at the Southwark Crown Court of conspiracy and bribery.  According to the SFO, the bribes were intended to secure, or serve as rewards for having secured, contracts from the Government of Indonesia for the supply of Innospec products including Tetraethyl Lead, a highly dangerous organo-lead compound.On 19 September 2014, a U.K. court of appeal upheld the convictions against Mr. Kerrison and Mr. Papachristos.  The justices, however, reduced Mr. Kerrison's sentence from four years to three because the trial judge incorrectly considered the starting point for the sentence as four years instead of five.IndonesiaOn 9 April 2010, The Jakarta Post reported that Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission ("KPK") had begun its own investigation into Innospec Ltd.'s activities in the country between 2000 and 2006. According to media reports in January 2012, Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission (Indonesian abbreviation "KPK") named a local agent for Innospec as a suspect in the Innospec bribery matter and charged the agent under Indonesian anti-corruption laws. According to media reports quoting a KPK spokesperson, Willy Sebastian Liem allegedly received over USD 17.48 million in commissions from Innospec and also channeled money to officials at the Energy Ministry, upstream oil and gas regulator BPMigas and state oil company Pertamina.On 17 January 2012, David Turner, Innospec's former Limited Global Sales and Marketing Director for Tetraethyl Lead, pleaded guilty to three counts of conspiracy to corrupt.  The first two counts charged Turner with conspiracy to give corrupt payments to public officials in Indonesia and Iraq between 2002 and 2008 in order to secure contracts for the sale of Tetraethyl lead.  In addition, Dr. Turner pleaded guilty to charges that he effected improper payments to Iraqi officials in 2006 and 2007 in order to ensure that tests on a competitor product would result in unfavorable assessments.

United StatesOn 16 April 2010, the DOJ and SEC commenced investigations into HP for possible FCPA violations relating to the Russia GPO deal.  On 9 April 2014, HP agreed to pay more than USD $108 million to settle the SECâ€™s charges and the parallel DOJ criminal case.  HP consented to the SECâ€™s order and agreed to pay USD $29 million in disgorgement (approximately USD $26.47 million to the SEC and USD $2.53 million to satisfy an IRS forfeiture as part of the criminal matter); prejudgment interest of USD $5 million to the SEC; and criminal fines totaling USD $74.2 million to the DOJ for a total of more than $108 million in disgorgement and penalties.   HP Russia will pay USD $58.7 million of the total fines imposed.HP Poland entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ and HP Mexico entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ.  GermanyOn 15 April 2010, German authorities arrested three current or former HP Germany employees in connection with the investigation.  A total of ten current or former HP Germany employees are currently targets of the investigation. On 13 September 2012, three former HP managers were charged in Germany with bribery, breach of trust, and aiding and abetting tax evasion.  One of the accused is Finnish, one is American, and one is German.  The prosecutors also requested that Hewlett-Packard be joined as defendant in the case.On 11 March 2014, HP disclosed that the German Public Prosecutor's Office issued an indictment for four individuals, including one current and two former HP employees, on charges including bribery, breach of trust and tax evasion. German prosecutors have also requested that HP be made an associated party to the case, and, if granted, HP could be subject to potential disgorgement of profits based on the conduct of the indicted current and former employees. CanadaFollowing HP's guilty plea to FCPA charges, HP may face a 10-year ban under new integrity rules imposed by Canada's Public Works and Government Services ministry.  Under the new rules, companies face an automatic ban on selling products and services to the Canada government if they are convicted of bribery.United Kingdom On 19 January 2015, the Director of the U.K. Serious Fraud Office ("SFO") closed an investigation into the sale of Autonomy to HP  in 2011.  The investigation was commenced in early 2013, following a referral from HP.  The SFO concluded that there was insufficient evidence for a conviction.The SFO ceded jurisdiction over the investigation to the US authorities and stated that the US investigation is ongoing.

On 28 April 2010, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against the four defendants.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, each defendant consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining them from violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions and aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Myers and Reynolds also agreed to pay civil monetary penalties of USD 40,000 each.On 3 August 2010, Elkin pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA.  While the charge carries a prison sentence of up to five years and a fine of up to USD 250,000, on 21 October 2010, Elkin was sentenced to just three years of probation and a USD 5,000 fine. On 6 August 2010, Alliance One International, Inc. entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ under which it agreed to cooperate with the government's ongoing investigation and appoint a compliance monitor for a three-year period.  The company's Swiss and Kyrgyz subsidiaries each pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and two counts of violating the statute's books and records provisions. Alliance One AG agreed to pay a USD 5,250,000 fine and Alliance One Osh agreed to pay a USD 4,200,000 fine. The subsidiaries are scheduled for sentencing on 21 October 2010. On the same day, Alliance One International, Inc. consented to the entry of a final judgment by the SEC enjoining it from future violations of the anti-bribery and books and records provisions of the FCPA. Alliance One International, Inc. also agreed to disgorge USD 10,000,000 in profits.

United StatesOn 9 January 2014, the SEC and DOJ charged Alcoa with repeatedly violating the FCPA in order to maintain a key source of business. Alcoa agreed to settle the SECâ€™s charges and a parallel DOJ criminal case announced by paying a total of USD $384 million. The SEC investigation found that more than USD $110 million in corrupt payments were made to Bahraini officials with influence over contract negotiations between Alcoa and a major government-operated aluminum plant.  Alcoa was charged with lacking sufficient internal controls to prevent and detect the bribes, which were improperly recorded in Alcoaâ€™s books and records as legitimate commissions or sales to a distributor.Alcoa will pay USD $175 million in disgorgement of ill-gotten gains to the SEC, of which USD $14 million will be satisfied by the companyâ€™s payment of forfeiture in the parallel criminal matter.  Alcoa also will pay a criminal fine of USD $209 million.Alcoa agreed to plead guilty to one count of violating the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA in connection with a 2004 corrupt transaction, to pay a criminal fine of USD $209 million, and to administratively forfeit USD $14 million.   As part of the plea agreement with the DOJ, Alcoa agreed to maintain and implement an enhanced global anti-corruption compliance program.United KingdomMr. Hall was extradited from Australia to the UK, and charged on 15 February 2012 at Westminster Magistrates' Court, with receiving bribes between 1998 and 2006.  Charges include conspiracy to corrupt, corruption, acquiring and transferring criminal property.  Mr. Hall and co-defendant Mr. Dahdeleh, appeared in Southwark Crown Court on 2 March 2012.  Mr. Hall pleaded guilty in 2012 to conspiracy to corrupt after he was charged with taking nearly USD $5 million in bribes.  He was ordered by the court to repay USD $5.1 million to Alba in seven days.  On 22 July 2014, Mr. Hall was put in jail in the U.K. for a period of sixteen months.On 10 December 2013, the trial of Mr. Dahdaleh ended in complete acquittal after two witnesses from U.S. law firm Akin Gump, involved in the investigation, refused to testify and another witness changed his evidence.  Please see separate Compendium summary regarding the case against Victor Dahdeleh.BahrainBahrain's 2008 investigation centered on Sheikh Isa bin Ali al-Khalifa, the country's former minister of petroleum and chairman of Alba, and on Jordan-born Canadian businessman Mr. Dahdaleh, who acted as Alcoa's agent in Bahrain.

The FCPA Sting Operation in which Morales was arrested resulted in acquittals or dismissals for all 22 individual defendants, in February 2012.  On 26 March 2012, the Company's Board of Directors wrote to its shareholders:  "In late February 2012 the DOJ dismissed charges against all of the individuals indicted as a result of the FCPA 'sting' operation, including the former employee of MECAR USA.  The Company has subsequently requested that DOJ consider the company's status in its investigation so that the Company may move forward with distributions to our shareholders."In November 2012, the SEC sent Allied Defense Group a declination.  On 8 August 2013, the DOJ finished its investigations, allowing Allied Defense Group to complete dissolution.

The FCPA investigations are ongoing.SerbiaIn June 2010, Nenad Borojevic was arrested, along with four other individuals, and charged with a criminal conspiracy centered on the receipt of kickbacks from drug companies given in exchange for the use of cancer drugs produced by the companies, which included Roche Holding, Erbitux and Merck KgaA (Germany).  Later, AstraZeneca Plc, Sanofi SA and Actavis confirmed the receipt of criminal indictments related to these allegations.  In addition to the companies above, PharmaSwiss (a subsidiary of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, Inc.) was apparently also involved.  In addition to Borjevic, Zoran Bekic, former head of the Pediatric Ward of the Institute for Oncology and Radiology, and Jasmina Gutovic, a representative of Merck, were charged in the conspiracy.Goran Orlic, a representative of Actavis who admitted participating in the scheme, received immunity in exchange for his testimony.Borojevic committed suicide on 10 January 2012.  Although he had denied all of the charges against him, the media had painted a harsh picture of the doctor.Gutovic left Merck in June 2011.  She entered a plea bargain with prosecutors but will be sentenced only when all defendants have been tried.Svetlana Vukajlovic, former head of the Department of Health Insurance, which approves pharmaceutical and other purchases by state-run medical institutions, was charged in September 2011 with corruption based on other facts.KoreaIn the Company's annual report for 2011, it also noted that it had received an administrative fine of KRW 1,512 million (USD 1.24 million) from the Korean Fair Trade Commission in September 2011, following an investigation of a number of companies for unfair trade practices related to interactions between the local pharmaceutical industry and Korean healthcare providers.  The KFTC claimed that AstraZeneca induced prescriptions through improper marking to physicians in 2006 and 2007, and also acknowledged that the practice ended in 2007 when the Company implemented a more comprehensive compliance program.
On 24 March 2011, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Ball consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order and agreed to pay a USD 300,000 civil penalty.

U.S.On 26 October 2011, the Company received a subpoena from the SEC.  On 13 February 2012, the Department of Justice submitted information to a grand jury focusing on whether Avon executives ignored the company's internal audit findings for 2005, indicating that employees in China may have bribed officials there, or actively hid the audit findings.In a press release SEC Form 8-K dated 5 October 2012, the Company announced Andrea Jung, Executive Chairman of the Company, would step down as Executive Chairman and as a member of the Board of Directors on 31 December 2012, noting that Fred Hassan would replace her and that Jung would become Senior Advisor to the Board.  Vice chairman Charles Cramb was fired on 31 January 2012 in connection with the allegations of bribery.In a public filing, SEC Form 10-Q, dated 1 August 2013, the Company announced that it had substantially completed its internal investigation and compliance reviews, and unsuccessfully tried to settle for USD $12 million with the SEC and DOJ.  As of February 2014, Avon had spent USD $340 million in legal and other costs associated with its internal investigation. On 17 December 2014, the SEC charged Avon with violating the FCPA by failing to put controls in place to detect and prevent payments and gifts to Chinese government officials from employees and consultants at its subsidiary in China.  Avon agreed to pay a total of USD $135 million to settle the SECâ€™s charges and a parallel case announced  by the DOJ and the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office for the Southern District of New York.  Avon, which neither admitted nor denied the allegations, agreed to pay disgorgement of $52,850,000 in benefits resulting from the alleged misconduct plus prejudgment interest of USD $14,515,013.13 for a total of more than USD $67.36 million to the SEC.  In the parallel DOJ criminal matter, Avon entities agreed to pay USD $67,648,000 in penalties.  Avon also is required to retain an independent compliance monitor to review its FCPA compliance program for a period of 18 months, followed by an 18-month period of self-reporting on its compliance efforts.Civil SuitsOn 16 March 2012, Avon shareholders filed a class action lawsuit alleging that Avonâ€™s corporate culture was â€œactively hostile to effective compliance measures.â€ù  The complaint alleged that "Avon executives bribed government officials responsible for China's â€˜direct salesâ€™ licensing process in 2005 and/or 2006," that Avon executives "(1) paid third-party intermediaries substantial sums to schedule meetings between [Avonâ€™s former chief executive officer and chairman of the board, Andrea] Jung and high-level Chinese government ministers; (2) repeatedly treated Chinese licensing officials to 'dinner and karaoke'; and (3) paid Chinese government officials and other employees to attend some Avon press conferences."  The complaint also alleged that, in 2006, "a former Avon auditor revealed that his or her supervisor, Avon's Global Internal Audit Director, Fabian LaPresa ('LaPresa'), received additional severance benefits â€“ which only [former vice chairman, Charles] Cramb could have approved â€“ after LaPresa threatened senior management that he would leak to the SEC an internal audit report in his possession reflecting bribes Avon executives made to Chinese government officials."In another lawsuit, shareholder-plaintiffs filed a motion in court to be allowed to examine Avon's books and records to identify "mismanagement and breaches of fiduciary duties" by the Board and executives in connection with the China bribery.
The investigation appear to be ongoing.

The company declared bankruptcy, and reorganized in December 2009.  In May 2009, the company's Japanese unit had been sold to PricewaterhouseCoopers, one or two business units in North America had been acquired by Deloitte.  The Brazil unit was absorbed into CSC, and the China unit went to Perot Systems.  The name BearingPoint survives in the Australian entity. It is not known whether the FCPA investigation has survived the existence of the company.
The investigations are ongoing.

ARGENTINA, BRAZIL, CHINAOn 26 March 2012, the SEC filed a complaint against Biomet, alleging that the company, along with four of its subsidiaries, paid bribes to public physicians employed by hospitals in Argentina, Brazil and China, between 2000 and 2008.  The complaint specifies that Biomet violated both Section 301 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by making illicit payments to foreign government officials in order to obtain or retain business, as well as Sections 13(b)(2)(A) and (B)of the Act in that it failed to have an adequate internal control system to detect and prevent the payments, and that the company recorded the payments improperly in its accounting books and records. Biomet agreed to disgorge USD $ 5.4 million in the settlement of this complaint.On the same day, the Company entered into a three-year Deferred Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ"), agreeing to pay a USD 17.28 million criminal penalty, to implement rigorous internal controls, and retain a compliance monitor for 18 months.  In the DPA, it is noted that Biomet's fine was reduced by 20% below the lowest possible fine; the DPA attributes the reduction to "Biomet's extensive internal investigation, the nature and extent of Biomet's cooperation in this matter, Biomet's cooperation in the Department's investigation of other companies pursuant to 8C4.1, and Biomet's extraordinary remediation."  According to a Form 8-K filed by Biomet on 17 March 2015, the DOJ informed Biomet on 13 March 2015 that the DPA had been extended for one year, as had the appointment of the independent compliance monitor. The DOJ also informed Biomet that it is retaining its rights to bring an action against Biomet for the alleged improprieties in Brazil and Mexico.BRAZILAccording to a Form 8-K filed by Biomet on 17 March 2015, the DOJ's investigation is ongoing.MEXICOAccording to a Form 8-K filed by Biomet on 17 March 2015, the DOJ's investigation is ongoing.

Corruption Investigation On 19 July 2012, the DOJ wrote a letter to Academi saying that it had closed its investigation into the bribery allegations.  The DOJ noted, "We have taken this step based on a number of factors, including...the investigation undertaken by Academi and the steps taken by the company to enhance its anti-corruption compliance program."Export and Firearms ChargesOn 7 August 2012, Blackwater/Academi entered into a three year Deferred Prosecution Agreement, and agreed to pay a USD 7.5 million fine for various non-FCPA violations (subject to a USD 2.5 million credit for compliance expenditures), and USD 42 million in a State Department fine for violations of  the Arms Export Control Act and the International Trafficking in Arms Regulations.  Among other allegations, the Company acknowledged trying to operate in Sudan in violation of trade sanctions and export restrictions.  Specifically, the company sold satellite communications devices in Sudan in 2005.  It also acknowledged having employed European nationals to construct armored personnel carriers without obtaining the requisite permits, and it exported arms and ammunition to Iraq and Afghanistan.The DPA includes the imposition of an export compliance monitor.The Company admitted to having violated the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) by shipping short-barreled rifles, fully automatic weapons, armored helicopters, armored personnel carriers, by providing training of foreign nationals without a license, and commiting firearms violations, resulting in 17 criminal charges against the company.  A portion of the allegations were subsumed under a non-prosecution agreement applicable to EP Aviation LLC; Aviation Worldwide Services LLC; Air Quest, Inc., Presidential Airways, Inc.; and STI Aviation, Inc.Among the facts stated in the FBI's bill of information and admitted by the Company are FCPA violations:"[C]ounts 13 through 17 allege that the company falsely represented to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives that five firearms were owned by certain individuals when the weapons had, in fact, been given as a gift to the King of Jordan and/or his traveling entourage in June 2005."

As stated in its 2009 SEC Form 10-K, BMS has resolved matters with the Munich Public Prosecutor's Office regarding alleged bribery by employees and agents of BMS subsidiaries in Germany.  It is not clear how those matters were resolved and whether any financial penalties were imposed. The SEC investigations are ongoing.

On 27 July 2011, without admitting or denying the SEC's findings, Diageo consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order prohibiting the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Diageo agreed to pay USD 11,306,081 in disgorgement, a prejudgment interest of USD 2,067,739, as well as a USD 3 million civil penalty.  As stated in its 2009 Annual Report, several former Diageo Korea employees have been prosecuted and convicted in Korea.

On 20 December 2012, the SEC charged Eli Lilly with violations of the anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  The Company neither admitted nor denied the allegations in the SEC's complaint, which included payments to offshore companies associated with Russian government officials, conferring benefits such as spa treatments to Chinese government officials, allowing its agents in Brazil to pay bribes to government health officials, and making donations to a Polish charity founded and administered by a Polish regional health director, in order to secure an ensured market position for the Company's pharmaceutical products.  Eli Lilly agreed to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest and penalties totaling USD 29,398,734.  In its Form 10-K on 19 February 2015, Eli Lilly announced that the DOJ issued a declination.

United StatesIn February 2009 Halliburton and KBR settled FCPA charges related to its involvement in the scheme, resulting in USD 579 million in combined penalties.  The DOJ and SEC have been investigating other joint venture partners since.  On 28 June 2010, Technip settled with the DOJ and SEC for a total of USD 338 million in penalties.  On 7 July 2010, the DOJ filed a deferred prosecution agreement and two-count information against Snamprogetti in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas, charging the company with one count of conspiracy and one count of aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA.  Under the terms of the two-year deferred prosecution agreement, Snamprogetti agreed to pay a USD 240 million criminal fine and  Snamprogetti, Saipem and Eni agreed to ensure that their compliance programs satisfied certain standards and agreed to cooperate with the DOJ's ongoing investigations.  On the same day, Snamprogetti and Eni reached a settlement of a related civil complaint with the SEC.  Snamprogetti was charged with violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions, falsifying books and records and circumventing internal controls .  Eni was charged with violating the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, the companies agreed to the entry of court orders permanently enjoining them from future violations of the respective securities law provisions.  Snamprogetti and Eni agreed to jointly pay USD 125 million in disgorgement of profits and prejudgment interest.  At the conclusion of the two-year deferral period, on 19 September 2012, all charges against the Company in the U.S. were dropped, definitively concluding U.S. criminal proceedings against Snamprogetti Netherlands BV for conduct connected with the TSKJ consortium's work on Bonny Island.  In a press release announcing dismissal of the charges, the Company listed its anti-corruption accomplishments, including the application of "groundbreaking anti-corruption control systems" and becoming "an international reference for best practices in anti-corruption. "ItalyThe long-running matter with the Milan Public Prosecutor's Office remains ongoing.  On  31 July and 12 August 2009, complaints were served on Saipem/Snamprogetti, but procedural issues relating to the admission of evidence and the application of conflicting statutes of limitations prevented the case from moving forward.   In a 26 January 2011 hearing, the public prosecutor served indictments on five former employees; preliminary hearings took place in May 2011.  Then, on 2 February 2012, it was determined that the statute of limitations conflict between Italian law and the requirements of the OECD convention must be addressed, and at a subsequent hearing, on 8 March 2012, resolution of the issue was postponed until 5 April 2012.  Meanwhile, information published in ENI's  20-F filed with the SEC on 5 April 2012 revealed that on 24 January 2012 the Judge for Preliminary Hearings set aside part of the proceedings, dismissing the case as against nine employees and former employees of Eni (relating to failure to pay excise duties).  The tax authorities reduced the amount originally claimed by the public prosecutor to EUR 114 million in unpaid taxes.   NigeriaThe press reported that Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission ("EFCC") had arrested ten Halliburton employees in Nigeria during a raid of the offices of Halliburton Energy Services Nigeria Limited in Lagos on 25 November 2010.   The EFCC also arrested one employee each from Saipem Contracting Nigeria and Technip Offshore Nigeria.  On 7 December 2010, the EFCC reportedly filed corruption charges against Halliburton, former U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney (who was the CEO of Halliburton during the period at issue), Albert Stanley (former CEO of KBR), David Lesar (current CEO of Halliburton) and William Utt (current CEO of KBR).  Technip, Snamprogetti and JGC Corp. were reportedly also charged on the same day.  The case number is Federal Republic of Nigeria v. Halliburton and others, CV/435/10, High Court of Justice, Abuja Judicial Division (Abuja).According to press reports, on 15 December 2010, Halliburton and the EFCC reached a USD 250 million settlement agreement to resolve the charges.  Halliburton will pay USD 120 million in penalties and USD 130 million in frozen assets in Switzerland will be repatriated to Nigeria.  In exchange, Nigeria dropped the charges.  Former U.S. President George H. W. Bush and former Secretary of State James Baker reportedly assisted with the negotiations.  On 20 December 2010, Saipem announced that Snamprogetti had entered into a settlement agreement and non-prosecution agreement with the Federal Government of Nigeria to resolve the investigation.  Snamprogetti agreed to the payment of a criminal penalty of USD 30 million, along with USD 2.5 million in reimbursement for legal costs and expenses incurred by the Nigerian authorities.  Nigeria agreed to dismiss all charges against Snamprogetti and to renounce to any civil claims and criminal charges in any jurisdiction.KazakhstanThe investigation is ongoing.African Development BankOn 2 June 2014, Snamprogetti agreed to pay the Africa Development Bank USD $5.7 million in penalties for bribery related to contracts for liquefied natural gas production plants on Bonny Island, Nigeria.

As reported in ENSCO's SEC Form 10-K filed on 24 February 2012, both the SEC and the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") have notified the Company that they do not intend to take any enforcement action against it with regards to the subject of the Company's internal investigation. The SEC's notice came in May 2010, and the DOJ's notice came in May 2011.
In 2012, the DOJ and SEC publicly announced that the investigations were closed and neither would be pursuing action.

ChinaIn China, four GSK executives have been detained pursuant to the Ministry of Public Security's investigation of potential economic crimes.  According to a Bloomberg News report from 15 July 2013, the executives are: Huang Hong (a GSK business development manager), Liang Hong (GSK's vice president and operations manager in China), Zhang Guowei (a GSK human resources director), and Zhao Hongyan (a GSK legal affairs director). According to the same story, all four executives are Chinese nationals. Bloomberg News also reported that the head of GSK in China, Mark Reilly, "returned to the U.K. on a routine, planned business trip and has been working from company headquarters on the response to the investigation."On 16 July 2013, The Telegraph cited a statement from the Ministry of Public Security as saying that "[a]fter initial questioning the suspects have admitted to the crimes, and the investigation is ongoing." The Telegraph also reported that the vice president of operations in China, Liang Hong, who is one of the four detained executives, confessed to the crimes on a news broadcast on 15 July 2013.The Guardian reported on 26 July 2013 that an additional group of eighteen or more GSK employees have been detained by the police in Zhengzhou. Additional details were unavailable.On 14 May 2014, Chinese prosecutors filed criminal charges against Mark Reilly, the former GSK China CEO.  Mr. Reilly allegedly ordered his sales teams to bribe doctors and hospitals to achieve the companyâ€™s sales targets, according to police in Changsha, Hunan province.  Two other GSK executives, allegedly helped execute the bribery scheme, which netted the company revenue worth billions of yuan.  GSKâ€™s drugs in China cost more than those in other countries because the company allegedly inflated drug prices to recoup bribery funds, according to Chinese police.On 19 September 2014, GSK agreed to pay an unprecedented USD $491.5 million to Chinese authorities after the companyâ€™s Chinese subsidiary was found guilty of bribery.  The ruling followed a one-day trial in Changsha, Hunan, and the penalty marks the largest corporate fine ever imposed in China.
