Mr. Reilly was sentenced to three years in prison after allegedly ordering his sales teams to bribe doctors and hospitals to achieve the companyâ€™s sales targets.  Mr. Reilly received a three-year prison sentence that was suspended for four years; he will be expelled from China following the four-year suspended sentence.  GSK published an apology in Chinese to the Chinese government and its people on its website.  And previously, in 2013, a confession by GSKâ€™s Vice President of China operations was broadcast on television.United KingdomOn 27 May 2014, GSK disclosed that the UK's Serious Fraud Office opened a formal criminal investigation of the company's commercial practices.United StatesThe DOJ and SEC investigation of the pharmaceuticals industry in a variety of countries appear to be ongoing.  PolandPoland's Central Anti-Corruption Bureau ("CAB") opened a criminal investigation into GSK and announced on 14 April 2014 that 13 people had been charged in connection with the investigation.
The investigations are ongoing.
The DOJ and SEC investigations concluded with no action taken.
The DOJ and SEC closed their investigations without taking any enforcement action against Golden Minerals.

The investigations in Brazil involving several former and current GTECH employees remain ongoing.  As stated above, the SEC in the United States closed its investigation without taking any enforcement action.

United StatesOn 18 March 2011, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, IBM consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from violating the FCPA's books and records and internal control provisions. IBM agreed to pay disgorgement of USD 5,300,000, USD 2,700,000 in prejudgment interest, and a USD 2,000,000 civil penalty.  The DOJ appears to have closed its investigation without taking any enforcement action. In December 2012, Judge Richard Leon notified the parties that he would not approve the settlement unless both the SEC and IBM could agree to additional settlement terms recommended by the court.  The Court would like to see reporting requirements imposed on IBM, including annual reports to the SEC regarding FCPA compliance efforts, as well as disclosure of new criminal or civil investigations involving the company.  IBM apparently agrees to the former but not the latter, and the SEC has supported IBM's position.  The Court asked the parties to provide evidence to support IBM's claim that the investigation reporting requirement is too burdensome.According to Bloomberg News, Judge Leon approved the settlement between the SEC and IBM on 25 July 2013. According to the article, "IBM agreed to make annual reports to the judge and the SEC describing its efforts to comply with the FCPA. The company also agreed to immediately report to the SEC and the court 'upon learning that it is reasonably likely' IBM violated the FCPA in connection with improper payments to foreign officials or any fraudulent books and records."South KoreaAs described in its 2009 annual report above, South Korean authorities previously charged employees of IBM Korea and LB IBM with bribery and bid rigging, among other charges, and these employees were subsequently found guilty and sentenced.  The two companies were fined and IBM Korea was temporarily debarred.

On April 8, 2011, J&J; entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a USD 21.4 million criminal fine.  The DOJ recognized the company's voluntary disclosure, thorough internal investigation, significant assistance to the government's industry-wide investigation, and extensive remedial efforts and compliance improvements.  J&J; was not required to retain an independent corporate monitor; rather, the company must report to the DOJ on the implementation of its remediation and enhanced compliance efforts every six months for the duration of the agreement.   With regard to the OIl-for-Food violations, the DPA stated as follows:  "Between in or around December 2000 and in or around March 2003, Janssen and Cilag were awarded 18 contracts for the sale of pharmaceuticals to the Iraqi Ministry of Health State Company for Marketing Drugs and Medical Appliances ...with a total contract value of approximately $9.9 million, which generated approximately $6.1 million in profits. Janssen and Cilag secured these contracts through the payment of approximately $857,387 in kickbacks to the government of Iraq."On the same day, J&J; also settled with the SEC.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, J&J; consented to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  J&J; agreed to pay USD 48.6 million in disgorgement of profits, including pre-judgment interest.Also on 8 April 2011, J&J;'s UK-based medical device subsidiary, DePuy International Limited (DPI), settled with the UK Serious Fraud Office in connection with improper payments made to Greek medical professionals in order to secure the sale of orthopedic products between 1999 and 2006.  In the High Court, the SFO obtained a Civil Recovery Order against DPI, under which the company will pay GBP 4.829 million (approx. USD 7.9 million), plus prosecution costs, in recognition of the unlawful conduct.  Previously, on 1 December 2009, the UK SFO issued a summons alleging that Robert John Dougall, former Director of Marketing at DPI, conspired to corrupt in violation of the Criminal Law Act 1977 in connection with improper payments and other inducements allegedly made to Greek health care professionals.  On 14 April 2010, in Southwark Crown Court, Dougall pleaded guilty to violating section 1 of the Prevention of Corruption Act 1906, admitting to his involvement in connection with GBP 4.5 million in corrupt payments made to Greek medical professionals.  Despite his cooperation with the SFO's investigation, the court sentenced Dougall to a 12-month prison term.  Justice Dean gave Dougall leave for appeal in recognition of important public interest issues raised in the case. On 1 May 2010, the Lord Chief Justice determined that the 12-month prison sentence was "manifestly excessive" and suspended it for two years. According to the SFO, Dougall was the first "co-operating defendant" in a major SFO corruption investigation.The Chinese domestic investigation appears to be ongoing. In the Company's SEC 10-Q report filed on 7 May 2012, on-going legal proceedings reported include shareholder derivative actions, filed in May and August 2011 in US District Court in New Jersey, and in New Jersey Superior Court, naming Johnson & Johnson and its current directors as defendants, and alleging breach of fiduciary duties related to the Company's compliance with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and participation in the United Nations Iraq Oil For Food Program, and failure to disclose the breaches. In January 2012, Johnson & Johnson moved to dismiss or stay the state lawsuits pending resolution of the federal lawsuit.

On 20 February 2014, LyondellBasell announced in an SEC filing that the DOJ closed its investigation into a payment made in Kazakhstan.  The DOJ ended its investigation without assessing any fine or penalty.
The SEC closed its investigation with no action.

On 31 January 2011, Maxwell reached a settlement with DOJ and SEC.  The DOJ filed a criminal information charging the company with one count of violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions and one count of violating the books and records provisions.  Maxwell entered into a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ and agreed to pay a USD 8 million criminal fine, to be paid in three installments over approximately two years.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Maxwell consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, internal control and disclosure provisions.  Maxwell was ordered to pay USD 5,654,576 in disgorgement, and USD 696,314 in prejudgment interest to be paid in two installments over one year.  The company also agreed to implement enhancements to its compliance program and internal controls, to report periodically to the agencies regarding its compliance efforts and to cooperate with the agencies' ongoing investigations.  On 11 October 2013, Alain Riedo was charged in San Diego with nine counts of violating the FCPA, conspiracy, falsifying records, and evading Maxwell's internal controls.

In its SEC Form 10-K submitted on 24 June 2013, Medtronic announced that both the SEC and DOJ have decided to terminate their investigation "without pursuing any enforcement action or charges against the Company." The authorities notified Medtronic of this decision earlier in June 2013.

As a result of the SEC civil Complaint, Garth Peterson was barred from working in the securities industry forever.  He was ordered to pay a civil penalty, to disgorge ill-gotten gains, and a receiver was appointed following the freezing of Peterson's interest in Shanghai Jin Lin Tiandi Serviced Apartments.Specifically, Peterson consented to a court order requiring him to disgorge USD 254,589 and relinquish to a court-appointed receiver the interest he secretly acquired from Morgan Stanley's fund in the Jin Lin Tiandi Serviced Apartments. Peterson's interest has a current estimated value of approximately USD 3.4 million. Also on 25 April 2012, Garth Peterson pleaded guilty to a one-count criminal information for conspiracy to evade the internal accounting controls required of Morgan Stanley in order to comply with the FCPA.  Peterson could have faced a maximum of 5 years in prison and a fine of USD 250,000 or two times his gross gain from the criminal offense.  But on 13 August 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York sentenced Peterson to 9 months in prison. The DOJ declined to prosecute Morgan Stanley, based on the Company's "system of internal controls, which provided reasonable assurances that its employees were not bribing government officials."

The SEC investigation was concluded in April 2012, as explained in the Company's SEC Form 10-Q filed on 2 November 2012:"On July 5, 2007, we received an inquiry from the U.S. Department of Justice relating to its investigation of one of our vendors and compliance with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. . . . Both the SEC and the Department of Justice have been advised of the results of our investigation. The SEC has advised us in April 2012 that it concluded its review of this matter and does not intend to recommend any enforcement action against us. Although the Department of Justice has not concluded its inquiry, we do not anticipate that its final determination will have an adverse effect on the Company."In its Form 8-K submitted to the SEC on 15 February 2013, Nabors Industries stated that the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") notified the Company that "it has concluded its inquiry, also without recommending any enforcement action against us."

United States: CorporationOn 4 November 2010, Noble entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a USD 2.59 million criminal penalty.  According to the DOJ, "the non-prosecution agreement recognizes Noble's early voluntary disclosure, thorough self-investigation of the underlying conduct, full cooperation with the department and extensive remedial measures undertaken by the company. As a result of these factors, among others, the department agreed not to prosecute Noble or its subsidiaries for the bribe payments, provided that Noble satisfies its ongoing obligations under the agreement."On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Noble consented to the entry of a court order enjoining it from violating the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions.  Noble was ordered to disgorge ill-gotten gains of USD 4,294,933 and pay prejudgment interest of USD 1,282,065.United States: IndividualsOn 24 February 2012, Mark Jackson and James Ruehlen were charged in a complaint filed by the SEC in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.  The government alleged that the two men bribed officials in the Nigeria Customs Service to grant and then to extend temporary permits to allow offshore oil rigs to enter Nigerian waters and then continue operating beyond their original permit period, without the necessity of exporting and re-importing the equipment, which would have involved tremendous cost in terms of lost work, in addition to Nigerian customs duties. The SEC claims that the two men arranged and facilitated the payment of hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes to obtain about 11 illicit permits and 29 permit extensions.  Ruehlen allegedly prepared false documents and paid the bribes, while Jackson approved and concealed the payments. In a separate complaint also filed on 24 February 2012, the SEC alleges that O'Rourke aided and abetted violations of the anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls sections of the Securities and Exchange Act, and that he directly violated false records and internal controls provisions of the Act.  O'Rourke agreed to the entry of a court order imposing a USD 35,000 penalty and permanently enjoining him from violations of the Act, although he neither admitted nor denied the allegations.On 8 May 2012, Ruehlen and Jackson filed separate motions to dismiss the claims against them, based on the failure of the government to state a claim, and on the statute of limitations.  The substantive claim for both men rests on the theory that the payments made to officials were "facilitation payments" and therefore legal within the meaning of the FCPA.  The motions also claim that the complaint does not identify in sufficient detail the Nigerian officials who allegedly received bribes.On 22 June 2012, the SEC filed a combined answer to Jackson's and Ruehlen's motions to dismiss.  The answer cites precedent rejecting the facilitation payments argument, and notes that with respect to the statute of limitations argument, a tolling agreement is on file and acknowledged by the defendants, and in any event some of the corrupt conduct took place within the five-year statute of limitations (the lawsuit was filed on 24 February 2012, and the conduct alleged took place between September 2004 and May 2007).  Moreover, since some of the relief requested by the SEC is injunctive and therefore equitable relief, the statute of limitations does not apply.  The answer also rejects the defendants' claim that the bribe recipients are insufficiently identified, since government agencies and positions of employment are specified.On 11 December 2012, District Judge Keith P. Ellison ruled on Jackson and Ruehlen's motions to dismiss.  Judge Ellison granted Jackson's motion as to all claims insofar as the SEC seeks monetary penalties, but denied Jackson's motion insofar as the SEC seeks injunctive relief.  Ruehlen's motion to dismiss was granted as to violations that occurred prior to 24 February 2007, but denied as to claims that arose thereafter.  Furthermore, the judge denied Ruehlen's motion as to the SEC's complaint for injunctive relief (since in that case the five-year statute of limitations does not apply).  In January 2013, Judge Ellison set 28 April 2014 as the date for the trial. On 26 March 2013, Main Justice reported that the SEC, in an effort to avoid additional statute of limitations problems, has amended its complaint to exclude allegations occurring before 10 May 2006. According to the SEC, this date is the sum of the five years prior to the filing of the original complaint in February 2012 plus 290 days (which the SEC says the defendants agreed to as part of a tolling agreement). Jackson and Ruehlen have until 19 April 2013 to respond to the amended complaint.On 25 March 2014, the SEC dropped internal controls charges in a civil foreign bribery case against Mr. Jackson and Mr. Ruehlen, a current and a former executive at Noble Corp.  In a court filing, the SEC said it dropped allegations they violated internal-controls claims â€œto narrow this case and streamline the presentation of evidence to the jury.â€ùOn 1 July 2014, federal district judge Keith B. Ellison denied motions for summary judgments filed by the SEC, and by former Noble executives Mark Jackson and James Ruehlen.  According to the docket, all deadlines in the SEC's enforcement action against two former Noble executives have been vacated "pending final settlement documents," indicating that the two defendants are planning to settle with the SEC.On 3 July 2014, Mark Jackson and James Ruehlen entered into a settlement with the SEC without financial penalty.  While the settlement contained injunctions against the two, it did not restrict current or future employment and contained no admission of wrongdoing.Nigeria EnforcementOn 13 January 2011, it was reported that Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) had detained twelve oil-industry employees, including four Noble employees, in connection with the agency's investigation into the bribery scheme.  In a filing on 31 January 2011, Noble reported that it had resolved the charges with the EFCC and Nigerian Attorney General Office, entering into a non-prosecution agreement to resolve all charges and agreeing to pay a USD 2.5 million penalty.
It appears that both the Norwegian and U.S. authorities have closed their investigations into this matter with no action.

On November 4, 2010, the DOJ filed a criminal information charging Panalpina with conspiracy to violate and violating the anti-bribery provisions of the FCPA.  Panalpina and the DOJ entered into a deferred prosecution agreement.On the same day, the DOJ filed a criminal information charging Panalpina, Inc. with conspiring to violate the books and records provisions of the FCPA and with aiding and abetting certain customers in violating the books and records provisions of the FCPA.  Panalpina, Inc. agreed to plead guilty to the charges.The deferred prosecution agreement and plea agreement impose a USD 70.56 million criminal penalty.  Also on November 4, 2010, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Panalpina, Inc. consented to the entry of a final judgment ordering disgorgement and permanently enjoining the company from violating the FCPA's anti-bribery provisions and aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Panalpina, Inc. agreed to pay USD 11,329,369 in disgorgement of profits and prejudgment interest.  According to press reports in November 2010, Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) is pursuing a domestic bribery action against Panalpina.  The EFCC reportedly raided Panalpina's Lagos office on November 26th and arrested 11 of its top officials.

The DOJ and SEC announced on 16 April 2013 that the two agencies have agreed to settlements with Parker Drilling regarding the FCPA charges against the Company. Parker Drilling and the DOJ reached a Deferred Prosecution Agreement, through which Parker Drilling agreed to pay a USD 11.76 million penalty. In its settlement with the SEC, Parker Drilling agreed to pay USD 3.05 million in disgorgement of profits and USD 1.04 million in pre-judgment interest. The total amount of these two settlements is USD 15.85 million.
The investigation appears to be ongoing.

The US Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC) levied $3.4 million in US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) fines against PBSJ and fined one of PBSJâ€™s former officers $500,000 for FCPA violations.  According to the SEC, the former PBSJ officer, Walid Hatoum, offered to bribe a foreign official to access confidential sealed-bid and pricing information to enable PBSJ to win bids for a hotel resort development project in Morocco and a light rail transit project in Qatar.  The SEC did not go to court for the case, entering into a two-year Deferred Prosecution Agreement (DPA) with PBSJ and an administrative order against Hatoum.

On 8 March 2012, the Croatian justice ministry's corruption investigative body, USKOK, reported that U.S. officials had requested information about Pfizer's possible payment of bribes to doctors in Croatia. On 7 August 2012, the SEC filed a complaint against Pfizer (please see the Compendium summary for Pfizer-Wyeth to an analysis of the SEC's separate complaint against Wyeth).  Without admitting or denying the allegations contained in the complaint, Pfizer consented to the entry of a final judgment ordering it to pay disgorgement of USD 16,032,676 in net profits and prejudgment interest of USD 10,307,268 for a total of USD 26,339,944.  In addition, Pfizer is required to submit periodic compliance reports to the SEC at least every nine months for two years. On the same day, the DOJ entered into a Deferred Prosecution Agreement (DPA) with Pfizer HCP, filing a two-count criminal information charging Pfizer H.C.P. with conspiracy and violations of the FCPA in Bulgaria, Croatia, Kazakhstan and Russia.  The agreement requires Pfizer to pay a USD 15 million penalty.  The DPA is for a period of two years and seven days but may be extended for one year at the DOJ's discretion.  Of particular note is that the DOJ did not require Pfizer to use a compliance monitor as part of the terms of the settlement.In reaching the settlement, the DOJ said that it lessened Pfizer's penalties because of the company's voluntary disclosure and self-investigation.  The government also praised Pfizer's compliance measures, including Pfizer's anti-corruption policies, internal audit program, annual reviews of commercial practices in other markets, due diligence compliance team for mergers and acquisitions, and training tools for Pfizer employees.

On December 10, 2010, without admitting or denying the charges, RAE consented to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  RAE agreed to pay USD 1,147,800 in disgorgement, plus USD 109,212 in prejudgment interest.  The company was ordered to comply with certain undertakings regarding its compliance program.On the same day, RAE also settled with the DOJ, entering into a non-prosecution agreement and agreeing to pay a USD 1.7 million criminal penalty.  On 13 January 2011, the Company announced the definitive sale of its 70% interest in the RAE Fushun joint venture.  Although RAE expected to receive compensation for products and services already provided to the joint venture by RAE, the Company did not anticipate receiving any direct compensation for sale of the venture to the Shenyang Research Institute of China Coal Research.On May 12, 2011, RAE disclosed in a SEC filing that it was under investigation again by the DOJ and SEC in connection with another possible FCPA violation in China.  The company described the matter as follows:"In the course of telephonic discussions between April 15 and 19, 2011, outside counsel for the Company was asked by the SEC whether RAE China had adopted a sales program whereby customers are awarded points based on the level of their purchases of RAE products and are then eligible to redeem those points at year-end for gifts such as iPads or cameras, and whether such a program complies with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act ('FCPA'). We do not believe that any RAE China personnel have been engaging in such a practice. We are conducting a review in response to the SEC's inquiry, and intend to provide our conclusions to the SEC and Department of Justice."On 30 June 2011, the Company de-listed with the SEC.

In its SEC Form 10-K filed on 13 February 2013, Raytheon said the following:"We have completed a self-initiated internal review of certain of our international operations, focusing on compliance with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. In the course of the review, we identified possible areas of concern involving certain practices related to operations in a foreign jurisdiction where we do business. We voluntarily disclosed and shared the results of our review with the SEC and the DoJ. The SEC staff and the DoJ have completed their review of this matter without recommending enforcement action."

Rockwell Automation received a declination letter from the DOJ in 2010.  On May 3, 2011, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Rockwell Automation consented to the imposition of a cease-and-desist order prohibiting it from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Rockwell Automation agreed to pay disgorgement of USD 1,771,000, prejudgment interest of USD 590,091 and a civil money penalty of USD 400,000.  The SEC noted that it did not impose a civil penalty greater than USD 400,000 in recognition of Rockwell Automation's cooperation with the Commission's investigation.

On November 4, 2010, the DOJ and Shell entered into a deferred prosecution agreement that requires, among other things, SNEPCO to pay a USD 30 million criminal penalty.In a related SEC action on the same day, Shell and its U.S. subsidiary, Shell International Exploration and Production Inc., agreed to a pay approximately USD 18.1 million in disgorgement of profits and prejudgment interest.According to press reports, in October 2010 Shell paid a USD 10 million fine to the Nigerian government to resolve its domestic investigation into the matter.
The investigations appear to be ongoing.
It is unclear whether the investigations are ongoing.

Poland InvestigationOn 31 December 2012, media sources reported that Polish prosecutors in Katowice had conducted searches in dozens of residences and offices over the course of a few months, seeking evidence to support allegations that employees of Stryker Poland bribed hospital administrators between 2003 and 2006.  The purpose of the alleged corrupt payments was to win contracts for the sale of Stryker products.  Kickbacks were purportedly paid to 100 individuals at 51 hospitals. Earlier in 2012, a separate bribery case was heard by a court in the city of Olsztyn in 2012.  In that case, the lower court found a hospital director guilty of accepting bribes from Stryker.  The appeals court overturned both the indictment and the prison sentence.  The case is expected to be retried in 2013. U.S. InvestigationStryker has agreed to pay over $13.2 million to settle the SEC charges.
The investigations are ongoing.

On 28 July 2011, in its Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements, Grifols stated that Talecris' internal investigation was completed in the first quarter of 2011 and that the company made an initial presentation of its findings to the DOJ in July 2011. In its Form 6-K filed with the SEC on 30 November 2012, Grifols announced that the DOJ has declined to continue its investigation of the allegations. According to Grifols, the DOJ noted "the significant cooperation of Grifols with the DOJ by taking immediate steps to secure valuable information and making responsible decisions that lead to the early disclosure of information to the DOJ, thanks to the Compliance Program, internal audit functions concerning bribery and related misconduct, and the continuing improvements in the global anti-corruption compliance procedures."

The SEC and DOJ closed their investigations without taking any enforcement action against Team.  Team explained as follows in its SEC Form 10-K filed on August 2, 2011:"During an internal management review of our TMS branch operations in Trinidad in the spring of 2009, employees informed us of allegations of improper payments made by local employees of our wholly-owned Trinidad subsidiary to employees of certain customers, including foreign government owned enterprises. In June 2009, the Audit Committee of our Board of Directors (the â€œBoardâ€ù) commenced an internal investigation of our Trinidad operations, focusing on the legality, under the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (â€œFCPAâ€ù) and other laws. In May 2010, we voluntarily disclosed information relating to the initial allegations and the findings of the independent investigation to the U.S. Department of Justice (â€œDOJâ€ù) and to the Securities and Exchange Commission (the â€œSECâ€ù).In May 2010, we met with representatives of the SEC and the DOJ. In a letter to us dated July 12, 2011, the staff of the SEC informed us that it had completed its investigation and did not intend to recommend any enforcement action by the Commission or impose any fines or penalties against the Company. We have not received formal notification from the DOJ, however in July 2011, the staff of the DOJ informed us that it was likely that the staff would not recommend taking any further action or imposing any fines or penalties against the Company.Since the commencement of the investigation in 2009, we have expended an aggregate of approximately $3.2 million on legal and other professional services related to this investigation. While our and the governmentâ€™s investigations have concluded, we continue to remain committed to and focused on conducting our operations in compliance with the FCPA."

On May 17, 2011, Tenaris settled FCPA charges with the DOJ and SEC.  Tenaris entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a $3.5 million criminal penalty.  Tenaris entered into a two-year deferred prosecution agreement with the SEC (the SEC's first such agreement) and agreed to pay $5,428,338 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest, as well as to comply with certain undertakings regarding its FCPA compliance program.The DOJ and SEC highlighted Tenaris's voluntary disclosure and "extraordinary cooperation", as well as the company's enhanced compliance efforts.

On November 4, 2010, Tidewater Marine and the DOJ entered into a deferred prosecution agreement that requires, among other things, Tidewater Marine to pay a USD 7.35 million criminal penalty.On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Tidewater consented to a court order permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  Tidewater was ordered to pay USD 7,223,216 in disgorgement plus prejudgment interest of USD 881,146, and a USD 217,000 civil penalty.On January 13, 2011, it was reported that Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) had detained twelve oil-industry employees, including several Tidewater employees, in connection with the agency's investigation into the bribery scheme.  Tidewater described the events as follows in a securities filing on February 4, 2011:"On January 10, 2011, representatives of the Nigerian Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) entered the offices of the company's operating company in Lagos, Nigeria, and requested that representatives of the operating company participate in a series of interviews. Those representatives agreed to participate and were interviewed by the EFCC.The company has now been asked to participate in discussions with the Nigerian Attorney General's Office to resolve, under Nigerian law, issues raised by the company's FCPA-related settlements with the United States Department of Justice and the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. It is our current understanding that the discussions with the Nigerian Attorney General's Office relate solely to Nigeria operations issues raised in those settlements and that the Nigerian Government seeks monetary restitution based on the same issues. The company has begun participating in those discussions.The company has not concluded that any potential liability that may result from any potential enforcement action by the Nigerian Attorney General's Office is both probable and reasonably estimable and, thus, no accrual has been recorded as of December 31, 2010. Should additional information be obtained that any potential liability is probable and reasonably estimable, the company will record such liability at that time."On March 3, 2011, Tidewater announced in a securities filing that it had agreed to pay USD 6.3 million to settle bribery charges with the Nigerian Government: "Tidewater Inc. (NYSE:TDW) announced today that it has reached agreement with the Federal Government of Nigeria ("FGN") to settle and resolve the previously disclosed investigation by the FGN relating to allegations that the Nigerian affiliate of a Swiss-based freight forwarder had made improper payments to government officials in Nigeria on behalf of Tidewater's foreign subsidiaries. The FGN's investigation in this regard focused on facts and circumstances associated with Nigeria operations in 2007 and previous years that were detailed in Tidewater's previous settlements with the U.S. Department of Justice and U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Pursuant to the settlement agreement, the FGN has terminated the above-mentioned investigation and agreed not to bring any criminal charges or civil claims against any Tidewater entity or associated persons arising from these allegations. In return, Tidewater agreed to pay $6.0 million to the FGN and to pay an additional $0.3 million for the FGN's attorneys' fees and other expenses. The total $6.3 million ($0.12 per diluted common share) settlement payments will be made promptly and will be reflected in Tidewater's fourth fiscal quarter results ending March 31, 2011. Among other provisions in the settlement agreement, Tidewater also affirmed a continuing commitment to good corporate governance and compliance."

On November 4, 2010, Transocean Inc. and the DOJ entered into a deferred prosecution agreement that requires, among other things, Transocean Inc. to pay a USD 13.44 million criminal penalty.On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Transocean Inc. consented to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  The company was ordered to pay USD 5,981,693 in disgorgement, plus prejudgment interest of USD 1,283,387.Also on the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, GlobalSantaFe consented to the entry of a court order permanently enjoining it from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  The company was ordered to pay disgorgement of USD 2,694,405, prejudgment interest of USD 1,063,760, and a civil penalty of USD 2.1 million.On January 13, 2011, it was reported that Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) had detained twelve oil-industry employees, including two Transocean employees, in connection with the agency's investigation into the bribery scheme.

United StatesIn April 2006, an FCPA action was filed against Tyco by the SEC.  Tyco consented to the entry of a final judgment enjoining it from violations of the FCPA and other securities laws.  The judgment was entered on 1 May 2006, and the Company paid USD 1 in disgorgement and USD 50 million in civil penalties.  The 2012 settlement involves violations that occurred following the entry of the 2006 injunction.On 24 September 2012, Tyco and its subsidiary, TVC-ME pleaded guilty to conspiracy to violate the FCPA, and agreed to pay USD 26 million to resolve the SEC's and DOJ's charges.  USD 13.68 million of the penalty is attributable to the Company's falsification of books and records in connection with bribe payments by the Company's subsidiaries to government officials in Saudi Arabia (TVC-ME will contribute USD 2.1 million of this penalty).  The DOJ entered a non-prosecution agreement with Tyco as part of the settlement.Specifically, in exchange for a guilty plea by TVC-ME in a plea agreement dated 20 September 2012, the government agreed not to file additional criminal charges against Tyco and its subsidiaries and affiliates based on the conduct detailed in the statement of facts or any information disclosed by the Company prior to the date of the plea agreement.  The DOJ agreed to the imposition of the lowest fine within the federal guidelines:  USD 2,100,000 plus the mandatory special assessment of USD 400 per count.  Also on 20 September 2012, the DOJ and Tyco signed a three year Deferred Prosecution Agreement, and the latter agreed to pay a penalty of USD 13,680,000.Also on 24 September 2012, Tyco consented to the SEC's proposed final judgment, and agreed to pay USD 10,564,992 in disgorgement and USD 2,566,517 in prejudgment interest.In its press statement announcing the settlement, the DOJ  acknowledged the Company's "timely, voluntary and complete disclosure, its cooperation â€“ including a global internal investigation concerning bribery and related misconduct â€“ and its extensive remediation.  That remediation includes the implementation of an enhanced compliance program, the termination of employees responsible for the improper payments and falsification of books and records, the severing of contracts with the responsible third-party agents and the closing of subsidiaries due to compliance failures."  In fact, at least 90 employees, including supervisors, were terminated as a result of FCPA compliance concerns.At a docketed hearing date on 31 January 2013, U.S. District Judge Richard Leon for the District of Columbia had yet to officially agree to the civil settlement between the SEC and the company.  It was unknown why the agreement was not officially entered, however, as hearings between the SEC and the company have been held in private, away from reporters, in Judge Leon's chambers.  Bloomberg News reported that Judge Leon approved the civil settlement on 17 June 2013.GermanyThe action against Tyco brought by the German prosecutor's office has been resolved.  In the company's Form 10-K submitted to the SEC for the fiscal year ending 24 September 2010, it revealed that it had "reported to German authorities potentially improper conduct involving agents retained by the Company's [Europe, Middle East, and Africa] water business.  The company has since resolved this matter with German authorities. . .."  In addition, in the company's Form 10-Q filed on 31 January 2012, the company also reported that "in early 2007 certain former subsidiaries in the Company's Flow Control business were charged, prior to their divestiture, by the German Federal Cartel Office ('FCO') with engaging in anti-competitive practices, in particular with regard to its hydrant, valve, street box and fitting business. . . The Company cooperated with the FCO in its investigation and settled the matter during the first fiscal quarter of 2012."Italy This investigation is finished, according to Tyco's 10-K SEC report for the fiscal year ending on 9 September 2011.  The report reads as follows: "two subsidiaries in the Company's Flow Control business in Italy have been charged, along with numerous other parties, in connection with the Milan public prosecutor's investigation into allegedly improper payments made to certain Italian entities.  During the fourth quarter of 2011, the Company's subsidiaries were acquitted of these charges."

On August 6, 2010, Universal Corp.'s subsidiary, Universal Brazil, was charged with and pleaded guilty to FCPA violations related to bribes paid to Thai officials to secure contracts with the Thailand Tobacco Monopoly in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.  Under the plea agreement, Universal Brazil agreed to pay a USD 4.4 million criminal fine.  Additionally, Universal entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ under which the company agreed to retain a compliance monitor for a minimum of three years.  On the same day, Universal Corp. and Alliance One International, Inc. consented to the entry of final judgments  enjoining both companies from future violations of the anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions of the FCPA. In addition, Universal agreed to disgorge approximately USD 4.5 million in profits. [Please see a separate Compendium entry titled "Alliance One" for information regarding that company's settlement with the DOJ and SEC.]

On June 29, 2010, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Veraz consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Veraz was ordered to pay a $300,000 civil penalty.

On October 13, 2011, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Watts and Chang consented to the entry of a cease-and-desist order prohibiting them from violating the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  Watts agreed to pay USD 2,755,815 in disgorgement, USD 820,791 in prejudgment interest and a USD 200,000 civil penalty.  Chang agreed to pay a civil money penalty of USD 25,000.  The SEC recognized Watt's cooperation and remedial measures, which included ending commission-based compensation at CWV, implementing enhanced anti-corruption policies and procedures, and conducting a worldwide anti-corruption audit. In a later development, on 6 June 2012,Watts filed a suit against the law firm that had been responsible for vetting Watts Valve (Changsha) Co., Ltd.prior to its acquisition by Watts.  In the suit, Watts Water Technologies, Inc. v. Sidley Austin LLP, Superior Court for the District of Columbia, the company claims that it paid Sidley to perform due diligence in anticipation of the acquisition.  The law firm is alleged to have discovered a document describing the policy of paying kickbacks to Chinese officials, and to have failed to indicate the FCPA issues potentially raised by the payments.  Watts went ahead with the acquisition, but now claims that it would not have proceeded, had it been aware of the incentive program.  A second law firm hired by Watts in 2009 to investigate allegations of corruption received the damaging document from Sidley.  In the lawsuit, Watts is asking for at least USD 100,000 in damages plus legal fees.

Weatherford agreed to pay USD $65.6 million to the SEC in the global settlement, including a USD $1.875 million penalty assessed in part for lack of cooperation early in the investigation.  Weatherford agreed to pay USD $87 million in criminal fines to the Department of Justice for the FCPA violations, and USD $100 million to three other U.S. agencies for the sanctions violations.  The company agreed to retain an independent compliance monitor for 18 months and self-report to the SEC staff for an additional 18 months.

The SEC has closed its investigation without taking action.  It appears that the DOJ may have closed its investigation as well.  Wright Medical Group does not mention any further FCPA investigation in its SEC Form 10-K filed on 11 February 2011.
It is unclear whether the investigations are ongoing.  Xerox has not addressed the matter in recent public filings.

In its 10-K Form submitted to the SEC on 27 February 2013, Zimmer said that it has received formal notification from both the SEC and DOJ that the two agencies have finished their investigations and will not pursue any enforcement action. No additional details regarding specific reasons for the declinations were provided.

On 6 February 2012, a settlement was reached with the SEC whereby S&N; agreed to pay USD 5.4 million as disgorgement of profits.S&N; Inc. entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ on 6 February 2012, requiring the payment of a USD 16.8 million penalty, and implementation of rigorous internal controls, continued cooperation with the DOJ, and the retention of a compliance monitor for a period of 18 months.The DOJ noted its satisfaction with the company's cooperation in the investigation, and it expressed its acknowledgment for the assistance of the 8th Ordinary Interrogation Department of the Athens Court of First Instance and the Athens Economic Crime Squad in Greece.

On 4 October 2012, media reports revealed that a subpoena had been served by the French investigating magistrates.  Although there was no official confirmation, media sources pointed to Jasbir Singh Chahl as the possible recipient of the summons.  Jasbir was allegedly involved in the purchase of the Scorpene submarine.The investigation is ongoing.

On 29 April 2010, the World Bank debarred Macmillan for a six-year period.  The debarment may be reduced to three years subject to continued cooperation from the company and its remedial efforts.On 22 July 2011, Macmillan agreed to pay a GBP 11,263,852.28 civil recovery order under Part 5 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 in order to conclude the SFO investigation.  The company will also pay GBP 27,000 to cover the SFO costs of pursuing the order.   A compliance monitor was imposed for a 12-month period, who will report to the SFO and World Bank.The SFO highlighted Macmillan's cooperation and remedial efforts.

On 2 August 2010, Digi reported that received confirmation from the DOJ and SEC that the agencies would not be initiating any enforcement action against the company.  Digi's press release explained as follows: "As previously reported in the third fiscal quarter 2010 earnings release of July 22, 2010, after receiving allegations regarding possible violations of our gifts, travel and entertainment policy for activities in the Asia Pacific (APAC) region by a few employees, we initiated an investigation of these policy and corresponding internal control issues, and any possible related violations of applicable law, including the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA).  We voluntarily disclosed the allegations to the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) and the United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).  The investigation has been under the direction of the Audit Committee, comprised solely of independent directors, utilizing outside counsel, and focused on the APAC region.  For completeness purposes, the investigation reviewed certain other foreign regions where no allegations have been made.  We believed the investigation was substantially complete, pending input from the DOJ and the SEC.  We have been providing the DOJ and SEC with updates and our proposed remediation plan."Digi has now received confirmation through discussions with representatives of the DOJ and the SEC that they will not be initiating any enforcement proceedings against Digi, including not seeking any monetary or other sanctions. "Based upon what we have learned from the investigation, we are strengthening our monitoring controls over foreign locations and other operational and regulatory compliance procedures, including third party assistance in implementation of our remediation plan.   We are also evaluating any impact of this matter on our Internal Controls over Financial Reporting.  Based on the results of our investigation, we are not aware of any material impacts to our reported consolidated financial statements that would require restatement, and no issues were detected outside of the Asia Pacific region."In its SEC Form 10-K filed on 29 November 2010, Digi provided the following additional details regarding its investigation:"During the third quarter of fiscal 2010, we received allegations regarding possible violations of our gifts, travel and entertainment policy for activities in the Asia Pacific (APAC) region by a few employees. We initiated an investigation of these policy and corresponding internal control issues, and any possible related violations of applicable law, including the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA). We voluntarily disclosed the allegations to the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) and the United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The investigation was under the direction of the Audit Committee, comprised solely of independent directors, utilizing outside counsel, and focused on the APAC region. For completeness purposes, the investigation reviewed certain other foreign regions where no allegations had been made. We provided the DOJ and SEC with updates and our proposed remediation plan."We announced on August 2, 2010 that we received confirmation through discussions with representatives of the DOJ and the SEC that they would not be initiating any enforcement proceedings against Digi, including not seeking any monetary or other sanctions."The investigation identified violations of company policy that primarily involved three individuals in Hong Kong and our former Chief Financial Officer. The investigation also found an unsubstantiated accrued liability recorded in Hong Kong. All four individuals were terminated or had resigned from the company as of May 12, 2010. While we determined that no adjustment was required to our previously reported consolidated financial statements, we recorded an immaterial outâˆ’ofâˆ’period adjustment during the third quarter of fiscal 2010 in order to correct the unsubstantiated accrued liability in Hong Kong."Based upon what we learned from the investigation, we have and are further strengthening our monitoring controls over foreign locations and other operational and regulatory compliance procedures, including retention of third party assistance to enhance our controls. We incurred general and administrative expense of $1.4 million related to the cost of the investigation and remediation during fiscal 2010."

The charge against ACS was withdrawn by the Alberta Crown Prosecutor on 31 October 2006.  In November 2007, following a Preliminary Inquiry, the Provincial Court of Alberta dismissed all charges against PSS for the reasons enumerated in the attached ruling.  At the conclusion of the Preliminary Inquiry, the Alberta Crown Prosecutor had already advised the Court that he was withdrawing the allegation relating to the possibility of post-retirement employment.The Court found that there was no evidence and no reasonable inference that the alleged benefits were provided in to order to secure improper support for continuing the contract and that there was also no evidence and no reasonable inference that the conduct of the PSS employees at issue should be attributed to the company itself (no PSS employees were ever charged in connection with the matter).In separate proceedings in September 2007 and October 2008, after a full trial on the merits, the Edmonton police officers were also found innocent of any misconduct.

In 2002, the High Court of Lesotho found Sole guilty of accepting bribes from various multinational companies that were attempting to secure LHWP contracts.  In 2003, Sole's appeal was denied.  He is currently serving a 15-year prison term.In 2003, the High Court convicted Acres of bribery and fined the company ZAR 15 million.  In 2004, Acres was debarred by the World Bank for a three-year term.In 2003, the High Court convicted Lahmeyer of bribery and fined the company ZAR 10.6 million.  The company appealed against the conviction and on appeal the fine was increased to ZAR 12 million. In 2006, Lahmeyer was debarred from World Bank contracts for a seven-year term.  In August 2011, two years ahead of schedule, the World Bank removed Lahmeyer from its list of illegible firms in recognition of the company's improved compliance efforts.In 2003, Jacobus Michiel Du Plooy, an intermediary acting behalf of Impregilo, which was the lead partner of the consortium that built the main dam in the project, pleaded guilty to paying bribes to Sole on behalf of Impregilo. In exchange for cooperation with prosecutors, the High Court fined Du Plooy ZAR 500,000 and sentenced him to a conditionally suspended prison term.In 2004, Spie Batignolles (now Schneider Electric SA), the multinational French construction company responsible for building the transfer tunnels in the project, pleaded guilty to sixteen counts of bribery.  The High Court imposed a fine of ZAR 10 million.  [While Schneider Electric became legally liable for the offenses  allegedly committed by Spie Batignolles prior to the merger, it did not itself have any involvement in the matter.]In 2006, Impregilo pleaded guilty and was fined ZAR 15 million by the High Court.Lahmeyer assisted prosecutors in their case against two other Lesotho officials, Reatile Mochebelele and Letlafuoa Molapo, former delegates of Lesotho on the Highlands Water Commission.  Mochebelele and Molapo were initially acquitted by the High Court but then found guilty on appeal. Other multinational companies involved with the LHWP were initially investigated in connection with the Sole bribery scandal - including Sir Alexander Gibb and Company and Balfour Beatty of the UK, ABB of Switzerland, and Sogreah, Dumez, and Cegelec of France - but it appears that no formal charges were brought against these entities.

AlgeriaOn 6 June 2012,  employees of both Huawei and ZTE were convicted of bribery related to telephone company contracts in Algeria between 2003 and 2006.  The men, Mr. Xiao of Huawei and Mr. Chen and Mr. Dong of ZTE, were sentenced in absentia to ten years in prison, and fined USD 65,000, in a case concluded in Algiers by Judge Derbouchi.Mr. Boukhari, a former senior official with Algerie Telecom, and Mr. Madjdoub, a businessman who also holds Luxembourg citizenship, were found guilty of money laundering and mismanagement and received sentences of 18 years, along with a fine of USD 111,660, plus confiscation of any goods or wealth acquired during the period in question.Both companies, Huawei and ZTE, were fined, and have been debarred from bidding on public contracts in Algeria for two years.  It is the first time the Algerian government has ever banned a company from public tenders.  International warrants were issued for the arrest of the three Chinese employees.ZambiaThe Zambian government terminated its USD 210 million contract with ZTE as a result of the allegations.

An Italian court sentenced Maetz to a year and ten-month prison term.  Massimo De Carolis was sentenced to a three-year prison term.The Milan city government banned Vivendi Acqua from participating in the new bidding process.
The matter appears to be ongoing.

The investigations are ongoing; however, the head of the Czech Police stated at the outset that he does not believe the investigation could be successful because the alleged improper payments occurred "so long ago."

The investigations appear to be ongoing. In February 2011, the World Bank withdrew its funding for a Strabag-led consortium to lead the Nairobi Toll Road project over concerns related to the company's ability to meet integrity benchmarks.  It appears that the Chinese government will take over the funding for the Kenyan project.  It is not clear whether the World Bank's concerns were related to Strabag's activities in Rwanda, as discussed above.

SwitzerlandIn a 29 March 2012 press statement, SNC-Lavalin announced that Ben Aissa had been arrested in Switzerland, although specific details were unknown.  He has since been extradited to Canada to face charges there.On 13 April 2012, SNC-Lavalin announced that the RCMP had conducted another raid on its offices in connection with an investigation of "certain individuals who are no longer employed by the Company." The press report went on to say that the SNC-Lavalin is cooperating fully with the authorities but cannot comment on an ongoing investigation.In November 2012, Swiss prosecutors allegedly questioned Sami Bebawi, who served as manager of construction at SNC-Lavalin until January 2007.On 26 November 2012, Swiss authorities extended Riadh Ben Aissa's detention, as they sought to learn the destination of USD 139 million in funds deposited by SNC-Lavalin into accounts at a private bank, EFG, in Geneva.  According to a 25 November 2012 report in CBC News, Ben Aissa has been indicted in Switzerland on charges of money laundering and corruption.  CBC News also reports that a Swiss attorney associated with Ben Aissa (Roland Kaufmann) has been charged with money laundering and corruption for having set up two companies (Dinova and Duvel Securities) in the British Virgin Islands, which were involved in the money transfers.  CBC News says that a joint investigation is underway involving Canadian and Swiss authorities.  On 20 August 2014, Mr. Ben Aissa agreed to a deal with Swiss prosecutors that could lead to his extradition.  Switzerlandâ€™s Attorney-General's office said that Mr. Ben Aissa signed a plea deal with prosecutors on 4 August 2014, and a Swiss court is expected to rule on the plea deal in October.On 21 February 2013, Reuters reported that the Swiss authorities have extended their investigation to include SNC-Lavalin agent Farid Bedjaoui.  TunisiaVarious media reports in April 2012 revealed that SNC-Lavalin is under investigation by the Tunisian Commission of Inquiry into Corruption and Embezzlement regarding a CAD 320 million contract the company was awarded in 2010 with an Italian partner, Ansaldo Energia.India On 25 February 2011, it was reported that the Indian Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) Special Court had again issued a summons to SNC-Lavalin in connection with the corruption scandal in India's Kerala state.  The court reportedly has also issued an arrest warrant for Klaus Triendl, former Senior Vice President at SNC-Lavalin, and initiated steps to extradite him to India. According to press reports, the CBI's "SNC-Lavalin case" is ongoing.  According to these reports, on 11 July 2012, the CBI presented documentation to the Kerala court substantiating efforts taken to effect the extradition of Klaus Triendl, including contacts with the Union Minister of External Affairs, the High Commission of India in Canada and the Canadian Police authorities.  In 2013, the Kerala court reportedly split the trial between Klaus Triendl and CPI state secretary Pinarayi Vijayan.Canada On 3 September 2011, it was reported that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police ("RCMP") had initiated an investigation into the Company regarding alleged corruption involving a USD 1.2 billion World Bank loan for a USD 2.9 billion bridge project in Bangladesh and had executed several raids in Ontario.  In a press release on 6 September 2011, SNC-Lavalin confirmed the investigation.   On 11 April 2012, Mohammed Ismail, Director of International Projects at SNC-Lavalin Toronto and Ramesh Shah, former Vice President at SNC-Lavalin Toronto were charged with one count of violating the Corruption of Foreign Officials Act ("CFPOA").  The two men appeared in a Toronto court on 25 June 2012 in order to set a date for their preliminary hearing, which will take place in 2013.On 28 November 2012, the L'Unite permanente anticorruption ("UPAC"), Quebec's anti-corruption unit, announced that its Investigation Service had arrested Pierre Duhaime, former Chief Executive Officer of SNC-Lavalin, at his home that morning, on suspicion of conspiracy to commit fraud, fraud and use of false documents.  In the same press statement, UPAC announced that mutual assistance proceedings are underway between UPAC and authorities in Switzerland regarding Riadh Ben Aissa.The Star reported that Pierre Duhaime was formally charged with fraud on 11 February 2013, to which he pleaded not guilty.In September 2013, the RMPC charged Kevin Wallace, former Senior Vice President of SNC-Lavalin International Inc, Zulfiquar Ali Bhuiyan, a Canadian citizen with ties to business in Bangladesh and Abul Hasan Chowdrey, a prominent Bangladeshi lobbyist, have been charged for violating Canada's Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act related to the company's failed bid to oversee the building of the Padma Bridge in Bangladesh. Two lower-level SNC-Lavalin employees await trial in Toronto for similar allegations. On 21 January 2014, the RCMP in Montreal filed criminal charges against two former senior SNC-Lavalin executives. Mr. Roy, a former vice-president at SNC-Lavalin, was charged with fraud, bribing a foreign public official, and contravening a United Nations economic measures act related to Libya.  Mr. Bebawi was charged with fraud, two counts of laundering the proceeds of a crime, four counts of possession of property obtained by crime and one count of bribing a foreign public official.On 10 September 2014, police in Canada charged Mr. Kyres, a prominent lawyer who formerly headed the tax practice at the Montreal office of Dentons Canada LPP, for an alleged plot against a potential witness in connection with the SNC-Lavalin probe. Mr. Kyres was charged  with extortion and obstruction of justice, according to the Globe and Mail.  Mr. Kyres allegedly approached undercover police to obtain a statement from Riadh Ben Aissa, a former vice president of SNC-Lavalin who was in jail in Switzerland for money laundering, fraud, and corruption.  Sami Bebawi, another former senior SNC executive, was also charged with obstruction of justice on 10 September 2014. SNC Lavalin, claiming it was duped by its own executives, will recoup more than USD $13 million that was recovered in a bribery probe by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.On 19 February 2015, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police's (RCMP) National Division charged SNC Lavalin Group Inc., its division SNC-Lavalin Construction Inc. and its subsidiary SNC-Lavalin International Inc. with violating the Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act (CFPOA). The charges relate to CAN$47,689,868 (US$37,946,982) in alleged bribe payments made to Libyan officials between 2001 and 2013. A second count is for fraud of approximately CAN$130-million (US$103-million) related to construction projects in Libya, including the Great Man Made River Project.  BangladeshThe Bangladesh Anti-Corruption Commission ("ACC") initiated an investigation of the matter.  On 2 July 2012, the ACC questioned Ziaul Haque, a local agent of SNC-Lavalin.  In a World Bank press release dated 20 September 2012, it is noted that the World Bank "believes" the Bangladeshi government to have put all officials suspected of involvement in the alleged corruption on leave pending the outcome of the investigation. The Chairman of the ACC, Ghulam Rahman, alleged on 27 November 2012 that "[a]ttempts of bribery were made regarding the appointment of a consultant for the [Padma Bridge Project]."  Rahman also noted that World Bank investigators, who had visited Bangladesh in October, would return in early December 2012.Unconfirmed media reports on 18 December 2012 alleged that the ACC planned to issue a report accusing the former president of Candu Energy Inc. of conspiracy to bribe government officials. On 20 September 2012, the World Bank announced the conditional resumption of funding of the Padma Bridge Project.  Measures demanded by the World Bank include the introduction by Bangladesh of new procurement arrangements, with better oversight and transparency.  Bangladesh was also required to commit to the conduct of a "full and fair" investigation into the corruption allegations, and to allow the results of the investigation to be reviewed by an external panel, which will report its findings both to the Bangladeshi government and the World Bank.However, Bangladesh withdrew its request for World Bank funding for the Padma Bridge Project on 31 January 2013. The World Bank said on 1 February 2013 that Bangladesh's "letter to the World Bank confirms the authorities' intent to continue the investigation of alleged corruption related to the project. The World Bank has taken note of the government's decision of not seeking renewed World Bank financing for the Padma Bridge, and it encourages the Anti-Corruption Commission to complete a full and fair investigation of the corruption allegations."AlgeriaAccording to a CBC News report from 3 June 2013, police searched SNC-Lavalin's offices in Algiers. SNC-Lavalin's spokeswoman told CBC News that "the authorities have given us no details" about the investigation and that it "included a search of our offices with which we co-operated in order to assist the authorities to obtain whatever information is needed to resolve the matters in question."FranceThe investigation is ongoing.World Bank On 2 April 2012, the Company reported in a press release that "one of its subsidiaries received formal notice from the World Bank that the rights of that subsidiary to bid on new World Bank projects have been temporarily suspended." (By agreement, the other developments banks that were committed to funding portions of the project followed the World Bank suspension:  the Asian Development Bank (ADB) had pledged USD 610 million, Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) had committed USD 400 million and the Islamic Development Bank had promised USD 140 million.)   SNC-Lavalin acknowledged that the World Bank had issued an "Early Temporary Suspension" ("ETS").  Under the World Bank's Sanctions Procedures, an ETS may be issued prior to the conclusion of an investigation by the Bank's integrity vice presidency, if there is sufficient evidence to conclude that a sanctionable practice has occurred, and that the appropriate sanction for such misconduct is a minimum of two years' debarment. A temporary suspension prevents a company from being awarded new World Bank-financed contracts for an initial period of six months, subject to possible extension for an additional six months.On 29 June 2012, the World Bank issued the following press statement: "The World Bank has credible evidence corroborated by a variety of sources which points to a high-level corruption conspiracy among Bangladeshi government officials, SNC Lavalin executives and private individuals in connection with the Padma Multipurpose Bridge Project.  The World Bank provided evidence from two investigations to the Prime Minister, as well as the Minister of Finance and the Chairman of the Anti-Corruption Commission of Bangladesh (ACC) in September 2011 and April 2012. We urged the authorities of Bangladesh to investigate this matter fully and, where justified, prosecute those responsible for corruption.  We did so because we hoped the Government would give the matter the serious attention it warrants.  In Canada, where SNC Lavalin's headquarters are located, after executing numerous search warrants and a year-long investigation based on a referral from the World Bank, the Crown Prosecution Services brought corruption charges against two former SNC executives in connection with the Padma Bridge Project."On 17 April 2013, the World Bank announced that it reached a settlement with SNC-Lavalin Inc. regarding allegations of misconduct in two World Bank projects. The settlement includes a 10-year debarment for SNC-Lavalin Inc. and over 100 of its affiliates. These companies have been barred from bidding on World Bank-financed projects for the 10-year period due to "the company's misconduct in relation to the Padma Multipurpose Bridge Project in Bangladesh, as well as misconduct under another Bank-financed project." The press release stated that the other project is the Rural Electrification and Transmission Project in Cambodia. The period of debarment can be reduced to eight years based on the Company's compliance with the debarment agreement. It is important to note that this debarment does not include all SNC-Lavalin Group Inc. subsidiaries and affiliates. SNC-Lavalin Inc. and these 100-plus affiliates represent a significant portion of the Group's business, but not all of it. Subsidiaries and affiliates of SNC-Lavalin Group Inc. that are not included in the debarment may still bid for World Bank projects provided that they comply with the relevant rules and procedures.
ARGENTINAThe investigation appears to be ongoing. BRAZILThe investigation is ongoing.

On June 11, 2009, Gi-Hwan Jeong pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.  On November 10, 2009, he was sentenced to five years in prison and a ordered to pay a USD 50,000 fine.Jeong's co-conspirators in the AAFES were prosecuted as well.

On March 29, 2010, following a trial that was closed to the public, the Shanghai No. 1 Intermediate Peopleâ€™s Court found the four Rio Tinto employees guilty of accepting millions of dollars in bribes and stealing commercial secrets (there was no further mention of the initial charge that they paid bribes to Chinese officials).  The defendants were given sentences of between seven and fourteen years in prison and were ordered to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines.  Stern Hu received seven years in prison for bribery and five years for stealing commercial secrets, which the court then reduced to a total of ten years.  Wang Yong, Ge Minqiang and Liu Caikui appealed their convictions; their appeal was rejected by the Higher People's Court of Shanghai on May 17, 2010.At the time of the conviction of the Rio Tinto employees, the Shanghai No. 1 Intermediate Peopleâ€™s Court stated that it also planned to charge at least two Chinese steel industry officials with passing trade secrets to the company.  Shortly following their convictions, the four employees were terminated by Rio Tinto.

The matter is ongoing.  According to press reports in March 2011, Yang Fan and two Namibian officials involved in the case have raised a constitutional challenge to Namibia's Prevention of Organised Crime Act.
The investigations are ongoing.

Afghanistan's Anti-Corruption Tribunal sentenced Shaw to two years in prison and imposed a USD 25,000 fine (the same amount as the alleged bribe payment).  Shaw's co-defendant, Maiwand Limar, was also sentenced to two years, without a fine.G4S then raised the case with the Foreign & Commonwealth Office in London and the new British Ambassador in Kabul.On July 4, 2010, an Afghan appeals court overturned Shaw's conviction and sentence, citing lack of evidence.  He will continue to be held in prison until completion of various legal formalities.  Shaw has reportedly described his time in the Pul-e-Charki prison as "a living hell."On July 9, 2010, G4S announced that Bill Shaw had been released from the Pul-i-Charki prison.

The investigations appear to be ongoing. United StatesOn 23 May 2013, the Wall Street Journal reported that the SEC has initiated an investigation into the allegations of bribery involving Ericsson in Romania. ChinaMedia reports on 18 November 2012 stated that an equipment procurement officer from Ericsson had been questioned by Chinese authorities, as part of the investigation of Li Hua, general manager of the Sichuan office of China Mobile, and Chen Binglan, deputy general manager of the same branch.  Li and Chen are in custody.  Another Chinese executive, Shen Changfu, former director of the Chongqing Telecom Administration and subsequently general manager of China Mobile Chongqing, was detained in an investigation by the Chinese authorities of procurement contracts with foreign suppliers, including Ericsson. It is unclear whether Ericsson itself is a subject of the Chinese investigation.

According to press reports, on 27 March 2009, the 10th Criminal Bench at the Federal First Instance Court in Ethiopia found Miao Keyin guilty on two counts of importing undeclared goods and of bribing a customs officer.  He was sentenced to a 15-year prison term.  The company he worked for was unnamed.  The court also found Mesfin Zebene, an Ethiopian customs official, guilty of attempt to receive bribes and for failure to report to superiors on the inconsistency of the goods brought in and what was declared to customs on the commercial invoices.  He was sentenced to a 10-year prison term.

In 2004, Mexico's Ministry of Public Administration fined Areva MXN 341,100 and barred the company from participating in public tender procedures for two years.(Alstom, another French company, was similarly charged and penalized in connection with the matter.) There is no further information regarding the possible investigation of Areva or Areva executives by the Chinese authorities following the reported detention of the company's marketing director, Paul Felten, in 2009.  It appears that the government focused on enforcement of the Chinese officials at issue.  On 19 November 2010, Kang Rixin was convicted on corruption charges in Beijing's First Intermediary Court and sentenced to life in prison.The German investigation is ongoing.
The 2009 companies were fined a combined KRW 20.4 billion.  The 2011 companies were fined a combined USD 9.3 million.
The SFO investigation was closed without action.

In April 2012, charges were brought against three men over misusing Foreign Ministry development aid for the deals.  In May 2013, the former employees of Instrumentarium were acquitted of corruption charges stemming from a deal in Costa Rica more than a decade ago. The Helsinki District Court tossed dropped the charges in May 2013.

According to press reports, the Beijing Higher People's Court convicted the Mitsui employee for bribery and sentenced him to a two-year prison term, to be followed by deportation.  The bribe-recipients - the division head and the vice minister - were each sentenced to 13 years in prison in 2001 for their roles in the matter.

An Argentine court indicted the President of the Chamber of the Restaurant Tickets industry (Camara de Empresas de Servicios de Vales) who also used to be a Director of an Accor subsidiary in Argentina, as well as the Argentine middleman who offered the bribes.  It is unclear what came of these proceedings.  Both defendants asked for "diversion" but the Prosecutor, quoting the UNCAC, refused any sort of agreement and asked for trial.  The Court of Cassasion currently reviewing the defendant s motion. On 27 February 2008, the Argentine NCP accepted the case as a "specific instance."  The NCP forwarded the complaint to Accor Services and invited the company to engage in a NCP-facilitated mediation process.  Accor Services engaged in the process and the matter was successfully concluded with a negotiated agreement in March 2009.  The details of the mediated settlement were not made public, but it is understood Accor Services agreed to make a financial contribution to an Argentinean NGO - Poder Ciudadano (the Argentine chapter of Transparency International) - to support its transparency and anti-corruption program.  The amount of the contribution was USD 60,000, much lower than the complainant's request for a contribution equal to 5% of the bribe offered.  The agreement also included protection for the workers affected by the outcome of the case.

Mr. Hwang was sentenced to six years in prison and fined KRW 1,558,000,000 for receiving bribes in violation of the Act on the Aggravated Punishment, Etc. of Specific Economic Crimes and for offering bribes in violation of the Criminal Code. Mr. Chung (Representative Director of "Company K") was sentenced to one and a half years in prison for offering bribes in violation of the Act on the Aggravated Punishment, etc. of Specific Economic Crimes.Mr. Lee was sentenced to two and a half years in prison and fined KRW 35 million for bribery in violation of the Act on the Aggravated Punishment, Etc. of Specific Economic Crimes.Mr. Chung (KTX's Treasury Manager) was sentenced to two and a half years in prison with two years of probation and fined KRW 21,950,000 for bribery in violation of the Act on the Aggravated Punishment, Etc. of Specific Economic Crimes and the Criminal Code.Mr. Yang was handed a suspended jail sentence and fined KRW 2,508,903 for bribery in violation of the Criminal Code.(Other relevant persons were sentenced imprisonment of between one and a half years and five years.)
Lee was charged and sentenced to one year in prison by the Incheon District Court for his role in the conduct.  Neither CASA nor any CASA employee was charged in connection with the matter.

On 12 May 2010, Kosmos received a declination letter from the DOJ stating that the Department did not intend to take any enforcement action and had closed its inquiry into the matter.  On 2 June 2010, EO received a similar declination letter from the DOJ.In subsequent SEC filings, Kosmos does not mention any pending FCPA issues (for example, in SEC Form 10-K, filed 1 March 2012).It appears that Ghanaian authorities' investigation into EO (but not Kosmos) remains ongoing.Kosmos remains exposed to FCPA liabilities, however, as one of its partners in the Jubilee project is under investigation.  MODEC, the contractor for the floating production, storage and offloading ("FPSO") facility for the Jubilee Field Phase 1 development is reportedly under investigation "for certain potential FCPA violations by the Jubilee Unit partners and the syndicate of international banks who had committed to refinance the construction costs of the FPSO (a portion of such costs were originally loaned by the Jubilee Unit partners, including Kosmos)" (see Kosmos SEC Form S-1, dated 13 January 2011, attached).  Modec, however, issued a press release on 23 January 2011 stating that its internal investigation found no evidence of an FCPA violation (see attached press release).

SOUTH AFRICAN NATIONAL PROSECUTING AUTHORITYTony Yengeni was investigated in 2001 for receiving discounts on cars from Daimler Aerospace, which later became EADS. He pleaded guilty to one charge of fraud in 2003 and was sentenced to four years in prison; he served four months of his sentence.  The charge of corruption was dropped as a result of the plea bargain. Michael Woerfel, former Managing Director of EADS South Africa, was arrested and charged with corruption related to providing discounts on luxury vehicles to South African officials including Tony Yegeni. The charges against Mr. Woerfel were dropped in 2003 because the government had dropped the same charge against Mr. Yegeni. Schabir Shaik, former Director of Thomson-CSF South Africa Party Ltd. and a number of other companies including the Nboki group of companies, was convicted on June 2, 2005 on two charges of corruption and one charge of fraud. On June 5, 2005 Mr. Shaik was sentenced to 15 years in prison. On March 3, 2009, Mr. Shaik was paroled on medical grounds due to hypertension and high blood pressure after serving two years and four months in prison. According to a February 2009 report by the National Prosecuting Authority ("NPA"), the SFO was assisting the South African government with its investigation of BAE. The NPA declined to list potential targets of the investigation in the report.The NPA stated in its February 2009 report that it was still investigating the German Frigate Consortium and had requested information from the German government. It declined to list specific companies or individuals that were under investigation. The Directorate of Special Operations ("DSO") otherwise known as the Scorpions was the arm of the NPA responsible for investigating and prosecuting organized crime and corruption in South Africa. It was officially disbanded in late January 2009. For a while it was unclear whether the NPA has continued its investigations into the Arms Deal after the dissolution of the Scorpions.  On October 18, 2010, it was reported that the Police's Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation had formally closed the investigation based on the lack of admissible evidence. According to press reports on July 31, 2011, South African police reopened its investigation into Saab and were requesting assistance from Swedish and UK authorities.  The probe is now being led by the "Hawks", the new elite investigative squad of the police and successor to the "Scorpions".  According to press reports on September 15, 2011, President Zuma will be setting up a commission of inquiry to look into the broader scandal.
