According to press reports on October 27, 2011, the commission has been established with a $5 million, two-year budget and the panel of judges will have search and seize powers and the power to compel witnesses. NON-SOUTH AFRICAN INVESTIGATIONSThe UK Serious Fraud Office ("SFO") began investigating BAE's role in the South African Arms Deal in 2003, according to press reports. The SFO coordinated efforts with the NPA, including requesting the NPA to conduct a dawn raid on BAE's South African offices in November 2008. On February 5, 2010 the SFO entered into a settlement with BAE related to allegations of bribery and corruption in Tanzania, apparently declining to prosecute the company for bribery in South Africa. According to press reports, German authorities launched an investigation into Thyssen Krupp's alleged role in the South Africa bribery scheme related to the German Frigate Consortium. On June 18, 2006 the company announced that the investigation by German authorities had been closed without finding any evidence of corruption.  [See "German Frigate Consortium" summary.]
According to Sojitz officials, the DOJ advised the company in April 2012 that their investigation had been discontinued.

The UK investigation appears to be ongoing. Liberian President  Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf  named a three-person committee to investigate the matter.  On 20 October 2013, the Committee concluded that the CHC contract was a product of fraud and corruption.  The Committee found that several persons were involved in the scheme of bribery and corruption regarding the CHC contract, but most of them carefully concealed their activities that direct evidence is hard to obtain against them.

CanadaIn August 2013, Mr. Karigar was found guilty under the Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act for his role in planning to bribe Indian officials.  On 23 May 2014, Mr. Karigar was sentenced to three years in prison; his sentence is the first prison term for an individual convicted under Canada's anti-bribery law.On 5 June 2014, the RCMP charged Mr. Barra, Mr. Bernini, and Mr. Govindia with violating the Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act.  The RCMP alleged that the defendants were part of a failed bribery scheme by CryptoMetrics Canada to win a USD $100 million contract from Air India to supply facial-recognition software.

The DOJ declined to prosecute Smith & Wesson in June 2014 for its role in the Africa Sting Operation. In its Form 10-K filed on 19 June 2014, Smith & Wesson said the DOJ investigation caused it "to make substantial changes in our foreign sales personnel and foreign representatives, modify our processes, and cease sales in certain foreign countries." The changes have had "a material adverse effect" on foreign sales, the company said.On 28 July 2014, the SEC charged Smith & Wesson with violating the FCPA.  The company agreed to pay USD $2 million to settle the charges.  The company agreed to pay USD $107,852 in disgorgement, USD $21,040 in prejudgment interest, and a USD $1.906 million penalty.
The investigation remains ongoing.

On 5 March 2012, the Indian Ministry of Defence announced that it had barred six companies from contracting with the Indian military for ten years. The companies were Rheinmetall Air Defence AG ("RAD"), Israel Military Industries, Singapore Technologies Kinetics, Corporation Defence Russia, and two Indian companies, T.S. Kisan & Co. and R.K. Machine Tools.On 9 June 2012, an Indian businessman, Abhishek Verma and his wife, Anca Neacsu, were arrested and charged under the Prevention of Corruption Act with attempting to bribe government officials to prevent RAD from being blacklisted. Verma was accused of receiving USD 530,000 from RAD to influence Indian officials. The bribery charges could result in a prison sentence of up to five years.An American businessman and former partner of Verma provided information to the CBI, including a document evidencing a bank transfer of USD 530,000 from RAD to a New York bank account belonging to a company called Ganton Limited, which the CBI claims is owned by Verma. An earlier purchase order from RAD for consultancy services, reflects the same amount. The CBI claims that Verma initiated contact with RAD after the company was blacklisted for using corrupt and illegal means to obtain a contract for the provision of a 35 mm revolver gun air defense system. The company had hoped to forestall the debarment process so that the contract could be signed.

On 31 January 2011, JGC released a "Notice of Loss and Revision of Earnings Forecasts for Fiscal Year Ending March 2011," stating that it had set aside JPY 17.8 billion (approx. USD $218.4 million) in anticipation of settlement with the DOJ.  The company also set aside JPY 2.3 billion (USD $28.2 million) for settlement with the Nigerian authorities.On 6 April 2011, the DOJ filed a two-count criminal information charging JGC with with one count of conspiracy and one count of aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA.  JGC entered into a two-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a USD $218.8 million criminal fine and to retain an independent compliance consultant for a two-year term. African Development BankOn 21 March 2014, the African Development Bank levied a USD $5.2 million fine against JGC for corrupt practices in connection to contracts for natural gas production plants on Bonny Island, Nigeria from 1995 until 2004.

On 27 July 2010, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, GE, Ionics and Amersham consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the companies from future violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  GE was ordered to disgorge USD 18,397,949 in wrongful profits, pay USD 4,080,665 in pre-judgment interest and pay a civil penalty of USD 1,000,000.According to GE, the DOJ notified the company that it had closed its investigation and would take no action relating to these matters.

USOn 22 October 2013, Diebold agreed to pay more than USD $48 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest to settle the SECâ€™s charges and resolve a parallel criminal matter announced by the DOJ.  The company agreed to pay a USD $25.2 million fine and enter a three-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ to resolve charges that it violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act between 2005 and 2010.  It will also pay USD $22.9 million to resolve related SEC civil charges. Both settlements call for the company to appoint an independent compliance monitor.  The total amount of the two settlements is approximately USD $48 million.

On 28 February 2014, Merck announced that the DOJ closed its investigation into Merck related to the companyâ€™s activities in other countries concerning possible violations of the FCPA.The SEC investigation appears to be ongoing.

The investigations are ongoing.  On 17 March 2014, SciClone said it reserved USD $2 million for penalties related to the ongoing FCPA probe.  While the company said that a settlement of that size was "probable," it didn't not have any prediction about the exact fines that could be imposed or the timing of a resolution.
The investigation is ongoing.

On 6 February 2012, Orthofix reached an Agreement in Principle with the DOJ to settle the FCPA claims.  The company will set aside an additional accrual of $4.5 million during the 4th quarter of 2011 to anticipate the proposed criminal and civil resolution.  The agreement also includes a resolution of the qui tam claim filed by Susan Hutcheson against Blackstone and Orthofix in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.  In the Company's 8-K filing on 10 July 2012, definitive agreements with the DOJ and SEC are described:  "On July 10, 2012, Orthofix International N.V. (the ' Company ') entered into definitive agreements memorializing the previously disclosed agreement in principle previously reached with the Department of Justice (the 'DOJ') and Securities and Exchange Commission (the ' SEC ') regarding the Company's self-initiated and self-reported internal investigation of its Mexican subsidiary, Promeca S.A. de C.V. (' Promeca '), into allegations of non-compliance by Promeca with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (' FCPA ').  As part of the settlement of this matter, the Company has entered into (i) a consent to final judgment (the ' SEC Consent ') with the SEC and (ii) a deferred prosecution agreement (the ' DPA ') with the DOJ."Under the terms of the SEC Consent, the Company will settle civil claims related to this matter by voluntarily disgorging profits to the United States government in an amount of $5,225,701, inclusive of pre-judgment interest.  The Company has also agreed to pay a fine of $2,220,000 to the United States government pursuant to the terms of the DPA.  The Company previously recorded charges of $3.0 million during the first quarter of 2011 and $4.5 million during the fourth quarter of 2011 to establish an accrual in anticipation of a future final resolution of these matters with both the DOJ and the SEC.  The Company expects to make these settlement payments in the third fiscal quarter of 2012."As part of the DPA, which has a term of 3 years, the DOJ has agreed not to pursue any criminal charges against the Company in connection with this matter if the Company complies with the terms of the DPA.  The DPA takes note of the Company's self-reporting of this matter to the DOJ and the SEC, and of remedial measures, including the implementation of an enhanced compliance program, previously undertaken by the Company.  The DPA provides that the Company shall continue to cooperate fully with the DOJ in any future matters related to corrupt payments, false books and records or inadequate internal controls.  In that regard, the Company has represented that it has implemented and will continue to implement a compliance and ethics program designed to prevent and detect violations of the FCPA and other applicable anti-corruption laws.  The Company will periodically report to the DOJ during the term of the DPA regarding such remediation and implementation of compliance measures."In addition, under the terms of the SEC Consent, the Company will periodically report to the SEC during a 2-year term regarding the status of such remediation and implementation of compliance measures."The SEC Consent and the DPA do not provide for the appointment of any independent external monitor by the DOJ or the SEC."

On 15 September 2010, the DOJ indicted the two intermediaries, Enrique Faustino Aguilar Noriega and Angela Maria Gomez Aguilar, both of Cuernavaca, Mexico, for the alleged illegal payments to the CFE officials.  Enrique Aguilar was charged with conspiracy to violate the FCPA, substantive FCPA violations, conspiracy to commit money laundering and money laundering.  He remains a fugitive.  Angela Aguilar was charged with conspiracy to commit money laundering and money laundering.  She was arrested on 10 August 2010 on a criminal complaint when she traveled to Houston from Mexico, and then was ordered detained and removed to the Central District of California where she remains in custody. On 21 October 2010, Keith Lindsey, Steve Lee and Lindsey Manufacturing were charged in an eight-count superseding indictment with conspiracy to violate the FCPA and substantive FCPA violations.  The superseding indictment also charged the Aguilars, replacing the charges initially laid on 15 September 2010.  Enrique Aguilar was charged with the conspiracy to violate the FCPA and substantive FCPA violations, while Enrique and Angela Aguilar each were charged with conspiracy to commit money laundering and money laundering.  The judge dropped the substantive money laundering charge against Angela Aguilar on 9 May 2011.The FCPA conspiracy charge carried a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 250,000 or twice the value gained or lost, while each of the four FCPA counts carried a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 100,000 or twice the value gained or lost.  The conspiracy and substantive money laundering counts each carried a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a fine of the greater of USD 500,000 or twice the value of the property involved in the transaction.  The indictment also provided notice of criminal forfeiture.On 10 May 2011, after just a day of deliberations, the jury in the U.S. District Court, Central District of California handed down guilty verdicts on all counts against all of the defendants on trial in this case.  Angela Aguilar was convicted of one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering.  Lindsey Manufacturing, Keith Lindsey, and Steve Lee were each convicted of one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and five substantive FCPA violations.Following the verdict, the attorney for Lindsey Manufacturing and Keith Lindsay stated that they would continue to pursue their motion to dismiss the indictment on grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.In December 2011, U.S. District Judge Howard Matz issued an order vacating the convictions and dismissing with prejudice the case against Lindsey Manufacturing, Keith Lindsey and Steve Lee.  The decision was based on a finding of prosecutorial misconduct, described as follows:"the Government team allowed a key FBI agent to testify untruthfully before the grand jury, inserted material falsehoods into affidavits submitted to magistrate judges in support of applications for search warrants and seizure warrants, improperly reviewed e-mail communications between one Defendant and her lawyer, recklessly failed to comply with its discovery obligations, posed questions to certain witnesses in violation of the Court's rulings, engaged in questionable behavior during closing argument and even made misrepresentations to the Court."  The dismissal of the indictment with prejudice means that the defendants cannot be tried again for the same offenses. Prosecutors appealed the dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.  But on 25 May 2012, the DOJ filed a motion for voluntary dismissal of the appeal, ending the case as regards Lindsey Manufacturing, Keith Lindsay, and Steve Lee.
The investigation is ongoing.
The DOJ and SEC investigations are ongoing.
As discussed above, CBRE has concluded its internal investigation and the DOJ and SEC closed their inquiries without taking enforcement action against the company.

In the Company's SEC Form 10-Q filed on 24 November 2012, the original FCPA disclosure statement was repeated, followed by: "In October 2012, Schlumberger was advised by the DOJ that it has closed its inquiry as it relates to Schlumberger."

In its SEC Form 10-Q filed on 27 July 2012, the Company described the closure by the DOJ of its FCPA investigation:"During 2012, the DOJ informed us that it has closed its inquiry into the matter but indicated that it could reopen its inquiry in the future in the event it were to receive additional information or evidence. We have not received an update from the SEC concerning the status of its inquiry."As noted, the SEC investigation may be ongoing.

In April 2010, the SFO charged Messent with two counts of corruption in violation of section 1(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act 1906.  On October 22, 2010, he pleaded guilty in Southwark Crown Court.On October 26, 2010, Messent was sentenced to 21 months imprisonment and ordered to pay GBP 100,000 in restitution to the Republic of Costa Rica.  If Messent fails to make the restitution, he must serve an additional 12 months imprisonment.  He was also disqualified from acting as a company director for a period of five years.Costa Rican authorities have an ongoing domestic bribery investigation into the government officials at issue.
The investigation is ongoing.

In its SEC Form 10-Q filed on 1 August 2012, the Company announced that the FCPA investigation had been closed:  "In May 2012, the SEC and DOJ notified us that they would not recommend any enforcement action be taken against our Company in this matter."

On 16 May 2013, China-based Rino International Corp. and two of its executives agreed to settle a lawsuit with U.S. regulators over allegations that the executives looted more USD $3.5 million in company assets and violated the accounting provisions of a U.S. anti-bribery law.The executives, Dejun Zou and Jianping Qiu, who are husband and wife, agreed to pay at least that much money to resolve  additional allegations that they schemed to overstate the revenue of China-based manufacturer of water-treatment equipment, according to court documents. Qiu is the companyâ€™s chairman and Zou is the chief executive.Qiu and Zou  neither admitted nor denied the charges and also agreed to pay $100,000 and $150,000 in civil fines, respectively. The pair couldnâ€™t be reached for comment.The couple allegedly used the looted corporate funds to buy a California home, cars and designer clothing, and falsely recorded the expenditures in the companyâ€™s books and records, according to the court documents. The alleged false accounting violated the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which prohibits bribes to foreign officials and requires accurate books and records to be kept. The pair allegedly violated the books and records provisions, but not the bribery provisions.

U.S. On 15 August 2014, the company announced that the DOJ declined to prosecute the company for FCPA violations.  The company previously accrued a reserve of USD $10.4 million for settlement of the DOJ and SEC investigations but reduced the reserve to USD $5.3 million following the declination.  On 27 October 2014, Layne Christensen agreed to pay USD $5.1 million to the SEC to resolve allegations that the company made improper payments to foreign officials in several African countries in order to obtain beneficial treatment and reduce its tax liability.  The SECâ€™s order found that Layne Christensen violated the anti-bribery, books and records, and internal controls provisions of the FCPA.  The company agreed to pay USD $3,893,472.42 in disgorgement plus USD $858,720 in prejudgment interest as well as a USD $375,000 penalty that credited Layne Christensenâ€™s self-reporting, remediation, and significant cooperation with the SECâ€™s investigation.  For a period of two years, the settlement requires the company to report to the SEC on the status of its remediation and implementation of measures to comply with the FCPA.  Layne Christensen consented to the order without admitting or denying the SECâ€™s findings.

According to press reports on 19 January 2011, Swedish prosecutors called Scania's Chief Executive Officer, Leif Oestling, in for questioning in connection with the matter.  In June 2011, Oestling filed a complaint with Sweden's Chancellor of Justice (Justitiekanslern), alleging that the prosecutor illegally leaked confidential information about the investigation, and damaged Oestling's reputation.  Oestling was eventually not charged, and on 5 May 2011, his contract as President and CEO of Scania was extended through 31 March 2015.

On December 15, 2010, Weir pleaded guilty in the High Court in Edinburgh to two charges of breaching U.N. sanctions.  The company was ordered to pay a GBP 3 million fine and to repay the GBP 13,945,962 in benefits derived from contracts obtained through the kickback arrangement.  The repayment amount was secured under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (POCA).
The matter remains ongoing.

DOJ InvestigationOn 22 February 2012, attorneys from the Department of Justice stated that the investigation into whether Allianz SE violated the FCPA or other bribery laws in Indonesia had been closed, and that the DOJ did not intend to take any enforcement action. SEC InvestigationInitially, the media reported allegations an Allianz joint venture paid bribes to win contracts to insure big infrastructure projects in Indonesia and whether the printing equipment maker paid bribes in Europe and elsewhere.  But prosecuting the potential violations proved very difficult for the SEC: although Allianz Capital Partners owns a majority stake in manroland AG (about 60%), the holdings are passive, and Allianz does not exercise day-to-day control and therefore, under  German law, cannot compel manroland to give documents to the SEC. Moreover, since the entity that allegedly paid the bribes in Indonesia is a Swiss subsidiary of Allianz' German subsidiary, the corporate connection between the companies is further removed.  And even Allianz is no longer listed on a U.S. stock exchange. On 17 December 2012, the SEC charged Allianz with FCPA books and records and internal controls violations, based on Allianz' alleged payments to Indonesian officials over the course of seven years.  Utama, a majority-owned subsidiary of Allianz, made improper payments to foreign officials to obtain or retain government insurance contracts, and recorded the payments as legitimate transaction costs. Since Utama's financial statements were consolidated into Allianz's financial statement, Allianz violated Section 13(b)(2)(A) of the Exchange Act, which requires issuers to keep accurate books, records and accounts.  Allianz also failed to devise and maintain an effective system of internal controls sufficient to provide reasonable assurances that improper payments were not being made by its subsidiary, thereby violating Section 13(b)(2)(B) of the Exchange Act, which requires issuers to devise and maintain a sufficient system of internal accounting controls.In its Offer accompanying the SEC Cease and Desist Order, the Company agreed to pay USD 5,315,649 in disgorgement and USD 1,765,125 in prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty of USD 5,315,649.
The investigation appears to be ongoing.  BJ Services was acquired by Baker Hughes Inc. in March 2010.

USOn 3 November 2014, Bio-Rad agreed to pay USD $55.1 million to the SEC and DOJ to resolve allegations that the companyâ€™s subsidiaries in Russia, Vietnam, and Thailand violated the anti-bribery and books and records provisions of the FCPA by allegedly making improper payments totaling USD $7.5 million.  The U.S. authorities estimate that the illicit payments enabled Bio-Rad to receive USD $35 million in unlawful profits.  The company agreed to pay USD $40.7 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest to the SEC, and a USD $14.35 million criminal fine to the DOJ. The company must report its FCPA compliance efforts to the DOJ for a period of two years.VietnamOn 6 November 2014, Vietnam announced that it was launching an investigation into improper payments made by Bio-Rad.  InternalThe company said it completed an internal investigation on 17 March 2014 and found "likely" violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions and its own internal policies.

The DOJ and SEC closed their investigations without taking any enforcement action.  Cameron explained as follows in its SEC Form 10-Q filed on 1 August 2011:"In July 2007, the Company was one of a number of companies to receive a letter from the Criminal Division of the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) requesting information on activities undertaken on their behalf by a customs clearance broker. The DOJ inquired into whether certain of the services provided to the Company by the customs clearance broker may have involved violations of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA). The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) also conducted an informal inquiry into the same matter."Following a review of the investigation conducted by the Companyâ€™s special counsel and a number of follow-up meetings, both the DOJ and SEC have notified the Company they do not intend to pursue enforcement action against the Company with regard to this matter and their respective files have been closed."Likewise, in the Company's SEC Form 10-Q Quarterly Report filed on 2 November 2011, the Company reported, "The Company has recently concluded an investigation into possible FCPA violations in connection with importation of equipment and supplies into Nigeria in response to inquiries by the Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission."
The SEC investigation appears to still be open.
The SEC investigation was closed with no action.
The investigation is ongoing.

On April 1, 2011, Fuchs and Frenkiel were convicted by the Tbilisi City Court.  Fuchs was sentenced to seven years in prison and fined USD 300,000.  Frenkiel received six years in prison and a USD 60,000 fine. The two men are appealing.
The investigation is ongoing.
The investigation is ongoing.
The investigations are ongoing.

On February 10, 2011, the DOJ filed a criminal information in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia charging Tyson Foods with conspiracy to violate the FCPA and substantive violations of the FCPA.  Tyson Foods entered into a two-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a USD 4 million criminal fine, implement rigorous internal controls and cooperate fully with the DOJ.  On the same day, Tyson Foods, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, consented to the entry of a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from future violations of the FCPA's anti-bribery, books and records and internal controls provisions.  Tyson Foods agreed to disgorge more than USD 1.2 million in profits and pre-judgment interest.

In the Form 10-K it submitted to the SEC on 14 February 2013, 3M said that both the DOJ and SEC told the Company in January 2013 that they are terminating their investigations of the FCPA allegations. The agencies said that they would bring no action against 3M and that the Company would not be liable for any fines. According to 3M, the DOJ said that some of the reasons for its decision were "the Companyâ€™s voluntary disclosure and cooperation, the Companyâ€™s thorough investigation, and the steps the Company has taken to enhance its anti-corruption compliance program."

United StatesOn 5 April 2013, the SEC announced that it reached a settlement with Philips regarding the FCPA allegations against Philips Polska. Philips agreed to pay USD 4,515,178 (disgorgement of USD 3,120,597 and prejudgment interest of USD 1,394,581) as part of the settlement. The SEC's cease-and-desist order says that Philips violated the books and records and internal accounting controls provisions of the FCPA. The DOJ's investigation appears to be ongoing.PolandOn 17 May 2011, the Associated Press reported that 23 Polish citizens, including two former employees of Philips Polska, had been indicted on corruption charges. The two Philips Polska employees were apparently the former head of the medical section and the former regional director.  Their names were given as "Krzysztof B." and "Marian R." These former employees could face up to 12 years in prison. Sixteen public hospital directors were alleged to be involved, and they could face 10 years in prison for accepting the bribes. On 16 November 2011, the Wall Street Journal reported that the trial for these 23 individuals began that day in Poland. Also, the article stated that three former Philips Polska employees were among the 23 individuals indicted.

The SFO commenced an investigation which led to Al-Hassan's arrest in September 2008.  He was charged August 2009 and pleaded guilty to all charges on 13 January 2011.  On 25 January 2011, Al-Hassan was sentenced to 16 months imprisonment, suspended for two years.The UK made the breach of United Nation sanctions on Iraq a criminal offense by legislation implemented in 1990 and 2000.  Al-Hassan pleaded guilty to offenses under the legislation implemented in 2000 - i.e., The Iraq (United Nations Sanctions) Order 2000 (Statutory Instrument 3241) - which made it a criminal offense to make funds available to the Iraqi Government without a license granted by HM Treasury.

The SFO commenced an investigation which led to the arrest of El-Taher in August 2008.  He was charged in August 2009 and pleaded guilty to all charges on January 13, 2011.  On February 25, 2011, El-Taher was sentenced to 10 months in jail.  The UK made the breach of United Nation sanctions on Iraq a criminal offence in by legislation implemented in 1990 and 2000.  El-Taher pleaded guilty to offences under the legislation implemented in 2000 - i.e., The Iraq (United Nations Sanctions) Order 2000 (Statutory Instrument 3241) - which made it a criminal offence to make funds available to the Iraqi Government without a licence granted by HM Treasury.
The investigation is ongoing.

On 7 April 2011, CTI entered into a two-year non-prosecution agreement with the DOJ, agreeing to pay a USD 1.2 million criminal fine. CTI agreed to cooperate with the DOJ's ongoing investigation and to implement rigorous internal controls.On the same day, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, CTI consented to a final judgment permanently enjoining the company from violations of the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.  CTI consented to pay USD 1.6 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.

Both the DOJ and the SEC investigations are closed.  In its SEC Form 10-Q filed on 27 July 2012, the Company reported:"On April 24, 2012, the Company received a letter from the DOJ notifying the Company that the DOJ has closed its inquiry into the Company regarding possible violations of the FCPA and does not intend to pursue enforcement action against the Company. The DOJ indicated that its decision to close the matter was based on, among other factors, the thorough investigation conducted by the Company's special counsel and the Company's compliance program."At the time, Hercules noted that "[t]he Company, through the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors, intends to continue to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation. At this time, it is not possible to predict the outcome of the SEC's investigation, the expenses the Company will incur associated with this matter, or the impact on the price of the Company's common stock or other securities as a result of this investigation."However, in its SEC Form 8-K filed on 8  August 2012, the Company gave notice that the SEC had also closed its investigation as of 7 August 2012:  "On August 7, 2012, Hercules Offshore, Inc. (the 'Company') received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC') notifying the Company that the SEC staff has completed its investigation into the Company regarding possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act ('FCPA') and does not intend to pursue enforcement action against the Company. . . ."As a result of the termination by the SEC and the prior termination by the DOJ, there are no open FCPA investigations against the Company."

The SFO charged Mark Jessop in November 2009.  On 13 April 2011, in Southwark Crown Court, Jessop pleaded guilty and admitted to ten counts of engaging in activities to make funds available to the Iraqi Government in contravention of The Iraq (United Nations Sanctions) Order 2000 (Statutory Instrument 3241), which made it a criminal offense to do so without a license granted by HM Treasury.  He was sentenced to 24 weeks imprisonment and ordered to pay GBP 150,000 to the Development Fund for Iraq and pay prosecution costs of GBP 25,000.

According to the indictment, the defendants allegedly bribed Muammar Gaddafi's oil minister and relatives of an official in India's Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers. On 14 April 2014, Mr. Reitan stepped down from his position as chairman at Yara following the bribery fine.
