PTC noted that it has received no indication from the U.S. Department of Justice regarding the status of its investigation of FCPA allegations.In its SEC Form 10-Q filed on 6 May 2014, PTC confirmed that the SEC and DOJ investigations are still ongoing, and both offices continue to request information from the company.

UNITED KINGDOMOn 10 January 2013, April Casburn, formerly the Detective Chief Inspector in the Metropolitan Police's counter-terrorist financing unit, was convicted in Southwark Crown Court of misconduct in public office, for accepting money in exchange for confidential information about the phone-hacking investigation of News of the World. On 14 March 2013, the Wall Street Journal reported that police in the UK had arrested four journalists, bringing the total number of arrests of journalists and police officers in the UK's investigation of News Corp. to 116. The Wall Street Journal reported on the same day that prosecutors announced plans to charge one police officer, James Bowes, for releasing information in exchange for money. On 20 March 2013, the Wall Street Journal reported that Geoff Webster, deputy editor of The Sun (a News Corp. tabloid), had been charged with two offenses of "conspiring to commit misconduct in public office." The charges stem from allegations that Webster authorized bribes to police officers in order to acquire information. The Guardian reported on 24 April 2013 that Duncan Larcombe, chief royal correspondent for The Sun, was charged with bribing a sergeant of a British military academy (where Prince Harry and Prince William had spent part of their military training) and his wife in order to acquire information about the royal family. The Guardian said that 34 bribes totaling approximately GBP 23,000 were allegedly made between 2006 and 2008. On 26 February 2014, three reporters at News Corp.â€™s Sun tabloid and two former police officers were arrested by the Crown Prosecution Service.  On 12 August 2014, Mr. France, a crime reporter for News Corp subsidiary based out of the U.K., The Sun, was charged by the Crown Prosecution Services with allegedly paying public officials for information.  Mr. France allegedly made improper payments to police officer Timothy Edwards between March 2008 and July 2011, and July 2009 and August 2009 respectively.In 2014, two former News of the World editors, Andy Coulson and Clive Goodman, were on trial for charges related to their alleged payments to police officers for royal phone directories. The jury was unable to reach a verdict, and a retrial will begin in June 2015.On 5 November 2014, a former journalist for News of the World was convicted of conspiracy to commit misconduct in public office. The charges against the journalist were related to his or her payments to a prison officer for information about a murderer. That person's identity cannot be disclosed for legal reasons.On 16 January 2015, Mr. John Edwards and Mr. Troup were acquitted by a jury at Kingston crown court of conspiring to commit misconduct in public office.  Mr. Troup had been charged with paying an unknown prison official at HMP Whitemoor in November 2007 for a story about a suicide there.  During the trial, it emerged that the four-paragraph story had not been written by Mr. Troup, and there was no evidence as to whether the payment was made.Mr. Edwards was cleared of two charges: that he conspired with Pharo, Pyatt and Oâ€™Driscoll over payments to the Surrey police officer Simon Quinn, and that he was involved with them in a second conspiracy in connection with leaks from Broadmoor high-security hospital.On 20 March 2015, Fregus Shanahan, executive editor of The Sun (a News Corp. subsidiary), Geoff Webster, the Sun's deputy editor, John Kay, the Sun's former chief reporter, and Duncan Larcombe, a reporter, were found not guilty of charges of conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office. The charges stem from allegations that they had authorized bribes to police officers in order to acquire information. UNITED STATESThe DOJ informed News Corp. on 28 January 2015 that its investigation was complete and it would not be prosecuting the company.

In total, ADM paid approximately USD $54.3 million to the U.S. government to settle the FCPA violations.The U.S. Department of Justice announced on 20 December 2013 a non-prosecution agreement with ADM.  ACTI Ukraine paid a criminal fine of USD $17.8 million to the DOJ. The SECâ€™s complaint charged ADM with violating Sections 13(b)(2)(A) and 13(b)(2)(B) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  ADM consented to the entry of a final judgment on 23 December 2013 ordering the company to pay disgorgement of USD $33,342,012 plus prejudgment interest of USD $3,125,354.  The final judgment permanently enjoined ADM from violating those sections of the Exchange Act, and required the company to report on its FCPA compliance efforts for a three-year period.  The SEC took into account ADMâ€™s cooperation and significant remedial measures, including self-reporting the matter, implementing a comprehensive new compliance program throughout its operations, and terminating employees involved in the misconduct.
The investigation is ongoing.

India AllegationsThe SEC filed a complaint against Oracle in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on 16 August 2012, alleging that between 2005 and 2007, employees of Oracle India set aside some of the proceeds from sales of software to the government of India, allowing the money to be used for bribery or embezzlement.  Over a dozen transactions were structured in this way, and USD 2.2 million were set aside.The senior Channel Sales Manager for Oracle India resigned in November 2007.  Following an audit by Oracle's  Asia Division, four other Oracle India employees were dismissed for allowing or actively participating in Oracle India to set aside funds through its distributors.Once the problem of the â€œparked fundsâ€ù was discovered by Oracle, the Company conducted additional due diligence on its partner transactions in India, creating greater transparency; the Company terminated its relationship with the suspect distributor, and instructed other distributors not to allow funds to be set aside.  Oracle also enhanced its anti-corruption training programs.The SEC requests that the court enjoin further books and records violations by the Company, and that Oracle be made to pay a civil monetary penalty pursuant to Section 21(d)(3) of the Exchange Act [15 U.S.C. Section 78u(d)(3)].On the same day the SEC Complaint was filed, the Company agreed to pay a civil penalty of USD 2 million to settle the charges.  Oracle neither admitted nor denied the allegations.In announcing the settlement, the SEC noted, "The settlement takes into account Oracle's voluntary disclosure of the conduct in India and its cooperation with the SEC's investigation, as well as remedial measures taken by the company, including firing the employees involved in the misconduct and making significant enhancements to its FCPA compliance program."Other AllegationsThe investigation is ongoing.  Oracle has yet to make a public announcement confirming or denying the press reports.  For example, in Oracle's SEC Form 10-Q filed on 23 March 2012, there is no mention of an FCPA investigation.

CroatiaSanader was arrested in Austria in December 2010, and extradited to Croatia in July 2011.  After a trial in the district court in Zagreb, on 20 November 2012, Sanader  was sentenced to ten years in prison, having been found guilty of bribery and abuse of power involving two both Mol Nyrt and the Hypo Alpe Adria Bank International AG, an Austrian bank.  On 20 and 21 November 2012, MOL issued press releases denying any wrongdoing, and suggesting that factual misconceptions would be corrected. On 31 March 2014, prosecutors in Croatia indicted the chief executive of MOL Group for bribing a former prime minister in order to gain control of a Croatian energy company.  Mr. Hernadi allegedly paid 10 million euros (approximately USD $13.7 million) to former Croatian prime minister Ivo Sanader to secure "a dominant influence" in the country's state-run oil and gas group, INA. HungaryIn January 2013, Hungarian prosecutors confirmed that MOL and its officials played no role in an alleged bribery case related to MOL and Croatia's oil concern INA after officially closing the investigation.
According to Reuters, Fakhre's bribery trial began on 30 May 2013 and ended the following day. On 20 June 2013, Fakhre was released from custody on the previous day.

CubaAs of 30 June 2014, Cuban prosecutors are seeking a 15-year prison term for Mr. Tokmakjian, and 12-year sentences for Mr. Puche and Mr. Vetere.  The three Canadian defendants were held for nearly 2 1/2 years before being charged.  Cuban authorities publicly revealed details of the trial with an account in the Communist Party daily Granma, which said the evidence phase of the trial lasted from 9 June 2014 to 21 June 2014 at a criminal court in Havana.
The Star reported on 13 June 2013 that Sarkis Yacoubian has been sentenced to nine years of prison.
The matter is ongoing.

The investigation is ongoing. In June 2012, media sources reported that the CBI was split over whether to transform a preliminary corruption inquiry against former Director General of Hydrocarbons VK Sibal into formal criminal charges.  It was reported that the joint director for the anti-corruption division as well as the Directorate of Prosecution had recommended that a criminal case be filed against Sibal, his subordinates at the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) and Reliance Industries for the grant of undue favors under the production-sharing contract for the KG D6 gas block.

The investigations are ongoing.As of 4 September, an Olympus news report stated that, "[h]aving completed its investigation, the SFO has decided to bring a prosecution against the Company and Gyrus Group Limited, a UK subsidiary of the Company (â€œGGLâ€ù) on charges of breaching Section 501 of the UK Companies Act of 2006. The Company and GGL received requisitions issued by the SFO on September 3, 2013.After a hearing date before the Magistratesâ€™ Court, it is expected that the matter will betransferred to the Crown Court for the future steps of the proceedings." Olympus reports that it is difficult to predict the outcome of the matter or the estimated amount of fines that may be imposed.

In October 2011, Bruce Allen Hall, former CEO of Alba, was extradited from Australia and charged in London on 15 February 2012 with violations of the Prevention of Corruption Act and the Proceeds of Crime Act. Victor Dahdeleh and co-defendent Bruce Allen Hall appeared in Southwark Crown Court on 2 March 2012.  Neither entered a plea.  Judge Alistair McCreath set conditions of their bail, including twice-weekly appearance at the local police station, and the a prohibition on either Dahdaleh or Hall contacting each other or any prosecution witnesses, either directly or indirectly, unless through their solicitors.  The two men appeared in court again later in March, and also on 16 April 2012, at which time the court did not require the entry of a plea but did set a provisional trial date for 8 April 2013.On 5 November 2013, Dahdaleh went on trial in London's Southwark Crown Court for making corrupt payments.  He is expected to plead not guilty and argue that his payments to Sheikh Isa and Hall were essentially a tax or â€˜government sponsorshipâ€™ common in Bahrain.On 10 December 2013, the SFO announced â€œthere is no longer a realistic prospect of convictionâ€ù of businessman Victor Dahdaleh for alleged bribery in Bahrain. The case collapsed under the weight of a cooperating witness who reversed his prior statements and two others who refused to show up in court to testify, the SFO said.
The investigation is ongoing.

On 28 February 2013, the SEC announced that it charged Keyuan and former CFO Aichun Li for multiple alleged violations of the Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including the FCPA's books and records provisions. The SEC also announced that Keyuan and Li settled the charges with the SEC by paying fines of USD 1 million (Keyuan) and USD 25,000 (Li).
The investigation is ongoing.

BrazilOn 23 September 2014, authorities in Brazil filed a criminal action against eight Embraer SA employees for an alleged USD $3.5 million bribe to an official in the Dominican Republic in return for a USD $92 million contract for attack planes.  The Wall Street Journal said that the criminal complaint, "marks one of the first known efforts by Brazil to prosecute its citizens for allegedly paying bribes abroad [. . .]."U.S.The investigation is ongoing.
The investigations are ongoing.

Ng received a prison sentence of eight years for embezzlement, two years for corruption, two and half years for a false capital declaration, and two years for bribery.  The sentence totaled 14.5 years, but was commuted down to 13 years by the court.  Ng's lawyers and Australian diplomatic officials say he will appeal the sentence.	Zheng Hong, ET-China Chairman, was sentenced to 16 years in jail on related embezzlement and corporate charges.Kitty Yang, ET-China CFO, received 3.5 years also on related embezzlement and corporate charges.

In February 2009, KBR's successor company, Kellogg Brown & Root LLC, pleaded guilty to FCPA-related charges for its participation in the bribery scheme; it was ordered to pay a USD 402 million fine and to retain an independent compliance monitor for a three-year period.In June 2010, Technip entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the Department of Justice, whereby the company agreed to pay a USD 240 million criminal penalty and to retain an independent compliance monitor for two years.Likewise, in July 2010, the DOJ entered into a USD 240 million deferred prosecution agreement with Snamprogetti.In April 2011, JGC agreed to pay a criminal penalty of USD 218.8 million, in a two-year deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ, also requiring the retention of an independent compliance consultant for a period of two years. Albert "Jack" Stanley, former CEO of KBR, pleaded guilty in September 2008 to conspiring to violate the FCPA for his involvement.  In February 2009, Jeffrey Tesler and Wojciech J. Chodan, a former salesperson and consultant of a United Kingdom subsidiary of KBR, were also indicted.   Tesler was extradited from the United Kingdom, and pleaded guilty to conspiracy and FCPA charges, agreeing to pay USD 148,964,568.  In December 2010, Chodan was extradited from the UK and pleaded guilty to FCPA charges, paying USD 726,885 in penalties.On 17 January 2012, a criminal information was filed against the Japanese trading company, Marubeni Corporation, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas, charging the company with conspiracy to violate the FCPA, and with aiding and abetting violations of the FCPA.   An agreement was reached with the DOJ, whereby prosecution of the violations will be deferred for two years, and Marubeni will pay USD 54.6 million to the DOJ; if Marubeni abides by the terms of the agreement, the criminal information will be dismissed upon the expiry of the two year period.
A preliminary investigation by the DOJ and SEC was initiated in January 2012.  It is ongoing.
The investigation is ongoing.

According to a Wall Street Journal story from 9 July 2013, the SEC has told Wynn Resorts that is has decided to not recommend formal civil enforcement against the company regarding the donation to the University of Macau. The DOJ's investigation is ongoing.

In its SEC Form 10-Q filed on 1 November 2012, the Company announced the closure of the DOJ investigation:"The Company retained outside counsel to assist in its investigation of this matter. On January 24, 2012, the Company contacted the DOJ and the Securities and Exchange Commission to voluntarily disclose that the Company was conducting an internal investigation, and agreed to fully cooperate and update the DOJ and SEC periodically on further developments. The results of the investigation, which have been submitted to the DOJ and the SEC, did not substantiate initial information suggesting significant use of gift cards for improper purposes. On August 14, 2012, the DOJ closed its inquiry into this matter." It appears that the SEC's investigation is ongoing.

On 6 March 2012, India debarred IMI from bidding on any defense contracts for ten years.  IMI intends to appeal the decision.Then on 17 April 2012, the Indian Ministry of Defense fined IMI for breach of an integrity agreement in an arms contract.  The Ministry seized a USD 70 million (INR 2,240,000) bank guarantee of IMI.  An "integrity pact" is an undertaking by foreign companies that they will not enter into corrupt activity. On 17 September 2014, India announced that it was lifting the ban against IMI, and will allow the company to bid on its tenders.

On 14 March 2012, the DOJ filed a criminal information charging BizJet with one count of conspiring to violate the FCPA.  On the same day, the DOJ and BizJet entered into their DPA in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.  The Company agreed to pay a USD 11.8 million criminal penalty, and to report periodically to the DOJ during the three-year deferment period.  BizJet undertook to continue to implement enhanced compliance measures and internal controls in order to prevent and detect FCPA violations in the future.  If the DOJ is satisfied that BizJet has complied with this agreement, the criminal charges will be dropped at the end of the three-year period.BizJet's indirect parent company, Lufthansa, and the DOJ entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement in 2011, which stipulates that Lufthansa will cooperate with the ongoing investigation for a three-year period and pursue a program of rigorous internal controls. In exchange, the DOJ promised to not prosecute Lufthansa.The DOJ noted specifically that the Company voluntarily came forward to report the violations "prior to imminent threat of disclosure or government investigation." The DOJ also remarked on the "extraordinary cooperation" of BizJet and Lufthansa. In addition to the internal investigations and making employees accessible to the investigators, the companies "engaged in extensive remediation, including terminating the officers and employees responsible for the corrupt payments, enhancing their due-diligence protocol for third-party agents and consultants, and heightening review of proposals and other transactional documents for all BizJet contracts."On 5 April 2013, the DOJ issued a press release announcing that FCPA charges against four former BizJet executives from 2011 and 2012 have been unsealed. The press release stated that on 5 January 2012, Peter Dubois (former vice president of sales and marketing at BizJet) pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and one count of violating the FCPA, while Neal Uhl (former vice president of finance at BizJet) pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the FCPA. Despite the possibility of significant prison time for both men, the two were sentenced to eight months of home detention based on their cooperation with the DOJ's investigation. On 5 January 2012, charges of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and launder money and charges of violating the FCPA and laundering money were also filed against Bernd Kowalewski (former president and CEO of BizJet) and Jald Jensen (former BizJet sales manager), although the two are believed to be outside of the United States.  On 24 July 2014, Mr. Kowalewski pleaded guilty to the charges of paying  bribes to officials in Mexico and Panama in exchange for their assistance in securing contracts for BizJet to perform aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul services.
The investigations are ongoing.
The investigation in Australia is ongoing.
The investigation is ongoing.

After disclosing the suspect transactions to US and Danish authorities, Analogic terminated employment of BK Medical employees who were involved in the transactions, and began winding down its relationship with BK Medical distributors who were involved.  In its SEC filing, the Company explained, "Revenue from sales to the BK Medical distributors with whom we have decided to wind down BK Medical's relationship, represented less than 1% of our total revenue in fiscal year 2011 and less than 2.5% of our total revenue in the three and six months ended January 31, 2012. During the six months ended January 31, 2012, we incurred employee termination costs of approximately $400 and inquiry-related costs of approximately $1,204 in connection with this matter."

On September 26, 2013, the DOJ notified SL Industries that it had closed its inquiry  without filing criminal charges.  As of 19 March 2014, the Company did not yet receive an update from the SEC regarding the status of its inquiry.
The investigations are ongoing.
The investigation is ongoing.

Regarding the alleged payments to expedite licenses and visas, the DOJ notified the Company on 5 February 2013 that "their inquiry regarding this matter has been closed based upon a number of factors, including, but not limited to, the voluntary disclosure by the company, the thorough investigation undertaken by the company, and the steps taken to enhance the company's anti-corruption compliance program." The SEC's investigation of these allegations appears to be ongoing.
In March 2013, the company was informed by the DOJ and SEC that they had closed their two-year investigations into possible FCPA violations.
The investigations are ongoing.
The SFO's criminal investigation of ENRC is ongoing.
The SEC's investigation is ongoing.
The SEC's investigation is ongoing.

The Company was charged by the Public Prosecution Service of Canada on 15 January 2013 with one count under section 3(1)(b) of Canada's Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act.  On 22 January 2013, the Company pleaded guilty to the charge and agreed to pay a CAD 10.35 million fine.   The statement of facts noted that "the sentence imposed takes into consideration steps already taken by GEI to reduce the likelihood of it committing a subsequent related offence.  Those steps include the adoption of a robust anti-corruption compliance program and the strengthening of existing internal controls."On 25 January 2013 Justice Scott Brooker of Alberta's Queen's Bench agreed on the USD 9 million fine, plus the 15 percent victim fine surcharge, which he said reflected the severity of the offense.Crown prosecutor Robert Sigurdson also reportedly told journalists after the 22 January 2013 hearing that he expects the United States to back off its Griffiths Energy investigation now that Canada has dealt with the charges.According to news reports in Chad on 26 January 2013, (a day after the sentencing in Canada against Griffiths Energy), Chad's President Idriss Deby Itno immediately fired Mahamoud Adam Bechir from his post as Chadian Ambassador to South Africa.  As of 30 January 2013, the South African government labeled the post as vacant on their official website. The Globe and Mail reported on 22 March 2013 that Canadian authorities are seeking to force Ms. Nouracham Niam to disgorge the founders' shares she purchased at a discount from Griffiths Energy.
The investigation appears to be ongoing.

South Africa Several media outlets reported that the South African Directorate for Priority Crimes Investigation as well as the Department of International Relations & Cooperation each initiated investigations in the summer of 2012 into allegations that MTN Group paid bribes in Iran.  The recipients of the bribes were reported to include Yusuf Saloojee, former South African ambassador to Iran, as well as Javid Ghorban-Oghli, Iran's former deputy foreign minister.  The formal investigation by the Directorate for Priority Crimes was commenced by the specialized Hawks unit of the SA police in June 2012.  The investigation by the Department of International Relations was announced in July 2012 in a reply by the Minister to a parliamentary question from Democratic Alliance (DA) MP David Maynier. On 26 November 2013, Turkcell filed a civil complaint in a South Africa court against MTN, alleging that it was the victim of MTN's corrupt actions.U.S. The civil suit filed by Turkcell against MTN was dropped in May 2013.

ITALYOn 4 July 2014, Italian prosecutors opened a probe into alleged corruption relating to the 2011 acquisition of OPL 245 in Nigeria by Italian oil group Eni and Shell.On 11 September 2014, Milan prosecutors disclosed that the CEO of Eni, Claudio Descalzi, was under investigation for alleged corruption tied to the company's 2011 acquisition of a Nigerian deepwater offshore block for USD $1.09 billion. On 12 February 2015, Italian prosecutors sought to indict Eni, Saipem, and Paolo Scaroni, former chief executive of Eni, for allegedly paying bribes to Algerian officials to win contracts.Investigations are still ongoing.

AustraliaA press release by the UK Serious Fraud office on 16 October 2010 announced that "during a coordinated search and arrest operation, over 80 members of the Serious Fraud Office, supported by officers of Surrey, Hampshire, Thames Valley, Cumbria and the Metropolitan police services executed search warrants at 8 residential and a commercial site in the UK.  Two men were arrested and are being interviewed.  Two search warrants were also executed in Spain by the Spanish authorities in relation to three British nationals.  In addition six search warrants were executed on residential premises in Australia."Information gained from these searches and arrests led, in July and August 2011, to the arrest of nine former executives of the two RBA subsidiaries, who were formally charged with conspiring to bribe foreign public officials, under Australia's criminal code; they were also accused of false accounting.On 27 October 2011, both companies, NPA and Securency, entered guilty pleas at the Melbourne Magistrateâ€™s Court yesterday to three charges each of bribing or conspiring to bribe foreign officials to obtain a business advantage.  The charges involve fines of about USD 13,000 per count.  Six months later, on 12 March 2012, the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) released a statement saying that it did not intend to prosecute  Securency for securities offenses such as breach of fiduciary duty by company directors. ASIC refused to comment further on the case. Prosecution of IndividualsOn 18 July 2012, David John Ellery, who served as Securencyâ€™s CFO, pleaded guilty to a charge of false accounting in relation to a AUD 79,502 payment to Kuala Lumpur arms broker Abdul Kayum Syed Ahmad.  Specifically, Ellery admitted that he created a false document to facilitate a payment to Kayum even though he knew the latter  was not entitled to it.  Ellery is one of nine individuals to have been indicted by the Australian Federal Police.  In accepting his guilty plea, the Victoria Supreme Court acknowledged Ellery's willingness to testify against the eight remaining defendants.  Ellery's counsel noted that his client had not been involved in a wider conspiracy, and falsified documents at the behest of his superiors, and even that Ellery had warned senior colleagues at Securency that Kayum was not entitled to any money from the company. Following a hearing on 18 July 2012, the Supreme Court of Victoria (Melbourne) issued a sentencing judgment on 20 August 2012.  Ellery's offenses could invoke a maximum 10 year prison sentence.  The judge went to great lengths to explain Ellery's offense and the court's reasoning.  Ellery approved a commission payment to Kayum in Malaysia of AUD 79,502.  Later, when an invoice fabricated by Kayum reflected the same amount but showed an itemized list of "expenses," Ellery forwarded it for payment.  When questioned about the "expenses" subsequently, Ellery concealed the nature of the payment.  In his favor, the judge noted that Ellery did not create the false document, did not at first wish to approve it, ultimately approved it without any idea of personal gain.  When confronted, Ellery pleaded guilty early in the proceedings, and agreed to cooperate in ongoing investigations both of Securency and NPA offenses in Malaysia and other jurisdictions.The judge therefore sentenced Ellery to 6 months' imprisonment suspended for two years, meaning that the sentence could be imposed if, at any time during the coming two years, Ellery commits another offense punishable by imprisonment.Amended charge sheets were issued against 8 individuals on 14 August 2012:  Anderson, Boillot, Brady, Curtis, Gerathy, Hutchinson, Leckenby and  Marchant.  A summary of the charges follows:Mitchell Anderson â€“ Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and June 2000 in one instance, and February 2001 in another instance, to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia.Christian Boillot and Barry Brady â€“ Charged with conspiring between October 2001 and December 2003 to offer to provide a benefit to another person to whom such benefit was not legitimately due, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with Bank Negara Malaysia.Myles Curtis â€“ Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and June 2000 in one instance, and February 2001 in another instance,  to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia.Curtis is also charged with conspiring between October 2001 and December 2003 to offer to provide a benefit to another person to whom such benefit was not legitimately due, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with Bank Negara Malaysia.Curtis is also charged with conspiring between January 2001 and September 2004, and again between January and October 2003, with offering to provide a benefit to a person when not legitimately due to that person, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties, in order to obtain or retain business with the State Bank of Vietnam.Curtis is also charged with dishonestly falsifying documents made or required for an accounting purpose (by concurring in the making of a false debit note), between June and July 2006, with a view to gain for another.Clifford Gerathy â€“ Charged with conspiring between January 2001 and September 2004, and again between January and October 2003, with offering to provide a benefit to a person when not legitimately due to that person, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties, in order to obtain or retain business with the State Bank of Vietnam.Gerathy is also charged with dishonestly falsifying documents made or required for an accounting purpose (by concurring in the making of a false debit note), between June and July 2006, with a view to gain for another.Peter Hutchinson â€“ Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and February 2001 to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia.John Leckenby â€“ Charged with conspiring between December 1999 and February 2001 to confer a benefit on another person when such benefit was not legitimately due him, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with the Bank of Indonesia. Leckenby is also charged with conspiring between October 2001 and December 2003 to offer to provide a benefit to another person to whom such benefit was not legitimately due, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties in order to obtain or retain business with Bank Negara Malaysia.Rognvald Marchant â€“ One charge was withdrawn.  Leckenby is charged with conspiring between January 2001 and September 2004 to provide, and again between January and October 2003, with conspiring to offer to provide a benefit to a person when not legitimately due to that person, with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of the officialâ€™s duties, in order to obtain or retain business with the State Bank of Vietnam.Australian authorities are seeking the extradition of an Indonesian intermediary hired by the RBA, Radius Christanto, who was in custody in Singapore.   Together, Ellery and the other eight defendants are alleged to have made or authorized over AUD 1.6 million in improper payments.MalaysiaOn 1 July 2011, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission ("MACC") reported that Abdul Kayum bin Syed Ahmad, 62 years, Director of Aksavest Sdn. Bhd had been charged with having "corruptly given a gratification of RM 50,000.00 to Datoâ€™ Mohamad Daud bin Dol Moin through a middleman on the 24th November 2004 at EON Bank, Jalan Taipan, Subang Jaya, Selangor as an inducement to assist Note Printing Australia Ltd to secure currency printing contracts for RM5 polymer bank notes from Bank Negara Malaysia. The second charge is for a similar offence allegedly committed on 15th February 2005 at the same venue." Likewise, another press release was issued by the MACC on the same day, noting that "Datoâ€™ Mohamad Daud bin Dol Moin was earlier charged this morning at the Special Courts for Corruption at Jalan Duta, Kuala Lumpur Court Complex on two counts of charges for accepting the gratification from the accused, Abdul Kayum bin Syed Ahmad."Although NPA appears to remain under investigation by the Nigerian Economic and Financial Crimes Commission ("EFCC") for alleged bribery of Nigerian officials in order to secure a banknote supply contract, it is not clear whether Securency also is under investigation.   The Indonesian investigation into the companies may be ongoing as well. Likewise, an investigation appears to be underway in Vietnam. The Kantipur reported on 16 August 2011 that Nepal's Commission for Investigation of Abuse of Authority has initiated an investigation into the allegations in Nepal.

Conviction in absentia of three Chinese telecommunications employees; conviction and sentencing to 18 years in prison, plus fine and restitution, of Mohamed Boukhari, a former senior official with Algerie Telecom, and Chami Madjdoub, a businessman who also holds Luxembourg citizenship.  Both companies, Huawei and ZTE, have been debarred from bidding on public contracts in Algeria for two years.International warrants were issued for the arrest of the three Chinese employees.
Investigations ongoing

ItalyPublic Prosecutor of NaplesFinmeccanica's Half-year Financial Report ("Half-year Report"), which was published on 31 July 2012, reported that Finmeccanica complied with a court order on 28 June 2012 to produce evidence regarding the AgustaWestland helicopter contract with India.  Finmeccanica had previously provided documentation in April and May, including documents regarding the Company's relationship with foreign suppliers and intermediaries.  According to the Half-year Report, on 3 July 2012, the Public Prosecutor of Naples' office issued a search warrant for the offices of the chairman of FATA SpA, in connection with a criminal investigation about the chairman's relationship with "certain third parties."  Earlier orders for production of documents focus on contracts entered into in 2010 between Finmeccanica and/or its group companies (AgustaWestland, SELEX Sistemi Integrati, and Telespazio Argentina) and the government of Panama. Likewise, earlier requests were made for documents involving relations with a consultancy company called VL Consulting, and a promoter called Agafia Corp. Prosecutors also investigated promotional expenses connected with Alenia Aeronautica and AnsaldoBreda, and the supply by Ansaldo of trains for the underground metrorail system in Fortaleza, Brazil.  Reuters reported on 23 October 2012 that Paolo Pozzessere, a former business manager at Finmeccanica (he resigned from his position when allegations first emerged) and current adviser to Finmeccanica, was arrested in Milan in connection with corruption allegations regarding the Company's contracts in Brazil and Panama.  On the same day, police searched offices in both Naples and Rome. Reuters also reported that former Minister of Industry (under Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi) Claudio Scajola, is under investigation.On 24 March 2014, two former managers of Finmeccanica, Mr. Borgogni and Mr. Carlini, were placed under house arrest over allegations of international corruption connected to a tracking system for waste-hauling trucks.Public Prosecutor of MilanAccording to the Half-year Report, Ansaldo Energia SpA filed an appeal against a decision issued by the Milan Court on 20 September 2011 ordering the Company to pay an administrative fine of EUR 150,000.  A hearing is scheduled for 20 September 2012.  (Ansaldo Energia is 100% owned by Ansaldo Energia Holding, which in turn is 54.55% owned by Finmeccanica.)  The fine was imposed for bribery in the award of tenders.Reuters reported that the Public Prosecutor of Milan arrested Giuseppe Orsi, CEO and chairman of Finmeccanica, on 12 February 2013. Reuters also reported that three other people, including AgustaWestland CEO Bruno Spagnolini, were put under house arrest. The Wall Street Journal reported that Orsi's trial in Milan began on 19 June 2013.On 16 July 2014, an Italian judge issued arrest warrants for Christian Michell, a consultant based in Dubai, and Giuseppe Orsi, former chairman and CEO.  The judge declared the two fugitives and said the paperwork had been sent to their lawyers.Public Prosecutor of RomeAccording to the Half-year Report, in conjunction with the proceeding initiated against SELEX Sistemi Integrati, the prosecutor's office filed an attachment order against Electron Italia on 17 January 2012.  The order required the production of all agreements signed in 2009 between SELEX and Soluzioni di Business, a consulting company.  Electron Italia paid Soluzioni a flat sum of EUR 10,000 as "the contractually agreed amount . . . by way of a lump-sum reimbursement of expenses."  The Director of External Relations of SELEX was investigated; his employment was terminated on 7 December 2011.  The former chairman of Finmeccanica was also under investigation, and resigned on 1 December 2011.  The CEO of SELEX was investigated for bribery offenses, and tendered his resignation on 14 December 2011.  The Sales Manager of SELEX, also investigated for bribery, resigned on 13 December 2011. In an investigation into allegations of bribery in the assignment of projects by ENAV, the prosecutor's office issued a search warrant on 18 January 2012 to obtain contracts signed with Print Sistem and Electron Italia in 2009.  Additional warrants were issued on 8 March 2012 for 2009 contracts with ENAV.  On 23 April 2012, SELEX Sistemi Integrati was notified by the prosecutor's office of these document seizures. According to the Half-year Report, in February 2012, SELEX hired an expert, RINA Services, to investigate fairness in the allocation of contracts to Arc Trade, Print Sistem, Techno Sky, and Renco between January 2008 and November 2011.  Of the analyzed orders, orders or portions of orders totaling EUR 32 million (or 23% of the total) were found incongruent, whereas another portion of orders approximating EUR 16 million could not be analyzed because they are fixed-price orders. SELEX elected to proceed to an on-site analysis by RINA in October 2012.According to the Half-year Report, SELEX Sistemi Integrati commenced disciplinary proceedings in March 2012 against five employees, three of whom were terminated based on their conduct regarding the ENAV contracts.  (Electron Italia is 80% owned by SELEX Elsag SpA.  Digint Srl was at one time 49% owned by Finmeccanica Group Service, in turn wholly owned by Finmeccanica, and now renamed SELEX Elsag Cyberlabs, which is 49% owned by SELEX Elsag.)Public Prosecutor of L'Aquila According to the Half-year Report, criminal proceedings were initiated by the Aquila public prosecutor concerning orders placed between SELEX Service Management and Abruzzo Engineering (30% owned by SELEX).  This led to a bribery investigation of SELEX's operations manager, which is still pending.IndiaOn 12 February 2013, the New York Times reported that the Indian Defence Ministry had been seeking information from the governments of Italy and the United Kingdom. Unable to gather enough information to support the allegations, the Defence Ministry referred the case to the Central Bureau of Investigation ("CBI"). The Financial Times reported on 13 February 2013 that the CBI has initiated a probe into the allegations.BBC News reported on 13 March 2013 that the CBI has registered a criminal case against Finmeccanica, AgustaWestland and SP Tyagi, among others. The BBC News article said that the CBI conducted a number of raids (including a raid of Mr. Tyagi's home) on 13 March 2013 in its investigation of four companies and twelve individuals.In December 2013, India's Defense Ministry canceled the EU 556 million contract for twelve helicopters.On 26 August 2014, India banned Finmeccanica from future contracts, as the investigation into the canceled helicopter contract continues.  According to a report by Reuters, an anonymous source within the Defense Ministry said, "Where a tender process is yet to commence, a company under the Finmeccanica group of companies should not be given tender papers for purposes of bidding."On 17 September 2014, India announced that it was lifting the ban against Finmeccanica, and will allow the company to bid on its tenders.

United StatesOn 18 June 2012, the DOJ filed a two-count criminal information in the Eastern District of Virginia, charging DSS with substantive and conspiracy violations of the FCPA.  At the same time, the company entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ for a two year period.  The company agreed to pay a criminal penalty of USD 8.82 million, to cooperate with the DOJ, make periodic compliance reports, and continue to implement an enhanced compliance program.In announcing the DPA, the DOJ noted DSS' extraordinary cooperation, "including conducting an extensive, thorough and swift internal investigation; providing to the department extensive information and evidence; and responding promptly and fully to the department's requests...[and engaging] in extensive remediation, including terminating the officers and employees responsible for the corrupt payments; instituting a more rigorous compliance program; enhancing its due diligence protocol for third-party agents and subcontractors, strengthening its ethics policies; providing FCPA training for all agents and subcontractors; and establishing heightened review of most foreign transactions."LithuaniaOn 19 June 2012, the Lithuanian Prosecutor General's Office initiated a pre-trial investigation into the alleged corruption at Ignalina, through the Special Investigation Service of the Vilnius Regional Prosecutor's Office.
Investigations appear to be ongoing.

Resolutions with both the World Bank Group and the SFO were announced in separate press releases by OUP, WB and the SFO on 3 July 2012.  The WB's Negotiated Resolution Agreement involved three components:  (1) debarment of OUPEA and OUPT for a period of three years â€“ also involving cross-debarment by other development banks -- with OUP receiving a conditional non-debarment; (2) payment by OUP of USD 500,000 to the WB, "in order to remedy part of the harm done by the misconduct"; (3) a commitment by all three entities to cooperate with the World Bank's Integrity Vice Presidency and continue to improve their internal compliance programs. The Civil Recovery Order issued by the High Court to settle the complaint filed by the SFO against OPL mandates the payment of Â£1,895,435 plus the costs of pursuing the order, Â£12,500, and imposes an independent monitor.  The monitor must be independent of OUP and its subsidiaries, must be appointed within 120 days, and must submit a report within 12 months.  If after receipt of the monitor's report and resolution of any issues raised therein, the SFO is satisfied that the "Internal corporate policies, procedures and controls considered by the Independent Monitor meet the standards required by applicable English law and principles of good corporate governance in relation to a corporation operating in the UK," then the independent monitor will be discharged, and the trustee appointed by the court for oversight of the process shall also be discharged.The SFO's statement provides an explanation of how the penalty was calculated, and why the SFO elected to pursue a civil recovery order rather than a criminal penalty.  These reasons include:  lack of admissible evidence for a criminal process; the high cost and difficulty of conducting a criminal investigation abroad; the unlikelihood that cooperation by some of the foreign persons involved would be forthcoming; and finally, that "a civil recovery disposal allows a better strategic deployment of resources to other investigations which have a higher probability of leading to a criminal prosecution."  The SFO also credited OUP with good conduct in self-reporting, and noted both that "there is no evidence of Board level (or the equivalent) knowledge or connivance within OUP in relation to the business practices which led to the case being referred to the SFO" and that "the products supplied were of a good standard and provided at 'open market' values.  This means that the jurisdictions involved have not been victims as a result of overpaying for the goods or as a result being supplied goods which were unsuitable or not required."  The SFO concludes that the terms of the settlement "ensure all gross profit from any tainted contract will be disgorged."OUP offered to contribute Â£2,000,000 to non-profit educational institutions in sub-Saharan Africa as part of the settlement with the SFO.  But the SFO declined to include the offer in the terms of the civil recovery order, on the grounds that it is not the function of the SFO "to become involved in voluntary payments of this kind."In its own press release also dated 3 July 2012, OUP announced its voluntary contribution of Â£2 million to not-for-profit organizations for teacher training and other educational purposes in sub-Saharan Africa.   The Chief Executive of OUP noted that the contribution "is in part a recognition that the conduct of our two subsidiaries in East Africa fell well below the standards we expect within our organisation. At the same time it is a direct and effective way of improving educational opportunities for children in sub-Saharan Africa, in a way which is true to our core values."

On 17 July 2012, the Company signed a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the Department of Justice.  The agreement requires the payment of a USD 2 million penalty, as well as full cooperation with the DOJ for the three-year term of the agreement, and the submission of periodic reports to the DOJ regarding compliance efforts. The DOJ noted that the Company had demonstrated to the DOJ and an independent accounting expert that a fine exceeding USD 2 million would substantially jeopardize the Company's continued viability; therefore, the parties agreed to a fine amount well below the range provided by the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines.
UNITED STATESInvestigations by the DOJ and SEC are ongoing.INTERNALTeva's internal investigation is ongoing.
The investigations are ongoing.

The SEC filed a complaint against Wyeth in August 2012, announcing on 7 August 2012 separate settlements, subject to court approval, with both Wyeth and Pfizer. The two companies combined agreed to pay more than USD 45 million combined to settle their respective charges. Wyeth agreed to pay disgorgement of USD 17,217,831 in net profits and prejudgment interest of USD 1,658,793, for a total of USD 18,876,624.Wyeth's parent company, Pfizer, is required to make regular compliance reports to the SEC as part of its deferred prosecution agreement with the DOJ; as a Pfizer subsidiary, the status of Wyeth's remediation and implementation of its compliance program will be submitted with that of Pfizer.The company is permanently enjoined from further books and records violations.In a parallel action, the Department of Justice announced that Pfizer H.C.P. Corporation agreed to pay a USD 15 million penalty to resolve its FCPA investigation.
The investigation is ongoing.

On 5 September 2012, the French Court de Correction fined Safran Euro 500,000 for engaging actively in corruption in Nigeria.The investigating judge, Renaud Van Rymbeke, concluded that the company's top executives did not have personal knowledge of the corruption.  Two individuals, Jean Pierre Delarue, former Sagem engineer in Nigeria, and Francois Perrachon, former head of the Identification Systems Division, were questioned and then discharged by the court, despite prosecutors' demands that they each be fined Euro 15,000 and that they receive suspended jail sentences of 15 to 18 months.Safran intends to appeal the ruling.

SwedenOn 26 September 2012, the National Anti-corruption Unit of Sweden, operating from the office of the Prosecutor General, ordered the police to open an investigation into TeliaSonera's operations in Uzbekistan in 2007.  Police removed documents from the Company's offices.A few weeks later, on 16 October 2012, the Swedish court approved the prosecutors' request to freeze an account controlled by Takilant at Nordea Bank, which holds about USD 30 million.  The court agreed to the freeze by explaining that it had grounds to suspect two Uzbek nationals, Gayane Avakyan and Alisher Ergashev, of money laundering.  Attorneys for the two Uzbekis have denied the money laundering allegations.  On 28 March 2013, the Wall Street Journal reported that Swedish prosecutors gave notice to TeliaSonera that the Company might be liable for fines and forfeiture depending on the outcome of the investigation of the Company's former employees. A source told the Wall Street Journal that this notice is required under Swedish law and that it does not mean that prosecutors have initiated a new investigation of the Company. The Company again said that the allegations are not true. The Wall Street Journal reported on 18 April 2013 that the Company has hired an outside law firm to investigate the allegations and review the Company's transactions in Eurasia.Investigations are ongoing.United StatesOn 17 March 2014, TeliaSonera said that it had received requests from the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC"), which are investigating TeliaSonera's purchase of a 3G license in Uzbekistan in 2007.NetherlandsOn 12 March 2014, TeliaSonera said that its Dutch holding companies that control its operations in Uzbekistan had been raided by authorities in a preliminary investigation into bribery.
The investigation is ongoing.

The investigation is ongoing.On 19 September 2012, Mr. Prem, Mr. Baghat and three other individuals were arrested by the Indian authorities.  The five men appeared in court on 20 September 2012.Mr. Prem has apparently initiated a defamation claim against his former employer.
The investigation is ongoing.

In its SEC Form 10-Q filed for the quarter ending 30 June 2013 the Company indicated that on July 18, 2013 it received a letter from the DOJ indicating that the DOJ presently did not intend to take any enforcement action and is closing its inquiry into the matter.  The Company said that it is not currently able to predict the duration, scope or result of any SEC investigation, which remains ongoing.
The investigations are ongoing.

The investigation is ongoing.Tullow responded to the October 2011 accusations in Parliament by submitting documents in response to the Parliamentary Ad-Hoc Committee's requests.  Later, the Company stated that the documents purporting to show money transfers to the three three officials through bank accounts in Malta and the UK were forged.  The Company also submitted statements by the Maltese and London police saying that the documents were forged; it also submitted a letter from the SFO stating that the SFO had elected not to investigate the allegations against Tullow.  A press statement was made available on Tullow's website in April 2012.
The investigation is ongoing.

NIGERIAOn 10 December 2013, Bilfinger agreed to pay a USD $32 million penalty and retain an independent corporate compliance monitor for at least 18 months to resolve charges that Bilfinger violated and conspired to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by bribing government officials in Nigeria to get contracts as part of a USD $387 million gas project. The company entered into a three-year deferred-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Department of Justice, which charged Bilfinger in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas with violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in a three-count criminal information document.An investigation by German prosecutors appears to be ongoing.EASTERN EUROPEThe German, Austria, Hungary and Slovakia investigations appear to be ongoing.BRAZILThe Brazilian Justice Ministry announced on 23 March 2015 that it has launched an investigation into bribes allegedly paid to secure $6.5 million in contracts for traffic control centers and integrated security for host cities of the 2014 World Cup. Bilfinger is currently conducting an internal investigation.

Sanader led the Croatian Democratic Union, and was elected prime minister in 2003 and again in 2007. He left office without explanation in 2009.  He was arrested in Austria in December 2010, and extradited to Croatia in July 2011.After a trial in the district court, on 20 November 2012, Ivo Sanader  was sentenced to ten years in prison, having been found guilty of bribery and abuse of power involving both Hypo Alpe-Adria and Mol Nyrt, a Hungarian oil refining company.

On 23 November 2012, Abbot agreed to a civil settlement of GBP 5.6 million (USD 8.9 million), which represents the profit obtained from a 2006 contract between an overseas unit of Abbot and an oil and gas company.  The settlement, similar to a Non Prosecution Agreement, is allowed under Scottish law under certain circumstances, which include voluntary disclosure, and the action taken by the company following discovery of the improper payments.  In Abbot's case, the personnel involved left the company, and Abbot undertook a thorough independent investigation.The penalty will be paid in three installments to the "CashBack for Communities Programme" established by the Scottish government. The program takes money from the Proceeds of Crime Act and invests it in sporting, cultural, community mentoring projects and sports facilities for the benefit of Scottish youth and communities. The Company stated that it could not disclose details about the persons or the jurisdiction involved, pending a possible criminal investigation of those individuals.In a 25 November 2012 press statement, the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service listed the criteria taken into consideration in deciding to refer the case to the Civil Recovery Unit for extra-judicial settlement, in accordance with the published guidance on self-reporting:  noted that In accordance with the published guidance on self-reporting, the following criteria were considered in the decision to refer this case to the Civil Recovery Unit for an extra-judicial settlement:  "the nature and seriousness of the offence and the extent of the harm caused;  the extent of the wrongdoing within the business, including whether the conduct was authorised by, or connived in, by senior management, or restricted to a small number of lower-ranking individuals; whether it is clear that the business is taking action as soon as the matter comes to the attention of senior management (as opposed to taking no action until it becomes aware that there is a risk that the conduct is going to come to light whether the business (or the individuals involved in the matter reported) has any previous record for this type of conduct. This would go beyond a previous criminal conviction, and would include any regulatory enforcement action or warning; whether the individuals involved in the wrongdoing have left the business and, where decisions were taken at Board level, whether there is a new Board in place, and in both cases the timing and reasons for the departure of these individuals; whether the business has honoured its commitment to engage with the Crown meaningfully and in particular to disclose the full extent of the wrongdoing; whether the business had in place adequate anti-bribery systems at the time of the criminal conduct and whether it has further addressed this following the conduct; whether there are particular considerations which may weigh against prosecution, such as the consequences of prosecution for the company's employees and stakeholders."Abbot is the first Scottish company, and one of the first companies altogether, to enter into a civil settlement under the 2011 self-reporting program introduced when the Bribery Act came into effect.

In an SEC Form 8-K filed on 4 December 2012, the Company announced that on 30 November 2012, it had received letters from the DOJ and SEC informing the company that these agencies, along with the FBI, had begun an investigation into whether Net 1 UEPS Technologies, Inc. and its subsidiaries, including their officers, directors, employees, and agents had violated the FCPA. The SEC's letter states that the investigation is a non-public, fact-finding inquiry. The Company stated that it intended to cooperate fully with the DOJ and the SEC.

UNITED KINGDOM In a press release on 6 December 2012, Rolls Royce announced that it voluntarily disclosed information relating to concerns about bribery and corruption involving intermediaries in overseas markets to the U.K. Serious Fraud Office ("SFO").  The company claimed it made the disclosures following a request for information from the SFO about allegations of malpractice in Indonesia and China. On 23 December 2013, Rolls Royce announced that the SFO opened a formal investigation into allegations of bribery and corruption in China and Indonesia.  The SFO arrested two men on 12 February 2014 in connection with the Rolls Royce corruption investigation in Asia -- Bhanu Choudhrie, executive director of C&C; Alpha Group Ltd., and his father, Sudhir Choudhrie.  No charges were filed, and the Choudhries denied any wrongdoing.  In July 2014, bail was lifted for the two men, and according to The Sunday Times, they are not expected to play a further role in the inquiry.  The SFO investigation is ongoing.UNITED STATESOn 5 March 2014, Rolls Royce announced that the U.S. Department of Justice ("DOJ") launched an informal investigation following allegations that its executives bribed officials in Indonesia, China and India in order to win lucrative contracts.The DOJ investigation is ongoing.INDIAThe CBI investigation is ongoing.  On 17 September 2014, India announced that it was lifting the ban against Rolls Royce, and will allow the company to bid on its tenders.BRAZILWhile Rolls-Royce was named by a Petrobras executive as having paid bribes, Rolls-Royce stated in February 2015 that it has not been approached by Brazilian authorities.INTERNALIn January 2013, Rolls Royce announced the appointment of Lord Gold, a well known attorney, to lead a review of the Company's compliance policies and procedures.

United KingdomOn 17 December 2012, four individuals were charged by the Serious Fraud Office with conspiracy to corrupt.  The four are Paul Jacobs, Bharat Sodha, Nidhi Vyas, and Trevor Bruce. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for 22 February 2013.The Swift Group is cooperating with the SFO in its investigation.  The Company is not facing criminal charges.

The Jakarta Globe reported on 4 December 2012 that Shiokawa Toshio was found guilty of bribing Imas Dianasari and sentenced to three years in prison. Toshio was also required to pay a fine of IDR 200 million (approximately USD 20,800) or spend six additional months in prison. According to the Jakarta Globe story, Toshio (who is a Japanese national) is "Indonesia's first foreign graft convict." The Jakarta Globe also reported that Imas Dianasari (the judge who accepted the bribe) and Odi Juanda (the human resources manager who paid the bribe) were sentenced to six years and four years in prison, respectively.
Internal and Chinese investigations ongoing.
Investigations reopened and ongoing.
The investigation is ongoing.
The investigations are ongoing.

United KingdomThe case was scheduled for trial in November 2012 in London, but the results were not published.United StatesOn 6 January 2015, a federal grand jury in Philadelphia indicted the former owner and president of Chestnut Consulting for bribing an official of the EBRD.  Dmitrij Harder was charged with one count of conspiracy to violate the FCPA and Travel Act, five counts of violating the FCPA, five counts of violating the Travel Act, one count of conspiracy to commit international money laundering, and two counts of money laundering.

Turks and Caicos Islands EnforcementOn 23 January 2013, media reports announced that Sandals had settled with the Turks and Caicos Islands Government for USD 12 million.  According to some reports, the Turks and Caicos' enforcement authority, the Special Investigation Prosecution Team (SIPT), took into consideration "the co-operation of the company with the United States authorities to a degree that has been acknowledged to be both extraordinary and unique and included the early and voluntary release of valuable evidence that has been shared with the SIPT.  That information has materially assisted SIPT's investigations."  The agreement between the company and the government of Turks and Caicos Islands was also reportedly "without any admission of liability by the company, its directors and/or officers. It does not however prevent the prosecution of any other persons in respect of any facts and matters."Related Private Action in the BahamasAccording to news reports, on 30 June 2011, the company sued Dr. Jeffrey Pyne for his alleged role in making the unauthorized wire transfers on behalf of Sandals Resorts International.  Pyne contends that he cannot recall agreeing to serve as a director of Sandals Resorts International and that the action before the Bahamian Supreme Court was filed to avoid litigation in either the Turks and Caicos Islands or Jamaica.

United StatesThe DOJ and SEC investigations are ongoing.Hong KongOn 20 December 2011, the Wall Street Journal reported that the Securities and Futures Commission in Hong Kong had notified SCL that it conducted an investigation of undisclosed allegations relating to SCL and that it would not take any regulatory action against it. The article stated that it is unclear whether this investigation was in any way related to the investigations of the DOJ and SEC, and it is also unknown if any allegations of bribery were investigated.

The Wall Street Journal reported on 8 March 2013 that the U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission ("SEC") initiated an investigation into the allegations. The Wall Street Journal also said that a member of the SEC's staff arranged to meet with Daniela Gonzalez, Brookfield Brazil's former chief financial officer and the source of the bribery allegations.On 19 November 2013, Brazilian prosecutors reported its investigation into Brookfield and its subsidiary, BISA.
